Function: delextract(<string>, <first>, <length>[, <delim>])
  
  Delextract returns a string of words that were not in the list that you
  specified.  This in effect works exactly opposite of extract...
explanation:
Function: delextract(<string>, <first>, <length>[, <delim>])
  
  Delextract returns a string of words that were not in the list that you
  specified.  This in effect works exactly opposite of extract.  Delim
  may be used to specify a delimiter other than space if desired.
  
  Examples:
    > say delextract(This is a really neat example, 4, 2)
    You say "This is a example"
    > say extract(Another@funky@test@for@extract, 3, 3, @)
    You say "Another@funky"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), index(), insert(), ldelete(), replace(),
            randextract()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: elist() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for elist() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: elist(<str>[,<phrase>[,<delim>[,<sep>[,<punctuation>[,<munge>]]]]])
  
  The elist function is used to return a list of words into an English
  recognizable format.  You may specify an outpu...
explanation:
Function: elist(<str>[,<phrase>[,<delim>[,<sep>[,<punctuation>[,<munge>]]]]])
  
  The elist function is used to return a list of words into an English
  recognizable format.  You may specify an output delimiter to use if
  you wish but it makes the format rather unique.  You may specify a separate
  punctuation instead of the default comma (,).  The punctuation may be
  more than one character.  You may specify the separator if not a space as 
  well.
  
  You can also supply a munging function to apply for each argument passed to
  elist.  So that if you passed in dbref#'s, you can munge to the name()
  function.  All arguments are passed as %0.  The order number of how they're
  passed is %1.
  
  Examples:
    > say elist(test)
    You say "test"
    > say elist(this test)
    You say "this and test"
    > say elist(this test again)
    You say "this, test, and again"
    > say elist(this test again,,,,;)
    You say "this; test; and again"
    > say elist(this test again,at least I think)
    You say "this, test, at least I think again"
    > say elist(one/two/three,what a life,/)
    You say "one, two, what a life three"
    > say elist(one/two/three,what a life,/,/)
    You say "one,/two,/what a life/three"
  
  See Also: iter(), citer(), nsiter(), list(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CREPLACE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CREPLACE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: creplace(<string>, <position>, <string2>[, <type>][,<range>])
            creplace(<string>, <position list>, <character>)
  
  The creplace function will replace characters starting at posi...
explanation:
Function: creplace(<string>, <position>, <string2>[, <type>][,<range>])
            creplace(<string>, <position list>, <character>)
  
  The creplace function will replace characters starting at position
  <position> and based on the type, will continue to overwrite till
  end of one of the strings.  You can replace one or more characters.
  
  If you specify the range, it will give the number of characters to enact
  upon.  Default is length of string2.
  
  The second option only allows three arguments, and will replace the 
  character positions specified in the space delimited <position list>
  with the character(s) specified with <character>.  If you specify more
  than one character, it will continue to wrap around the list until
  the end of the string is met.
  
  Note:  The second option can use output from totpos() to stage and prep
         the values you want to replace depending on the situation.
  
  This function is UTF8 and ansi aware.
    
  Valid types are: 
        o - overwrite : starting at position it'll continue to overwrite
            until the end of the <string2>. (this is the default behavior)
        c - overwrite and cut: starting at position it'll continue to
            overwrite up to the maximum length of the original string.
        i - insert : starting at position it'll insert all of string2
            into the string.
        r - replace string at position with <string2>
  
  Examples:
    > say creplace(this is a test,4,whee)
    You say "thiwhee a test"
    > say creplace(this is a test,4,wheewheewhoowha!)
    You say "thiwheewheewhoowha!"
    > say creplace(this is a test,4,wheewheewhoowha!,c)
    You say "thiwheewheewho" 
    > say creplace(this is a test,4,wheewheewhoowha!,i)
    You say "thiwheewheewhoowha!s is a test"
    > say creplace(this is a test,4,moo!,r)
    You say "thimoo!"
  
  Option 2 Example:
    > say creplace(this is a test,1 3 4,X)
    You say "XhXX is a test"
    > say creplace(this is a test,1 3 4,XYZ)
    You say "XhYZ is a test"
  
  See Also: replace(), lreplace(), totpos(), elementpos(), ruler()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: strmath() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for strmath() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: strmath (syntax follows)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  The strmath function is used to apply math to the entire string.  Numbers
  in th...
explanation:
Function: strmath (syntax follows)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  The strmath function is used to apply math to the entire string.  Numbers
  in the string are modified based on the math chosen applied to the number.
  You may specify optional input and output separators.  You may also specify
  the word to start (<st>) the math on and how many words (<amt>) after the 
  start you wish to use. If no math is specified, '+' is used as a default.
  The <idlm> and <isep> are inner delimiter and separator to use for the 
  normal delimited string.  This is so you can separate values such as:
  
                    To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15
  
  Note:  It handles floating point notation, so values with decimals are seen.
   
    Key:  str  -- input string    num  -- value to apply  math -- math to use
          dlm  -- delimiter       sep  -- separator       st   -- start value
          amt  -- word count      idlm -- inner delim     isep -- inner sep
          low  -- low val match   hi   -- high val match
  
  You may specify the 'low' and 'hi' values to specify a range of what values
  you wish to apply the math to.
   
{ see 'help strmath2' for value values for <math> and examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: strmath2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for strmath2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code: + - apply addition to all numbers in the string.
explanation:
Function: strmath (syntax follows)  (CONTINUED)
  strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>)
  
  Valid <math> arguments are:
        + - apply addition to all numbers in the string.
        - - apply subtraction to all numbers in the string.
        / - apply division to all numbers in the string.
        * - apply multiplication to all numbers in the string.
       %% - return remainder of division. (you need to use two %%'s)
  
  Valid conditional <math> arguments are:
         <VALUE - set to <num> for every condition < VALUE (eg. <10)
         >VALUE - set to <num> for every condition > VALUE (eg. >10)
         =VALUE - set to <num> for every condition = VALUE (eg. =10)
        !=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition != VALUE (eg. !=10)
        <=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition <= VALUE (eg. <=10)
        >=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition >= VALUE (eg. >=10)
  
  Examples:
    > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish green fish blue fish,10,+)   (default)
    You say "11 fish 12 fish green fish blue fish"
    > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish green fish blue fish,10,*)
    You say "10 fish 20 fish green fish blue fish"
    > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish 3 shoe 4 shoe,10,+,,,3,2)
    You say "1 fish 12 fish 13 shoe 4 shoe"
    > say strmath(To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15,150,+,|,|,1,0,:,:)
    You say "To hit:155|To Damage:10|Base AC:15"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,<40)
    You say "0 beats 0 but is less than 100"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,>40)
    You say "10 beats 5 but is less than 0"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,=5)
    You say "10 beats 0 but is less than 100"
    > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,!=5)
    You say "0 beats 5 but is less than 0"
  
  See Also: add(), sub(), mul(), div(), mod(), strfunc(), spellnum()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: STRFUNC() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for STRFUNC() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @list options system will also show the state of this feature.
explanation:
Function: strfunc(<function>, <list of arguments>[,<delim>])
  
  The strfunc (string function) function is used to transform a 
  string of arguments into separate identified arguments and feed 
  them into the specified function.  If you do not have access to the 
  function or if you give the target function an invalid number of 
  arguments, an error message will be displayed.
  
  This in effect will turn any function in the game into a string
  oriented function.  Thus the name, 'strfunc'.
  
  This will optionally allow executing @functions and/or @lfunctions
  based on the config parameter strfunc_softfuncs.
    0 - only hardcoded functions
    1 - hardcoded and @functions
    2 - hardcoded, @functions, and @lfunctions.
  
  You may use the config() function to check the value of the
  strfunc_softfuncs config parameter.
  
  @list options system will also show the state of this feature.
  
  Examples:
    > say add(1,2,3,4)
    You say "10"
    > say strfunc(add,1 2 3 4)
    You say "10"
    > say strfunc(add,1@2@3@4,@)
    You say "10"
    > say hastype(me,player)
    You say "1"
    > say strfunc(hastype,me player)
    You say "1"
    > say switch(add(1,1),2,match,1,nope,0,nope,nope)
    You say "match"
    > say strfunc(switch,add(1,1) 2 match 1 nope 0 nope nope)
    You say "match"
  
  See Also: strmath(), ladd(), lsub(), ldiv(), lmul(), passthrough()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: wildmatch() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for wildmatch() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: wildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
 
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the number of the first word that matches.  If no words match then 0 ...
explanation:
Function: wildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
 
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the number of the first word that matches.  If no words match then 0 is
  returned.  The case of the characters being matched is not significant.
 
  The words in the string  may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' 
  matches any one character, while '*' matches any number of characters, 
  including none.  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', 
  but 's*x' would match any of them.  <delim> may be used specified to 
  specify a delimiter other than a space.
  Examples:
    > say wildmatch(This is a test, test)
    You say "4"
    > say wildmatch(This is a test, is)
    You say "2"
    > say wildmatch(This *is* a test, whiss)
    You say "2"
    > say wildmatch(This is a test *, *not*)
    You say "5"
    > say wildmatch(This is a test, is a)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: member(), strmatch(), subnetmatch(), numwildmatch(), 
            totwildmatch(), match()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: numwildmatch() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for numwildmatch() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: numwildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>]) 
  
  This function returns the total number of matches <pattern> against each
  word of <string>.  If no words match, then 0 is returned.  The c...
explanation:
Function: numwildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>]) 
  
  This function returns the total number of matches <pattern> against each
  word of <string>.  If no words match, then 0 is returned.  The case is 
  not significant.  This works like wildmatch() except returns # of matches. 
  
  The string may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' matches any one
  character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none.
  So 'b??f' would match 'biff', 'boff', 'beef', but not 'borchf'.  'b*f'
  would match any of them though.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than the standard space.
  
  Examples:
  > say numwildmatch(This is a test, test)
  You say '1'
  > say numwildmatch(This test is a test of nummatch.  A test is fun, test)
  You say '3'
  > say numwildmatch(This test *e* is silly *ed, fred)
  You say '2'
  
  See Also: nummatch(), nummember(), wildmatch(), totwildmatch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: totwildmatch() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for totwildmatch() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: totwildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
  
  This function returns all matches of <pattern> against each word of
  <string>.  This works just like wildmatch(), except it returns every
 ...
explanation:
Function: totwildmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
  
  This function returns all matches of <pattern> against each word of
  <string>.  This works just like wildmatch(), except it returns every
  match and location of each match.  String also understands wildcarding
  such as '?' or '*'.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than the standard space.
  
  Examples:
  > say totwildmatch(This is a test, test)
  You say "4"
  > say totwildmatch(This test is a test of totmatch. A test is fun, test)
  You say "2 5 9"
  > say totwildmatch(This test *e* is silly *ed, fred)
  You say "3 6"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), totmember(), wildmatch(), numwildmatch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TOTMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TOTMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: totmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
  
  This function returns all matches of <pattern> against each word of
  <string>.  This works just like match(), except it returns every
  match a...
explanation:
Function: totmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
  
  This function returns all matches of <pattern> against each word of
  <string>.  This works just like match(), except it returns every
  match and location of each match.  This also understands wildcarding
  such as '?' or '*'.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than the standard space.
  
  Examples:
  > say totmatch(This is a test, test)
  You say "4"
  > say totmatch(This test is a test of totmatch. A test is fun, test)
  You say "2 5 9"
  > say totmatch(This test is silly, fred)
  You say "0"
  
  See Also: match(), nummatch(), member(), nummember(), totmember()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: GRABALL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for GRABALL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: graball(<string>, <pattern>[, <delimeter>[, <separator>]])
   
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the all the words it matches.  If no words are fou...
explanation:
Function: graball(<string>, <pattern>[, <delimeter>[, <separator>]])
   
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the all the words it matches.  If no words are found to match the pattern,
  then an empty string is returned.  <pattern> may consist of wildcards.
  Wildcards being the use of '*' for any number of characters or '?' for
  a single character.  An optional delimiter may be used as well as an
  optional output separator. 
  
  Examples:
    > graball(This is a test,*es*)
    You say "test"
    > graball(This is a test,*is*)
    You say "This is"
    > graball(players are cool.,*y*)
    You say "players"
    > graball(this is@a test,*es*,@)
    You say "a test"
    > graball(this is@a test@2 test,*es*,|)
    You say "a test|2 test"
 
  See Also: match(), member(), totmatch(), totmember(), grep(), grab()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: grab(<string>, <pattern>[, <delimeter>])
   
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning

  then an empty string is returned.  <pattern> may consist of wildcards.
  Wildcards being the use of '*' for any number of characters or '?' for
  a single character.  An optional delimiter may be used.
  
  Examples:
    > grab(This is a test,*es*)
    You say "test"
    > grab(players are cool.,*y*)
    You say "players"
    > grab(this is@a test,*es*,@)
    You say "a test"
   
  See Also: match(), member(), totmatch(), totmember(), grep(), graball()

title: REGRAB() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGRAB() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: regrab(<list>, <regexp>[, <delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the first word in list which matches the pattern.
  For grab(), the pattern is specified as in match(); i.e., it
  can cont...
explanation:
Function: regrab(<list>, <regexp>[, <delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the first word in list which matches the pattern.
  For grab(), the pattern is specified as in match(); i.e., it
  can contain wildcards. For regrab(), the pattern is a regular expression.
  
  Basically, this is a much more efficient way to do:
  1: extract(list, match(list, pattern, delimiter), 1) 
  2: extract(list, regmatch(list, regexp, delimiter), 1)
  
  Examples:
    > say regrab(this that those, (.)hat)
    You say "that"
    > say regrab(this tHat those phat, (.)hat)
    You say "phat"
  
  See Also: regrabi(), regraball(), regraballi(), grab(), graball()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: regrabi(<list>, <regexp>[, <delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the first word in list which matches the pattern.
  For grab(), the pattern is specified as in match(); i.e., it
  can contain wildcards. For regrab(), the pattern is a regular expression.
  regrabi() is case-insensitive.
  
  Basically, this is a much more efficient way to do:
  1: extract(list, match(list, pattern, delimiter), 1)
  2: extract(list, regmatch(list, regexp, delimiter), 1)
  
  Examples:
    > say regrabi(this that those, (.)hat)
    You say "that"
    > say regrab(this tHat those phat, (.)hat)
    You say "tHat"
  
  See Also: regrab(), regraball(), regraballi(), grab(), graball()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REGRABALL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGRABALL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: regraball(<string>,<regexp>[,<delim>][,<output separator>])
  
  These functions work identically to the grab() and regrab()/regrabi()

explanation:
Function: regraball(<string>,<regexp>[,<delim>][,<output separator>])
  
  These functions work identically to the grab() and regrab()/regrabi()
  functions, save that they return all matches, not just the first: They
  return all words in the list <string> which match <pattern>.
  If none match, an empty string is returned.
  
  Examples:
  > say graball(This is a test of a test,test)
  You say "test test"
  > say graball(This is testing a test,tes*)
  You say "testing test"
  > say regraball(This is testing a test,s$)
  You say "This is"
  
  See also: match(), matchall(), grab(), regmatch(), regraballi(), regrab()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: GREP() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for GREP() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: grep(<object>, <attribute(s)>, <pattern> [,<key>])
   
  This returns a list of any matching attribute that matches the
  <attribute(s)> that contain <pattern>.  The <attribute> may be wildc...
explanation:
Function: grep(<object>, <attribute(s)>, <pattern> [,<key>])
   
  This returns a list of any matching attribute that matches the
  <attribute(s)> that contain <pattern>.  The <attribute> may be wildcarded
  with a '*' or a '?' for multiple character matches and single character
  matches respectively.  In addition, the pattern may also be wildcarded.
   
  If <key> is specified as '1', it will no longer assume a wildcard match
  unless explicitly given.
   
  Examples:
    > @va me=This is a test
    > @vb me=This is another test.
    > @vc me=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say grep(me,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say grep(me,v*,is,1)
    You say "VA VB"
    > say grep(me,v*,*is*)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say grep(me,*,*)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say grep(me,*,Bark?)
    You say ""
 
  See Also: pgrep(), regrep(), regrepi(), grab(), match(), lattr(), @grep
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PGREP() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PGREP() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: pgrep(<object>, <attr(s)>, <pattern> [,<type> [,<delim> [,<key>]]])
  
  This function behaves just like the normal grep() function except it 
  transverses all parents for the grep that ret...
explanation:
Function: pgrep(<object>, <attr(s)>, <pattern> [,<type> [,<delim> [,<key>]]])
  
  This function behaves just like the normal grep() function except it 
  transverses all parents for the grep that returns a list of any matching 
  attribute that matches the <attr(s)> that contain <pattern>.  The <attr> 
  may be wildcarded with a '*' or a '?' for multiple character matches and 
  single character matches respectively.  In addition, the pattern may also 
  be wildcarded.  You may specify an optional output delimiter.  
  The valid types are:
      0 - show just matched attributes (default)
      1 - show the dbref# then matching attributes after it in sets
      2 - show the attributes in a dbref#/attribute pattern.
  
  By default, grep assumes the pattern is always wildcarded.  You may specify
  the key of '1' to disable assumed wildcarding and enforce literal wildcard
  placement.
    
  Examples:
    > @va me=This is a test
    > @vb me=This is another test.
    > @vc me=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say pgrep(me,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say pgrep(me,v*,is,,,1)
    You say "VA VB"
    > say pgrep(me,v*,*is*)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say pgrep(me,*,*)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say pgrep(me,*,Bark?)
    You say ""
 
  See Also: grep(), regrep(), regrepi(), grab(), match(), lattr(), @grep
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REGREP() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGREP() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: regrep(<object>,<attrs>,<regexp> [,<key>])
  
  This function returns a list of attributes on <object> containing
  <pattern> (or matching <regexp>).  <attrs> is a wildcard pattern for
  att...
explanation:
Function: regrep(<object>,<attrs>,<regexp> [,<key>])
  
  This function returns a list of attributes on <object> containing
  <pattern> (or matching <regexp>).  <attrs> is a wildcard pattern for
  attribute names to search; if you want to search all attributes, use "*".
  
  Parsing _does_ occur before this function is invoked. Therefore,
  "special" characters will need to be escaped out. 
  
  If <key> is specified as '1', attribute wildcards are done with
  regular expression matching.  The default is globbing (* and ?). 
  
  This function is case-sensitive. 
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=This is a test
    > @vb me=This is another test.
    > @vc me=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say regrep(me,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB"
    > say regrep(me,v*,.is.)
    You say "VA VB VC"
  
  See Also: regrepi(), grep(), pgrep()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REGEDIT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGEDIT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: regedit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
            regeditlit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that ...
explanation:
Function: regedit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
            regeditlit(<str>, <regexp>, <repl>[, ... , <regexpN>, <replaceN>])
  
  This function is a version of edit() that uses regular expressions.
  The part of <str> that matches the <regexp> is replaced by the
  evaluated <repl> (replacement), with $<number> in <replacement> expanded to
  the corresponding matching sub-expression of <regexp>, with $0 the entire
  matched section. regediti() only replaces the first match and is
  case sensitive.  The <replacement> argument is evaluated once for 
  each match, allowing for more complex transformations than is possible 
  with straight replacement.
  
  The regeditlit() function works same as regedit() but does not evaluate 
  the replaced values.
  
  Example:
  > say regedit(this test is the best string, (.)est, $1rash)
  You say "this trash is the best string"
  > say regedit(this test is the best string, (.)est, [capstr($1)]rash)
  You say "this Trash is the best string"
  
  See also: medit(), edit(), editansi(), regmatch(), regediti(), regeditall(), 
            regeditalli()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REGNUMMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGNUMMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: regnummatch(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
            regnummatchi(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the total matches of any word in the string
  that mat...
explanation:
Function: regnummatch(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
            regnummatchi(<string>, <regexp>, [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the total matches of any word in the string
  that matches the specified regular expression.  This works exactly
  like nummatch() except it uses regular expressions.
  
  Example:
  > say regnummatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
  You say "2"
  
  See Also: nummatch(), regmatch(), regmatchall(), regmatchalli()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REGLMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGLMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: reglmatchalli(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchall(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchi(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatch(<...
explanation:
Function: reglmatchalli(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchall(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatchi(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
            reglmatch(<string>, <regexp> [,<delimiter>])
  
  This function returns the positional matches of every word in the
  string that matches the specified regular expression.  This is
  exactly like the totmatch() function except uses regular 
  expression matching.  This function is case sensitive.
  
  The non 'all' functions will only return the position of the first
  match, or in other words functions like match() would.
   
  The reglmatchi() and reglmatchalli() functions ignores case.
  
  Example:
    > say reglmatchall(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4 6"
    > say reglmatch(one two three four five fourteen,.*ou.*)
    You say "4"
  
  See Also: totmatch(), regmatch(), regnummatch(), nummatch()
  
  'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REGMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REGMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: regmatch(<string>,<regexp>[,<register list>])
  
  This function matches the regular expression <regexp> against the
  entirety of <string>, returning 1 if it matches and 0 if it does not.
 ...
explanation:
Function: regmatch(<string>,<regexp>[,<register list>])
  
  This function matches the regular expression <regexp> against the
  entirety of <string>, returning 1 if it matches and 0 if it does not.
  This function is case sensitive.  It behaves like strmatch().
  
  If <register list> is specified, there is a side-effect: any
  parenthesized substrings within the regular expression will be set
  into the specified local registers, in the order they were specified
  in the list. <register list> can be a list of one through nine numbers.
  If the specified register is -1, the substring is not copied into a
  register. Under regmatchi, case of the substring may be modified.
  You may also use a-z as registers if currently enabled on your RhostMUSH.
  You may have to escape mush-special characters (like (, ), {, }, etc)
  Any invalid registers specified will be skipped over and ignored.
  
  Register list may contain labels.
    
  Examples:
    > say regmatch(cookies=30,\(.+\)=\(\[0-9\]*\))
    You say "1"
    > say regmatch(cookies=30,\(.+\)=\(\[0-9\]*\),0 3 5) |%q0/%q3/%q5|
    You say "1 |cookies=30/cookies/30|
  
  See Also: 'help regexp syntax' for an explanation of regular expressions.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: DICE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for DICE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: dice(<val1>,<val2>[[[[[,<type>],<botval>],<sep>],<fail>],<crit>])
   
  This function rolls the dice.  It works as if you were rolling dice and 
  returns the result.  <val1> is the number o...
explanation:
Function: dice(<val1>,<val2>[[[[[,<type>],<botval>],<sep>],<fail>],<crit>])
   
  This function rolls the dice.  It works as if you were rolling dice and 
  returns the result.  <val1> is the number of dice and <val2> is the 
  sides of the dice.  For example dice(2,4) would specify you rolling 2 
  4-sided dice.   The following 'type' values exist.
     0 - default.  Just display the total of both dice.
     1 - Display all the rolls of the dice.
     2 - Display the totals, then display all the roles of the dice.
     3 - Display the totals, then all normal rolls of dice, then display 
         failures/criticals after with the default '|' separator.
     4 - Display all the normal rolls of the dice, then display the
         failures, then the criticals separated by the default '|' character.
     5 - Display just the totals, then failures/criticals after with
         the default '|' separator.

  <botval> specifies low ceiling masks for the dice.  You may specify an 
  optional output separator for the numbers.  If the separator you specify
  is the '|' character, the separator used for failure/criticals becomes ':'.
  
  You may specify offset values to the 'fail'ure or for 'crit'ical success.
  The offset increases the range of failure or success.
   
  Examples:
    > say dice(2,4)        [give me the total of rolling 2 4-sided dice]
      You say "3"
    > say dice(2,4,1)      [give me the total and individual dice rolls]
      You say "3 1 2"
    > say dice(2,4,2)      [give me just the individual dice rolls]
      You say "1 2"
    > say dice(2,4,2,3)    [give me just the dice rolls with MIN value of 3]
      You say "3 3"
    > say dice(2,4,2,,@)   [give me just the dice rolls with a separator '@']
      You say "1@2"
   
  See Also: rand()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SHIFT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SHIFT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: shift(<value>)
            shift()
  
  This function controls the values returned with %0-%9 (or v(0)-v(9)) with
  regards to u() attributes, functions or @functions.  Each increment to
  s...
explanation:
Function: shift(<value>)
            shift()
  
  This function controls the values returned with %0-%9 (or v(0)-v(9)) with
  regards to u() attributes, functions or @functions.  Each increment to
  shift will shift the values 10.  So shift(1) will make %5 actually be
  the 15's argument, not the 5th.  You can shift up to the max arguments
  currently allowed by the mush.  The default is 30 total arguments, thus
  you can shift to the value '3'.
  
  If you do not specify an argument, it shows you what the current shift 
  value is set to.  This value resets itself for each pass through the
  queue (or by user-intervention).

  See Also: v()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TRACE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TRACE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: trace(<value>)
  
  This function controls the TRACE flag on the object executing the function.
  If the value is 0, the TRACE flag is removed. If the value is non-0 then
  the TRACE flag is...
explanation:
Function: trace(<value>)
  
  This function controls the TRACE flag on the object executing the function.
  If the value is 0, the TRACE flag is removed. If the value is non-0 then
  the TRACE flag is set.
  
  This function can be used to selectively turn on trace output for a piece
  of MUSH code. This can help to avoid the often spammy output of trace.
  
  You may specify a TRACE_GREP attribute on yourself (&TRACE_GREP me=<string>)
  if you wish to have a specific piece of code in trace output which matches
  the trace output return in red the match.
   
  Example: (line 2 wrapped)
    > &broken object=[add(3,mul)(3,7))]
    > &test object=$testme *:@emit I am [trace(1)][u(me/broken)][trace(0)][swi
      tch(%0,0,zero,non-zero)].
    > testme 0
   
  In this example you'll see trace output only for the u() of the broken 
  attribute. You will not see trace output for the @emit or the switch().
  However, if the TRACE flag was set on the object prior to execution, then
  you would see trace output for everything up to the trace(0) call.
  
  You may specify a TRACETAB attribute that contains a number between 0-10
  to indent related trace output.
  
  See Also: %_, TRACE, VERBOSE, PUPPET, chktrace()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: MATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for MATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: match(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
 
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the number of the first word that matches.  If no words match then 0 is
 ...
explanation:
Function: match(<string>, <pattern>[, <delim>])
 
  This function matches <pattern> against each word of <string>, returning
  the number of the first word that matches.  If no words match then 0 is
  returned.  The case of the characters being matched is not significant.
 
  The pattern may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' matches any one
  character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none.
  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', but 's*x' would
  match any of them.
  
  <delim> may be used specified to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  Examples:
    > say match(This is a test, test)
    You say "4"
    > say match(This is a test, is)
    You say "2"
    > say match(This is a test, *is*)
    You say "1"
    > say match(This is a test, *not*)
    You say "0"
    > say match(This is a test, is a)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: LISTS, member(), strmatch(), subnetmatch(), nummatch(), totmatch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: strmatch(<string>,<pattern>)
 
  This function matches <pattern> against the entire <string>, returning 1
  if it matches and 0 if it does not.  The case of the characters being
  matched is not significant.
 
  The pattern may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'.  '?' matches any one
  character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none.
  So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', but 's*x' would
  match any of them.
 
  Examples:
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*Test)
    You say "1"
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*This)
    You say "0"
    > say strmatch(This is a test,*is*is*)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: match(), member(), nummatch(), nummember(), totmatch(), totmember()

title: SUBNETMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SUBNETMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>,<netmask>)
            subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>/<CIDR>)
  
  This function allows you to check whether an IP falls into a certain subnet
  or not. The function...
explanation:
Function: subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>,<netmask>)
            subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>/<CIDR>)
  
  This function allows you to check whether an IP falls into a certain subnet
  or not. The function allows you to use either a format specifying the
  subnet address and netmask, or the common CIDR format.
  
  It returns 1 if the IP address is part of the subnet, 0 if it is not.
  
  Examples:
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0, 255.0.0.0) -> 1
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0, 255.255.0.0) -> 0
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0/8) -> 1
    subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0/16) -> 0
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: extract(<string>, <first>, <length>[, <delim>])
 
  Extract returns a string of length words, starting with the first 
  word. Unlike letters, the first word in a string is number 1,

explanation:
Function: extract(<string>, <first>, <length>[, <delim>])
 
  Extract returns a string of length words, starting with the first 
  word. Unlike letters, the first word in a string is number 1, 
  instead of 0.
 
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  Examples:
    > say extract(This is a really neat example, 4, 2)
    You say "really neat"
    > say extract(Another@funky@test@for@extract, 3, 3, @)
    You say "test@for@extract" 
  
  See Also: extractword(), index(), insert(), ldelete(), replace(), 
            randextract()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: EXTRACTWORD() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for EXTRACTWORD() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: extractword(<strng>[,<first>,<len>[,<dlim>],<sep>],<del>],<mod>]]])
  
  Extractword returns a string of <len> length words, starting with the first
  word.  This works effectively like extr...
explanation:
Function: extractword(<strng>[,<first>,<len>[,<dlim>],<sep>],<del>],<mod>]]])
  
  Extractword returns a string of <len> length words, starting with the first
  word.  This works effectively like extract(), however, the delimiter 
  <dlim> and separator <sep> can be multi-character.  In addition, the
  separator may also contain ansi or special characters.
  
  If you specify only <strng> and no other arguments, it returns the first
  word of the string as if the first() function.
  
  If you specify a negative number to <first>, it counts backwards from the end
  of the string.  So -1 is the last argument, -2 is previous to last, and so
  forth.
  
  If you specify a negative number to <len>, it will return up to the total
  words minus the length.  So -1 will return all words from start to the
  last element, -2 to the previous to last element, and so forth.
  
  If you specify the <del> toggle to '1' it assumes delextract() compatibility
  where the words chosen are all the words EXCEPT the range specified.
  
  If you specify the <mod> toggle to '1' it will apply a modulo to the <first>
  argument against the total words in <strng> and wrap-around the value
  automatically.
   
  Unlike extract(), extractword() is also ansi-aware.
  
  The default <delim> is a space.  The default <sep> is whatever <delim>
  is defined as.
  
  Examples:
    > say extractword(This is a really neat example, 4, 2)
    You say "really neat"
    > say extractword(a@@@multi@@@char@@@delimiter, 2, 2, @@@)
    You say "multi@@@char"
    > say extractword(a@@@multi@@@char@@@delimiter, 2, 2, @@@,%b)
    You say "multi char"
    > say extractword(Skip the first and last elements, 2, -2)
    You say "the first and last"
    > say extractword((Get just the last three elements,-3, 3)
    You say "last three elements"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), index(), insert(), ldelete(), replace(),
            randextract()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: INDEX() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for INDEX() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: index(<list>,<character>,<first>,<length>)
  
  This function is similar to EXTRACT(), except that an item in the
  list may be more than one word; instead of a space being used to
  separat...
explanation:
Function: index(<list>,<character>,<first>,<length>)
  
  This function is similar to EXTRACT(), except that an item in the
  list may be more than one word; instead of a space being used to
  separate items in the list, <character> is used. The function returns 
  <length> items starting from that in the <first> position. Trailing
  spaces are trimmed. The comma cannot be used as the <character> separator. 
 
  Example:
    > say [index(Cup of Tea | Mug of Beer | Glass of Wine, |, 2, 1)]
    You say, "Mug of Beer"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), aindex(), iindex(), rindex()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: aiindex(<list>, <string>, <position>, <delimiter>)
  
  This function is similar to index(), except that it inserts the <string>
  at the <position> in the given <list>.  You must specify a delimiter.
  For a space, use a '%b' as a delimiter.  This works exactly like iindex()
  except it allows you to 'add insert' to an empty list.
  
  Example:
    > say aiindex(this is a test,another cat and,3,%b)
    You say "this is another cat and a test"
    > say aiindex(,another test,1,|)
    You say "another test"
    > say aiindex(another test,a test,1,|)
    You say "a test|another test"
  
  See Also: index(), rindex(), aindex()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: art(<string> [,<key>])

title: ATRCACHE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ATRCACHE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
+*  grab         -- do a force recache then fetch value.
+*  recache      -- run a recache of the specified cache based on interval
+*  forcerecache -- force a recache of the specified cache
explanation:
Function: atrcache(<cache slot or name> [,<switch> [,<arg1>, <arg2>,...]])
  
  This function returns the value of the cached data in the specified
  cache slot by slot number or name.  If the interval has exceeded from
  the last cache, this function, depending on permissions, will recache
  the results before fetching it.
  
  Permissions on this function follow the same series of Immortal, 
  visibility, and lock.
  
  If you do not have permission to view the specified cache, an error
  will be displayed.
  
  This function will already read arguments passed from the stack, which you
  can override with specified arguments to the function.
    
  The following <switches> are available:
     fetch        -- (default) will fetch the value of the cash.
 +*  grab         -- do a force recache then fetch value.
 +*  recache      -- run a recache of the specified cache based on interval
  *  interval     -- return the interval that recaches are done
  *  visible      -- return if the cache is visible or not
  *  lock         -- return the hardening cache lock
  *  lastrun      -- return the last time the cache was executed
  *  owner        -- return the current owner of the cache
 +*  forcerecache -- force a recache of the specified cache
  *  exec         -- show the execution stack the cache uses
  
  Any value with a '*' requires owner or Immortal to use the switch.
  Any value with a '+' requires a valid owner on the cache.
  
  Examples: 
    > say atrcache(mynewtest)
    You say "#12345"
    > say atrcache(mynewtest, fetch)
    You say "#12345"
    > say atrcache(mynewtest, fetch, arg-v0, arg-v1, arg-v2)
    You say "#12345 arg-v0 arg-v1 arg-v2"
    > say atrcache(notacache)
    You say "#-1 INVALID CACHE"
  
  See Also: @atrcache, %-h
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ATTRCNT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ATTRCNT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: attrcnt(<object>[/<pattern>] [,<key>])
  
  This returns the total number of attributes that the target object has.
  This gets around some limitations of words(lattr(<object>)) due to the
 ...
explanation:
Function: attrcnt(<object>[/<pattern>] [,<key>])
  
  This returns the total number of attributes that the target object has.
  This gets around some limitations of words(lattr(<object>)) due to the
  parser limitation.  This attribute has the sideeffect of repairing
  attribute corruption on the target.
  
  The following keys exist:
      0 - (default) - list attributes and delete corrupted attributes.
      1 - list attributes and attempt to repair corrupted attributes.
      2 - list attributes but do not touch corrupted attributes.
      3 - remove any IS_LOCK on any attribute that is user-defined.
  
  If there is attribute corruption, the value returned will be '-1'.
  
  You may specify <pattern> as a wildcard pattern or if you start the
  <pattern> with a ^ character it will assume a regex pattern to match.
   
  Examples:
    > say attrcnt(me)
    You say "20"
    > say words(lattr(me))
    You say "20"
    > say attrcnt(me/v*)             (globbing wild pattern)
    You say "5"
    > say attrcnt(me/^v.*$)          (regex pattern)
    You say "5"
    > say words(lattr(me/v*))
    You say "5"
  
  See Also: words(), lattr(), vattrcnt(), cluster_attrcnt()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ATTRPASS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ATTRPASS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: attrpass(<object>/<attribute>, <password>, <type>)
 
  This function will set or check the password of the given attribute
  on the given target.  You must control both the target <object> a...
explanation:
Function: attrpass(<object>/<attribute>, <password>, <type>)
 
  This function will set or check the password of the given attribute
  on the given target.  You must control both the target <object> and
  the destination <attribute> to either set or check the password.
  
  You can not use this function to set or check the default player
  password attribute.  Attempting to do so will fail.  For immortals
  there is a password function utility to do so.  This does not view
  the password, as being hashed this is impossible.  It will only
  allow a comparison of the password to the hashed value for 
  validation. 
  
  A return code for both SET or CHK of '1' means a success.  0 is failure. 
  
  The following <type> are available for this function:
    SET -- this will set the <password>.  You may abbreviate this.
    CHK -- this will check against <password>.  You may abbreviate this.
  
  Note: <password> can not exceed 2048 characters.  DoS/DDoS limitation.
        This may change based on crypto settings.
    
  Examples:
    > say attrpass(me/va, test, set)
    You say "1"
    > say attrpass(me/va, test, chk)
    You say "1"
    > say attrpass(me/va, notest, chk)
    You say "0"
    > say attrpass(me/_wizonly, test, set)
    You say "0"     (a normal player can't chk/set wizard attributes)
  
  See Also: @password, testlock()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: VALID() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for VALID() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: valid(<option>, <string>)
  
  This function returns 1 if <string> is valid for <option>, and 0
  if it is not.
  
  The following options are available for the valid function:
     name    ...
explanation:
Function: valid(<option>, <string>)
  
  This function returns 1 if <string> is valid for <option>, and 0
  if it is not.
  
  The following options are available for the valid function:
     name       - returns '1' if the string is a valid object name
     attrname   - returns '1' if the string is a valid attribute name
     playername - returns '1' if the string is a valid player name.  This 
                  also checks if the player already exists.
     password   - returns '1' if the string is a valid password.
     command    - returns '1' if string is a valid command (or alias).
     function   - returns '1' if string is a valid function.
     ufunction  - returns '1' if string is valid @function/@lfunction.
     flag       - returns '1' if string is a valid flag.
     toggle     - returns '1' if string is a valid toggle.
     totem      - returns '1' if string is a valid totem.
     qreg       - returns '1' if string is valid qreg label.
     colorname  - returns '1' if string is a valid +name for ansi.
     ansicodes  - always returns '1'.  Meant for Penn compatibility.
     timezone   - returns '1' if string is a valid timezone.
     locktype   - returns '1' if string is a valid lock switch/type.
     lockkey    - returns '1' if string is a valid string for locking.
     tag        - returns '1' if string is a valid tag (must start with a #)
  
  If a valid option is not specified, this function returns #-1.
  
  Examples:
    > say valid(name, Fred)
    You say "1"
    > say valid(name, )
    You say "0"
    > say valid(playername,me)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: isobjid(), isdbref(), istag(), name()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: VATTRCNT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for VATTRCNT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: vattrcnt(<object> [,<type>])
  This function counts just the user-defined attributes that exist on
  an object.  User defined attributes are attributes that are set
  with the &attr object=s...
explanation:
Function: vattrcnt(<object> [,<type>])
  This function counts just the user-defined attributes that exist on
  an object.  User defined attributes are attributes that are set
  with the &attr object=string or @set object=attr:string commands and
  have no @<attribute> ability. (like @va, @desc, etc)
  
  If the <type> is specified to 1, it will reset the vattr count on
  the attribute.  This should never become out of sync with the true
  count on the object.  If there is a discrepancy, it usually points
  to larger problems that should be brought to the attention of the
  developers.  This could be caused from improper database writes
  to disk, quota/disk limitations, or possible db corruption.
  
  Examples:
    > say vattrcnt(me)
    You say "14"
    > say attrcnt(me)
    You say "20"
    > say words(lattr(me))
    You say "20"
  
  See Also: words(), lattr(), attrcnt()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TODEC() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TODEC() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: todec(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into decimal.  The following formats
  are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16)...
explanation:
Function: todec(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into decimal.  The following formats
  are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 
        0<number>   - used to specify an octal number.      (base 8)
        0b<number>  - used to specify a binary number.      (base 2)
        <number>    - used to specify standard decimal.     (base 10)
  
  Examples:
    > say todec(011)
    You say "9"
    > say todec(0b11)
    You say "3"
    > say todec(0x11)
    You say "17"
 
  See Also: tohex(), tooct(), tobin()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TOHEX() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TOHEX() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: tohex(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into hexidecimal.  The following 
  formats are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (bas...
explanation:
Function: tohex(<number>)
  
  Todec converts the inputted number into hexidecimal.  The following 
  formats are used to send to it:
 
        0x<number>  - used to specify a hexidecimal number. (base 16) 
        0<number>   - used to specify an octal number.      (base 8)
        0b<number>  - used to specify a binary number.      (base 2)
        <number>    - used to specify standard decimal.     (base 10)
  
  Examples:
    > say tohex(017)
    You say "F"
    > say tohex(0b11)
    You say "3"
    > say tohex(-1)
    You say "FFFFFFFF"
 
  See Also: todec(), tooct(), tobin()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: lflags(<object>[/<attribute>])
  
  Lflags works just like flags, but instead of returning the character
  representation will return the string representation.  You may also
  get the flags of the specified attribute.  You may wildcard the 
  attribute and lflags() will return the flags of the first attribute
  matched.
  
  Examples:
    > say lflags(me)
    You say "PLAYER CONNECTED"
    > say flags(me)
    You say "Pc"
    > say lflags(me/desc)
    You say "NOPROG"
    > say flags(me/desc)
    You say "p"
  
  See Also: @set, @toggle, @totem, flags(), hasflag(), ltoggles(), ltotems()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: totemset(<target>, <TOTEM1 TOTEM2 ... TOTEMN !TOTEM1 ... !TOTEMN>)
  
  This is a side-effect function that will set or unset totems on a target.
  The totem must be a valid totem and the target must be valid and
  controllable by the enactor.
  
  This requires the SIDEFX flag.  If you do not have access to the @totem
  command you may not use this side-effect.  If this side-effect has been
  disabled you will be unable to use this side-effect.
  
  Example:
    > say totemset(me,toteminit)
    Set.
  
  See Also: @totem, set(), toggle(), SIDEFX
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TOTEMS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TOTEMS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @totem
explanation:
Function: totems(<object>)
  
  Totems returns a string consisting of the totem letters attached
  to the object.  The string is, however, just one word.  All letters
  in the 'second' tier of letters will be surrounded by []'s.  All 
  letters in the 'third' tier of letters will be surrounded by {}'s.
  
  All default letters (?) defined to toggles will be skipped.  This
  is intentional.
  
  Examples:
    > @list totems
      Totems : FOO(f) BAR([b]) BAZ(z)
    > say ltotems(me)
      You say "FOO BAR BAZ"
    > say totems(me)
      You say "fz[b]"
  
  See Also: ltotems(), flags(), toggles(), lflags(), ltoggles(),
            @totem
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: flags(<object>[/<attribute>])
 
  Flags returns a string consisting of the flags attached to the 
  object. The string is, however, just one word.  Note that @switch
  is case-INsensitive.  i.e. p=P as far as it is concerned.  I wish
  that P=NP....
  
  You may also do wildcard flags() matches on attributes.  It will
  only return the first match it finds.  To see what the flag 
  letters are for the attribute flags, see 'help ATTRIBUTE FLAGS'.
  
  Example:
    > say flags(me)
    You say "Pc"
    > say flags(me/desc)
    You say "p"
    > say flags(me/asdfadsfasdfaf)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: lflags(), hasflag(), ltoggles(), ltotems(), totems()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: rnum(<target>,<object>)
  
  Returns the dbref number of the object, from target's perspective.
  You must control <target> to successfully get the object's number.
  
  Example:
    > say room(me)
    You say "#5"
    > say room(#122) (if #122 is an object that you owned)
    You say "#123"
    > say room(#124) (if #124 is an object that you owned)
    You say "#123"
    > say name(#122)
    You say "thingy"
    > say num(thingy)
    You say "#-1" 
    > say rnum(thingy,#124)
    You say "#122"
  
  See Also: locate(), num(), objid()

title: OBJID() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for OBJID() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: objid(<object>)
  
  Returns the object id of the object.  This essentially is the dbref#
  combined with the created time stamp (in julian seconds) that the object
  was created to allow a ...
explanation:
Function: objid(<object>)
  
  Returns the object id of the object.  This essentially is the dbref#
  combined with the created time stamp (in julian seconds) that the object
  was created to allow a fully unique identifier.
  
  This basically returns in the form <dbref>:<secs>.  
  
  If timestamps are not enabled on the mush, the object was created prior
  to timestamps being enabled, or the object is toggled to ignore timestamps,
  then this function will just return the dbref#.
  
  Example:
    > say objid(me)
    You say "#123:2848482828"
  
  See Also: num(), rnum(), locate()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: LOC() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LOC() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: loc(<object>)
 
  Returns the number of the location where <object> is.  You must either
  control the object or be nearby for it to work.  You can also use loc() 
  to find the location of ...
explanation:
Function: loc(<object>)
 
  Returns the number of the location where <object> is.  You must either
  control the object or be nearby for it to work.  You can also use loc() 
  to find the location of players that are not set UNFINDABLE (or DARK).
  
  When used on an exit it returns the *destination* of the exit, not the
  location. Use the home() function on exits to find their location.
  
  Example:
    > look
    Mortal's Room(#367R)
    A bare room with nothing in it but a bed and a chair.
    Contents:
    hat(#368)
    > say loc(me)
    You say "#367"
    > enter hat
    hat(#368)
    Contents:
    cat(#325)
    > say loc(me)
    You say "#368"
    > say loc(here)
    You say "#367"
  
  See Also: rloc(), room(), where(), home(), EXITS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: RLOC() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for RLOC() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: rloc(<object>,<levels>,[<type>])
 
  This function may be used to get the location of an object's location
  (for which you would previously use 'loc(loc(<object>))', which fails if you
  do...
explanation:
Function: rloc(<object>,<levels>,[<type>])
 
  This function may be used to get the location of an object's location
  (for which you would previously use 'loc(loc(<object>))', which fails if you
  don't control <object>'s location).  <levels> indicates the number of
  nested 'loc' calls to make, so 'loc(loc(<object>))' could be replaced with
  'rloc(<object>,2)'.  If rloc() encounters a room, the dbref of the room
  is returned.
 
  You must either control the object or be nearby for it to work.  When used
  on an exit it returns the destination of the exit.  You can also use rloc()
  to find the location of players that are not set UNFINDABLE.
 
  rloc(<object>,0) is the same as num(<object>), and rloc(<object>,1) is the
  same as loc(<object>).
  
  When used on an exit, it will return the exits dbref#.  Exits do not have
  a nested location so it returns itself.  If you want the exit's location 
  use the home() function. If you want the exit's destination use the loc()
  function.

  Optionally, you can supply a <type> argument. This can be either "OBJECT",
  "THING", or "PLAYER". OBJECT is an alias for THING in this case.
  If supplied, once rloc encounters such an object type as the location on the
  way 'down' it will immediately stop and return that #dbref instead - handy
  for exotic cases like trying to find players sitting inside objects inside
  other players - you could use rloc(<target>,5,PLAYER) and it would return
  the player #DBREF if <target> was in some way nexted inside a player object.
   
  Example:
    > look
    Object(#123p)
    You are inside your object
    > @fo #123=look
    Object> Room(#124R)
    Object> You are inside a room.
    > say loc(me)
    You say "#123"
    > say rloc(me,1)
    You say "#123"
    > say rloc(me,2)
    You say "#124"
  
  See Also: loc(), where(), home()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ERROR() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ERROR() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: error([<target>])
  
  This function takes either no arguments or an optional target player.  
  It returns one of the random error messages in a standard format.  
  If you, or the target s...
explanation:
Function: error([<target>])
  
  This function takes either no arguments or an optional target player.  
  It returns one of the random error messages in a standard format.  
  If you, or the target specified, have the toggle 'VANILLA_ERRORS' 
  enabled, you will only get the default error message.
  
  If a target is specified, you must control the target player, or
  the target player must exist.  If neither of these conditions are
  met, it defaults back to the enactor (or you) for how the error
  processes.
  
  Example:
    > say error()
    You say "Huh?  (Type 'help' for help.)"
    > say error(*tinyplayer)
    You say "Huh?  (Type 'help' for help.)"
    
  See Also: @toggle
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: WHERE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for WHERE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: where(<object>)
 
  This function returns the "true" location of an object. You must control
  the object or be near it in order for it to work. For players and things,
  the "true" location...
explanation:
Function: where(<object>)
 
  This function returns the "true" location of an object. You must control
  the object or be near it in order for it to work. For players and things,
  the "true" location is the normal location of the object. For exits, the
  "true" location is the source room. For rooms, it is #-1.
  
  Example:
    > say where(me)
    You say "#123"
    > say loc(me)
    You say "#123"
   
  See Also: loc(), rloc(), @whereis, @whereall
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: owner(<object>)
            owner(<object>/<attrib>)
 
  The first form of the owner() function returns the dbref of the owner of the
  object.  The object must either be yours or nearby.
 
  The second form returns the owner of an attribute on the named object.
  You must own either the object or the attribute.
  
  Example:
    > say owner(me)
    You say "#123"
    > say num(me)
    You say "#123" 
  
  See Also: @chown
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CNAME() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CNAME() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
cname(<dbref> [,<key>])
   
  This function returns the name of the indicated object with any special
  colorization or accents that they may have.  When called with an exit 
  it returns the only the...
explanation:
cname(<dbref> [,<key>])
   
  This function returns the name of the indicated object with any special
  colorization or accents that they may have.  When called with an exit 
  it returns the only the first alias.
  
  If <key> is specified it forces an ansi-normal (%cn/%xn) at the end
  of the string.  This will fix potential issues of monikers/ansinames
  that were not properly ansi terminated.  This can be prevelant with
  converted databases such as from MUX.  Please note that even if the
  string has an ansi-normal it will append a second one after it.
   
  This will colorize/accent the name using @ansiname or @extansi.
  
  Example:
    > say cname(me)
    You say "TinyPlayer"  (this would be colorized and/or accented)
    > say cname(me,1)
    You say "TinyPlayer"  (this enforces an ansinormal)
   
  See Also: fullname(), @alias, @name, name(), @ansiname, @extansi, %k
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: NAME() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for NAME() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @name hold true of this side-effect.
explanation:
name(<dbref>[,<newname> [,<key>]])
   
  This function returns the name of the indicated object.  When called with
  an exit it returns the only the first alias.
  
  If side-effects are enabled, and if this side-effect is enabled, and if
  the target is set SIDEFX, you may use the second option of this to set
  the target dbref with the new name.  All permissions and limitations to
  @name hold true of this side-effect.
  
  If <key> is specified as '1', then name() will behave like @name/ansi and
  combine @extansi and @name effectively colorzing the target name.
  
  If <key> is specified as '1' and <newname> is left blank, it will clear
  the ansi of the target but leave the name alone.
    
  Example:
    > say name(me)
    You say "TinyPlayer"
   
  See Also: fullname(), @alias, @name, cname()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: fullname(<dbref>)
  
  This function returns the full name of the indicated object.  This is the
  same as name() in all cases except when <dbref> is an exit, then all the
  aliases are returned as well.
  
  Example:
    > look
    A Room(#12345R)
    You see a room.
    Obvious exits:
    An Exit <AE>
    > say exit(here)
    You say "#123"
    > say name(#123)
    You say "An Exit <AE>"
    > say fullname(#123)
    You say "An Exit <AE>;ae;an exit;exit"
  
  See Also: name(), @alias, @name, cname()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

next(<thing>)

  object, then next will return the next object in ...
explanation:
next(<thing>)
 
  If thing is an exit in a room, then next will return the next 
  nondark exit in the list of exits for that room.  If thing is an 
  object, then next will return the next object in the inventory list 
  that the object is in.  Otherwise, it returns a '#-1' string.
    
  Example:
    > inv
    You are carrying:
    Glove(#123)
    Bat(#124)
    You have 200 gold pieces.
    > say con(me) 
    You say "#123"
    > say next(con(me))
    You say "#124"
  
  See Also: con()

explanation:
Function: not(<boolean>)
 
  Takes a boolean value, and returns its inverse.  So, if the input is
  equivalent to true(1) it returns a 0, and if the input is equivalent to
  false(0), it returns a 1.
  
  Example:
    > say not(1)
    You say "0"
    > say not(0)
    You say "1"
   
  See Also: BOOLEAN VALUES, and(), or(), xor(), nand(), nor(), xnor()

description: Help documentation for XGET() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:

  The xget function fetches the specified attribute from the named object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
  attribu...
explanation:
Function: xget(<object>,<attribute>)
   
  The xget function fetches the specified attribute from the named object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
  attributes of objects near you, and public and visual attributes other
  than the description of players wherever they may be.  If the attribute is
  not present on <object>, its parent is searched for the attribute.
   
  Example:
    > read me
    > say xget(me,desc)
    You say "My Desc"
  
  See Also: get_eval(), u(), get()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: xnor(<boolean1>,<boolean2>[,<booleanN>]...)
  
  Takes two or more booleans, and returns true(1) if both values are
  true(1) or false(0) and returns false(0) if any one value is
  false(0) but the other(s) are true(1).

explanation:
Function: gt(<integer1>,<integer2>)
 
  Takes two integers, and returns 1 if and only if <integer1> is greater than
  <integer2>, and 0 otherwise.  Warning: passing anything but integers will
  produce unexpected results, as non-numeric strings usually are treated
  as numeric 0.
 
  Example:
    > say gt(4,5)
    You say "0"
    > say gt(5,5)
    You say "0"
    > say gt(6,5)
    You say "1"
    > say gt(foo, bar)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: lt(), lte(), gte(), eq(), neq()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: lt(<integer1>, <integer2> [,<integer3>,...])
   
  Takes two (or more) integers, and returns 1 if and only if <integer1> is 
  less than <integer2> (which is less than <integer3> and so forth), and 0 
  otherwise.  This function handles floating point numbers as well.
  
  Warning: passing anything but integers will produce unexpected results, 
  as non-numeric strings usually are treated as numeric 0.  
   
  Example:
    > say lt(4,5)
    You say "1"
    > say lt(5,5)
    You say "0"
    > say lt(6,5)
    You say "0"
    > say lt(foo, bar)
    You say "0"
   > say lt(1,2,3,4,5)
    You say "1"
   > say lt(1,2,3,4,5,3)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: lte(), gte(), gt(), eq(), neq()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: eq(<integer1>, <integer2> [,<integer3>,...])
 
  Takes two (or more) integers, and returns 1 if all the values
  are equal, otherwise it returns a 0.  This function handles floating 
  point numbers as well.
  
  Warning: passing anything but integers will produce unexpected results,
  as non-numeric strings usually are treated as numeric 0.
   
  Example:
    > say eq(1,-1)
    You say "0"
    > say eq(5,5)
    You say "1"
    > say eq(foo, bar)
    You say "1"
    > say eq(5,5,5,5,5,5)
    You say "1"
    > say eq(5,5,5,3,5,5)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: lt(), lte(), gte(), gt(), neq()

explanation:
Function: neq(<integer1>, <integer2> [,<integer3>,...])
   
  Takes two (or more) integers, and returns 1 if one of the integers
  are different or '0' if they are all the same.  This function handles 
  floating point numbers as well.
  
  Warning: passing anything but integers will produce unexpected
  results, as non-numeric strings usually are treated as numeric 0.
   
  Examples:
    > say neq(1,-1)
    You say "1"
    > say neq(5,5)
    You say "0"
    > say neq(foo, bar)
    You say "0"
    > say neq(5,5,5,5,5,5)
    You say "0"
    > say neq(5,5,5,3,5,5)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: lt(), lte(), gte(), gt(), eq(), not()

title: TOTMEMBER() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TOTMEMBER() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: member(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
  
  Totmember takes a list and a word, and returns the position of every
  matching word in that list.  If the word does not occur in the list, 
  it will ...
explanation:
Function: member(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
  
  Totmember takes a list and a word, and returns the position of every
  matching word in that list.  If the word does not occur in the list, 
  it will return 0.  Unlike totmatch(), totmember() does not check for
  wildcarding.  It only takes a single non-space delimited word as
  the argument for word.  totmember() is case sensitive.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  Example:
    > say totmember(This is a totmember test this is, this)
    You say "6"
    > say totmember(this is a totmember test this is, this)
    You say "1 6"
    > say totmember(This is another test, *e*)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: TOTMATCH(), MATCH(), MEMBER(), NUMMATCH(), NUMMEMBER()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: member() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for member() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: member(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
 
  Member takes a list and a word, and returns the position of that word
  within the list.  If the word does not occur in the list, then 0 is
  returned. ...
explanation:
Function: member(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
 
  Member takes a list and a word, and returns the position of that word
  within the list.  If the word does not occur in the list, then 0 is
  returned.  Unlike match(), member() does not check for wildcarding,
  and the cases of <list> and <word> are significant.  A word is defined as
  a string which has no interior spaces.  So 'hello' would be one word,
  while 'hello there' would be two.  Member, unlike match, is case 
  sensitive.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
 
  Example:
    > say member(This is a member test, member)
    You say "4"
    > say member(This is a member test, Member)
    You say "0"
    > say member(This is a member test, *e*)   
    You say "0"
    > say member(This is a member test, is a)
    You say "#-1 CAN ONLY TEST ONE ELEMENT"
   
  See Also: LISTS, match(), strmatch(), subnetmatch(), nummember(), totmember()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: nummember(<list>, <word>[, <delim>])
  
  Nummember takes a list and a word and returns the total number of matches
  that word has in the list.  Unlike nummatch(), this function does not 
  check for wildcarding and the cases are significant.  A word is defined
  as a non-space separate string like 'hello' would be a word, but
  'hello world' would be considered two.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  Example:
    > say nummember(This is a test test test repeat a test, test)
    You say "4"
    > say nummember(This is another test, fred)
    You say "0"
    > say nummember(This is a test, *e*)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: nummatch(), totmatch(), totmember(), match(), member()
