title: WHILE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for WHILE() command/function in RhostMUSH
explanation:
while([<uobj>/]<uattr>,[<cobj>/]<cattr>,<list>,<str>[,<delim>[,<output d>]])
  
  This function evaluates the elements of <list>, until a termination
  condition is reached or the end of the list is reached.
  
  [<uobj>/]<uattr> is an attribute or object/attribute pair, like the first
  argument of map(). The <list> is passed to that function element-by-element
  (based on the input <delim> delimiter) as %0, just as if map() were being
  called, and the output is returned <output d>-delimited, again just as if
  map() were being called.
  
  However, for each element, after that evaluation is done, a second
  evaluation is done, to check a "termination value". [<cobj>/]<cattr>
  is an attribute or object/attribute pair, again like map(), and the
  same list elements are passed to that function as %0. However, the
  result of this evaluation is not kept; instead, it is compared to
  <str>, and if it matches exactly (case-sensitive, no wildcards),
  the no further elements of the list are processed.
  
{ Continued in 'help while2'. }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: WHILE2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for WHILE2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
while([<uobj>/]<uattr>,[<cobj>/]<cattr>,<list>,<str>[,<delim>[,<output d>]])
  
                              (CONTINUED)
  
  If the contents of [<uobj>/]<uattr> and [<cobj>/]<cattr> are the
  same, ...
explanation:
while([<uobj>/]<uattr>,[<cobj>/]<cattr>,<list>,<str>[,<delim>[,<output d>]])
  
                              (CONTINUED)
  
  If the contents of [<uobj>/]<uattr> and [<cobj>/]<cattr> are the
  same, the element is not evaluated twice; the result of the first
  evaluation is directly compared against <str>. (Note that the
  two object/attributes don't have to be the same -- just their
  contents need to be the same, since this function treats the
  pair like map(), not like u().)
  
  Examples:
    > &EVAL_FN me = [reverse(%0)]
    > &COND_FN me = [strlen(%0)]
    > say [while(EVAL_FN,COND_FN,foo bar meep flibble baz,4)]
    You say "oof rab peem"
    > SAY [while(EVAL_FN,COND_FN,foo|bar|meep|flibble|baz,4,|,-)]
    You say "oof-rab-peem"
  
  This function provided for TinyMUSH 3.0 compatibility.
  
  See Also: map(), step(), foreach(), iter(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

  The str function works very similar to after() and very much like the
  C function strstr.  This takes the string starting at the first match
  and returns that string to the end of that string.  This function runs
  faster than the after() function.
  
  Examples:
    > say str(This is a test,his)
    You say "his is a test"
  
  See Also: nostr(), before(), after()

title: OBJEVAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for OBJEVAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: objeval(<thing>,<function> [,<override>, [<enforce>]])
  
  The objeval function evaluates the target function according to the 
  permissions of the thing that is specified.  
  
  If you d...
explanation:
Function: objeval(<thing>,<function> [,<override>, [<enforce>]])
  
  The objeval function evaluates the target function according to the 
  permissions of the thing that is specified.  
  
  If you do not have permission over the <thing> then it will default back 
  to your own permissions instead.  This is done passively and silently.
  
  The above behavior can be enforced to error out if you specify the 
  <enforce> value to 1, in which case if you do not have permission
  over <thing> it will return an error.
   
  This function is useful when you need to parse arguments under a 
  different permission level than the one you currently at.
  
  The following permission overrides <override> are allowed as a bitmask:
    1 - Wizard only, will override the NO_CODE flag on the target and still 
        execute any code of that person.  This is ignored for any enactor 
        not a wizard.
    2 - Guildmaster and higher only.  Will enforce player, cause, and caller
        as the <thing> as a 'true' sudo to that target for the <function>.
   
  Examples:
    > (Let's assume #4523 is an object owned by a normal player)
    > say objeval(#4523,lwho())
    You say "#5 #6 #8" (assuming those are the dbrief#'s of connected players)
  
  This evaluates the lwho() function at citizen level even if you are
  a wizard.
  
  See Also: u(), u2(), get_eval(), objeval(), ueval(), streval(), sandbox()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ZFUNEVAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ZFUNEVAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: zfuneval([<zone>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The zfuneval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object 
  performing the function or from another zone you control, passin...
explanation:
Function: zfuneval([<zone>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The zfuneval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object 
  performing the function or from another zone you control, passing in 
  arguments and returning the result.  In this way it works just like 'zfun()',
  except you pass in a permission to specify what permission level you wish to
  use for evaluation.  It assumes the enactor (owner) of the function always 
  succeeds.  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original 
  enactor and not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that 
  supplied the attribute.  For more detail on functionality, look at ZFUN().
 
  The available permission levels are CIT[IZEN], GUILD[MASTER], ARCH[ITECT],
  COUN[CILOR], ROY[ALTY], IMM[ORTAL], SUB[EVAL].  You must have the permissions
  of the given level in order to use it else it defaults to your permission 
  level.  The permission must be included for the function to work.
  
  The special permission SUB[EVAL] will work like subeval() in that it will
  only evaluate substitutions on the target and not evaluate functions.
  
  Examples:
    > @set me=royalty (let's assume you're a wizard)
    > @va #2=[num(*Miriar)] (the ghod player - #1) (#2 a zone you control)
    > say zfuneval(va/royalty)
    You say "#1"
    > say zfuneval(va/citizen)
    You say "#-1"
  
  See Also: zfun(), zfun2(), objeval(), zfunlocal(), zfun2local(), sandbox(),
            subeval()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: ueval([<obj>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The ueval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing
  the function or from another object you own, passing in arguments and
  returning the result.  In this way it works just like 'u()', except you 
  pass in a permission to specify what permission level you wish to use for
  evaluation.  It assumes the enactor (owner) of the function always succeeds.
  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and
  not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that supplied the
  attribute.  For more detail on functionality, look at U().
 
  The available permission levels are CIT[IZEN], GUILD[MASTER], ARCH[ITECT],
  COUN[CILOR], ROY[ALTY], IMM[ORTAL], SUB[EVAL].  You must have the permissions 
  of the given level in order to use it or it defaults to your permission level.
  The permission must be included for the function to work.
  
  The special permission SUB[EVAL] will work like subeval() in that it will
  only evaluate substitutions on the target and not evaluate functions.
  
  Examples:
    > @set me=royalty (let's assume you're a wizard)
    > @va me=[num(*Miriar)] (the ghod player - #1)
    > say ueval(va/royalty)
    You say "#1"
    > say ueval(va/citizen)
    You say "#-1"
  
  See Also: u(), u2(), objeval(), ulocal(), u2local(), streval(), subeval(),
            sandbox()

code:
Function: u([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The u function evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the
  function or from another object you own, passing in arguments and returning

explanation:
Function: u([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The u function evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the
  function or from another object you own, passing in arguments and returning
  the result.
  
  When evaluating the fetched attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and
  not the 'calling' object, and 'me' refers to the object that supplied the
  attribute.
  
  See '@list options' to see if this functionality switched with u2()'.
  This will be switched if 'u() TinyMUSH compatibility' is enabled.
   
  Examples:
    > @va me=Word is [extract(v(vb),add(%0,1),1)], arg2 is %1.
    > @vb me=This is a test of the u function.
    > say u(va,4,Testing 123)
    You say "Word is of, arg2 is Testing 123."
    > say u(va,7)
    You say "Word is function., arg2 is ."
    > say u(me/va,6,Foobar)
    You say "Word is u, arg2 is Foobar."
  
  See Also: s(), v(), get(), get_eval(), map(), ueval(), streval(),
            objeval(), @lfunction, sandbox(), subeval()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: STREVAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for STREVAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @lfunction
explanation:
Function: streval(<string>, <evaluation level> [,<arg>,<arg2>,...,<argN>])
  
  This function works similar to u() or eval() where it takes the <string>
  then evaluates it according to the permission of <evaluation level>.  You
  must be equal to or less than the bitlevel specified or it assumes your
  own level.  By default, none of the arguments passed will be evaluated.
  
  Evaluation Levels allowed:
      CIT[IZEN]     -- Mortal (bit level 1)
      GUILD[MASTER] -- Staff (bit level 2)
      ARCH[ITECT]   -- Staff (bit level 3)
      COUN[CILOR]   -- Staff (bit level 4)
      ROY[ALTY]     -- Staff (bit level 5) -- This is a full Wizard
      IMM[ORTAL]    -- Staff (bit level 6) -- This is essentially #1
      GOD           -- Staff (bit level 7) -- Can only be ran as #1
  
  Examples: (assuming your a full wizard (royalty))
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],immortal)
    You say "5"                  (immortal is above your lvl, so ignores)
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],councilor)
    You say "4"
    > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)] -- Arg %0,citizen,foo!)]
    You say "1 -- Arg foo!"
    > say streval(NoEval: %0 ... Eval: [s(%0)],citizen,[add(1,1)])
    You say "Noeval: [add(1,1)] ... Eval: 2"
    > say streval(Test: [s(%0)],citizen,[bittype(me)])
    You say "Test: 1"
  
  See Also: ueval(), u(), default(), subeval(), sandbox(), objeval(), 
            @lfunction
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: U2() - RhostMUSH Help

code:
Function: u2([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
  
  This is nearly exactly like the original u() function except it parses
  in an object-dependant way like the old mushes.  It works by evaluating
  the func...
explanation:
Function: u2([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
  
  This is nearly exactly like the original u() function except it parses
  in an object-dependant way like the old mushes.  It works by evaluating
  the function(s) by the power of the owner of the item it's on, and not
  by the power of the enactor.  
  
  This command is also very handy to keep security.
  
  See '@list options' to see if this functionality switched with u2()'.
  This will be switched if 'u() TinyMUSH compatibility' is enabled.
   
  For examples or more information, look at u()
  
  See Also: u(), u2local(), u2ldefault(), @lfunction
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ZFUN2LOCAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ZFUN2LOCAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function:  zfun2local([<zone>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The zfun2local() function is almost identical to zfun2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function...
explanation:
Function:  zfun2local([<zone>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The zfun2local() function is almost identical to zfun2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
 
  However, unlike the zfun2() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the zfun2() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
 
  This makes zfun2local() particularly useful for global or shared code which

explanation:
Example of zfun2local():
    > @zone #2=#0
    > &FRUIT #2=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION #2=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION #2=[setq(0,are delicious!)][zfun2local(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say zfun2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas are delicious!"
 
  If SUB-FUNCTION had been called with zfun2() instead of zfun2local():
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are delicious!)][zfun2(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say zfun2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas apples bananas oranges pears"
 
  In this second example, in SUB-FUNCTION, %q0 was set to "apples bananas
  oranges pears", so that when the zfun2() "returned" and TOP-FUNCTION 
  evaluated %q0, this is what was printed. In the first example, zfun2local() 
  reset the value of %q0 to its original "are delicious!"
 
  See Also:  ulocal(), u(), u2(), uldefault(), u2ldefault(), setq(), r()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: U2LOCAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for U2LOCAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function:  u2local([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The u2local() function is almost identical to u2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or ano...
explanation:
Function:  u2local([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The u2local() function is almost identical to u2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
 
  However, unlike the u2() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the u2() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
 
  This makes u2local() particularly useful for global or shared code which
  calls arbitrary u2() functions, where global register values need to be
  preserved from accidental user clobbering.
 
{ See "help u2local2" for examples. }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PRIVATIZE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PRIVATIZE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: privatize(<boolean>)
            privatize(<boolean> [,<str>, [,<regs>, [<key>]] [,<multi>]])
  
  This function has two uses.  
  
  First, if you just pass a boolean (1) value to the funct...
explanation:
Function: privatize(<boolean>)
            privatize(<boolean> [,<str>, [,<regs>, [<key>]] [,<multi>]])
  
  This function has two uses.  
  
  First, if you just pass a boolean (1) value to the function, it will 
  optionally privatize everything that is localized.  It does this by 
  initializing to null every register that is referenced within the localized
  register.  A boolean of '0' turns off privatization.
  
  The second option allows you to pass a <str> to be evaluated which will
  combine localize() and privatize() for the duration of the evaluation
  of the <str>.  
  
  The register list can be 0-9 or a-z.  You can not use labels.  These will
  be, by default, what registers will be privatized/localized.  
  
  The <key> if '1' will reverse the effect of <regs> and effective
  turn the list to an omission list.
  
  Once privatization is finished, functionality returns as normally expected. 
  
  The <boolean> allowed are:
    1 - Toggle on the feature to initialize to null all registers (%q0-z)
        that are used in localized functions (localize(), ulocal(), etc)
    0 - Toggle off the feature to initialize to null registers (default).
  
  If you specify <multi> to '1' it assumes the register lists specified will
  be mulitple space-seperated arguments.  This allows extended checks with
  labels and register numbers that are greater than 9 if setq_nums is 
  enabled.
  
  <multi> allows full labels, a-z, 0-9, and 0-MAXARGS.  MAXARGS can be found 
  with nameq().  The default is 36.
   
  { see 'help privatize2' for examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: privatize(<boolean>)
            privatize(<boolean> [,<str>, [,<regs>, [<key>]] [,<multi>]])
  
  For Example 1, we will show the difference between calling the function,
  localizing the function, the privatizing before localizing the function.
  
  Example: (option 1)
    > @va me=(before R0: [r(0)])[setq(0,internal)] --My R0:[r(0)]--
    Set.
    > say [setq(0,external)][r(0)][u(va)][r(0)]
    You say "external--(before R0: external) My R0:internal--internal"
    > say [setq(0,external)][r(0)][localize(u(va))][r(0)]
    You say "external--(before R0: external) My R0:internal--external"
    > say [privatize(1)][setq(0,external)][r(0)][localize(u(va))][r(0)]
    You say "external--(before R0: ) My R0:internal--external"
  
  For Example 2, we show what it's like to essentially privatize a specific
  evaluation which auto-localizes the results.
  
  { see 'help privatize3' for examples on the second option }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

    > say [setr(0,TWO)]:[setr(1,CHEESE)], [privatize(1,u(va),0)], %q0:%q1

    You say "TWO:CHEESE, ONE:, ONE:CHEESE"
    > say [setr(0,TWO)]:[setr(1,CHEESE)], [privatize(1,u(va),0,1)], %q0:%q1
    You say "TWO:CHEESE, ONE:, ONE:CHEESE"
  
  Example: (option 2 with multi argument enabled)
    > @va me=[setr(0,O)]:[r(1)]
    Set.
    > say [setr(0,T)]:[setr(1,C)], [privatize(1,u(va),0 3 4,,1)], %q0:%q1
    You say "T:C, O:C, T:C"
    > say [setr(0,T)]:[setr(1,C)], [privatize(1,u(va),0 1 3 4,,1)], %q0:%q1
    You say "T:C, O:, T:C"
  
  See Also: pushregs(), ulocal(), zfunlocal(), eval(), localize(), setqm(),
            setr(), setrm(), setq(), r(), sandbox(), subeval(), @lfunction

title: SANDBOX() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SANDBOX() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: sandbox(<string>, <function list> [,<key> [,<local> [,<type>]]])
  
  This function sandboxes the evaluated <string> based on the list of
  space separated functions in <function list>.  Any...
explanation:
Function: sandbox(<string>, <function list> [,<key> [,<local> [,<type>]]])
  
  This function sandboxes the evaluated <string> based on the list of
  space separated functions in <function list>.  Any function that matches
  any function in the list will have restricted access.
  
  The following <key> exists:
    0 - Set the function deny (default)
    1 - Set the function ignore and check for local function.
  
  The following <local> key exists:
    0 - Don't check for local functions (@function/@lfunction) (default)
    1 - Check against @functions (in addition to built-in functions)
    2 - Check against @lfunctions (in addition to built-in functions)
    3 - Check against all possible function combinations
  
  The following <type> exists:
    0 - The function list is the list of functions denied. (default)
    1 - The function list is the list of functions allowed.
  
  A <key> of deny will return the #-1 PERMISSION DENIED
  A <key> of ignore will return the #-1 FUNCTION (blah) NOT FOUND
  
  Once you have the <type> defined as '1', it remains that way through
  all iterations of the sandbox()'d evaluation, regardless of how
  often sandbox() may be called recursively from inside it.
  
{ see 'help sandbox2' for examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
(CONTINUED)
  Function: sandbox(<string>, <function list> [,<key> [,<local> [,<type>]]])
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=BOO
    Set.
    > @lfunction boo=me/va
    LOCAL Function boo defined.
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],add)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 BOO"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub)
    You say "Test - 2 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED BOO"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo)
    You say "Test - 2 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED BOO"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo,,3)
    You say "Test - 2 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED #-1 PERMISSION DENIED"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub,,3,1)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo,,1,1)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 #-1 PERMISSION DENIED"
    > say sandbox(Test - [add(1,1)] [sub(1,1)] [boo()],sub boo,,3,1)
    You say "Test - #-1 PERMISSION DENIED 0 BOO"
  
  See Also: pushregs(), ulocal(), zfunlocal(), eval(), privatize(), 
            localize(), subeval(), @lfunction

title: LOCALIZE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LOCALIZE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: localize(<string> [,<register-list>, [<key>], [<multi-word>]])
  
  This function will evaluate <string> while preserving all setq() registers
  outside of the function.  This is handy for c...
explanation:
Function: localize(<string> [,<register-list>, [<key>], [<multi-word>]])
  
  This function will evaluate <string> while preserving all setq() registers
  outside of the function.  This is handy for calling global code or other
  functionality without it effecting your own functions and commands.
  
  You may specify a register list if you want only specific registers to be
  localized.  Otherwise, by default it assumes all registers.
  
  Default accepted register values are:
    0-9       -- Standard Q registers.
    a-z       -- Extended Q registers.
  
  You may toggle the <multi-word> argument to '1' to enable <register-list>
  to be a space/tab delimited list of registers.
  The multi-word accepted register values are:
    0-9       -- Standard Q registers.
    a-z       -- Extended Q registers.
    label     -- 'label' in this case is the name of the register label
    0-MAXREGS -- MAX regs can be found with the nameq() function (default 36)
  
  If the <key> is set to 1, the behavior is reversed and any register that
  you specify will be omitted from localization.  The default is '0'.
   
 { see 'help localize2' for examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: LOCALIZE2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LOCALIZE2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: localize(<string> [,<register-list>, [<key>], [<multi-word>]])
  
  Examples:

    Set.
    > @vb me=[setq(30,internal)]--My R30:[r(30)]--

explanation:
Function: localize(<string> [,<register-list>, [<key>], [<multi-word>]])
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=[setq(0,internal)]--My R0:[r(0)]--
    Set.
    > @vb me=[setq(30,internal)]--My R30:[r(30)]--
    Set.
    > say [setq(0,external)][r(0)][u(va)][r(0)]
    You say "external--My R0:internal--internal"
    > say [setq(0,external)][r(0)][localize(u(va))][r(0)]
    You say "external--My R0:internal--external"
    > say [setq(0,external)][r(0)][localize(u(va),12345)][r(0)]
    You say "external--My R0:internal--internal"
  
  Note: In the last example, we allowed '12345' to be localized, but not '0'.
  
  Example: (with setq_nums enabled)
    > say [setq(30,external)][r(30)][localize(u(vb),1 3 5 30 a b,,1)][r(30)]
    You say "external--My R30:internal--external"
  
  Note: You can interchange the number with the letter.  a=10, b=11, c=12, etc
  
  See Also: pushregs(), ulocal(), zfunlocal(), eval(), privatize(), setqm(),
            setq(), setr(), setrm(), r(), sandbox(), subeval(), @lfunction

Function: localfunc(<function-name>, <args>...)
  
  The localfunc() function is used to call customized functions that are
  server specific and allows a wrapper so that new functions might be added
  without having to modify more than a single file of the source.
  
  Example:
    > localfunc(test,This is a test)
    You say "This was a test. Function: 'test' First Arg: 'This is a test'"
  
  See Also: strfunc(), @lfunction

  Example:
    > say ldiv(20 2 0 0 0 0 2)
    You say "5"
    > say ldiv(20@2@0@0@0@0@2,@)
    You say "5"
  
  See Also: lavg(), lmul(), lsub(), lmax(), lmin(), ladd()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: lastcreate(<target>,<type>)

explanation:
Function: lastcreate(<target>,<type>)
  
  This function will return the dbref# of the last <type> that was created
  by the target.  If the type was not created by the target, it will return
  a '#-1'.  Possible types are:
                r - rooms
                t - things (objects)
                e - exits
                p - players
  
  If an invalid type is given, it will return '#-1'.
  
  Example:
    > say lastcreate(me,t)
    You say "#-1"
    > @create MyObject
    MyObject created as object #1369
    > say lastcreate(me,t)
    You say "#1369"
  
  See Also: @create, @dig, @open, @clone

Function: lxnor(<list of numbers>[,<delim>])
   
  Takes two or more booleans, and returns true(1) if both values are
  true(1) or false(0) and returns false(0) if any one value is
  false(0) but the other(s) are true(1).  You may specify an optional
  delimiter.

    You say "0"

    You say "0"

title: STEP() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for STEP() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: step([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>,<step size>[,<delim>[,<output delim>]])
  
  This function takes elements of <list>, <step size> elements at a time,
  and passes them to the function defined by <...
explanation:
Function: step([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>,<step size>[,<delim>[,<output delim>]])
  
  This function takes elements of <list>, <step size> elements at a time,
  and passes them to the function defined by <attr>, as %0, %1, %2,
  etc. The number of elements in the list does not need to be evenly
  divisible by the step size. If no delimiters are provided, a space is
  used as the delimiter. The step size must be at least 1, and no greater
  than 30. Calling this function with a step size of 1 is equivalent to
  using map().  Anything over argument 9 (%9) can be called with v().  Such
  as v(10), v(20), and so forth.
  
  Example:
    > &print_line me = %r%0 -- %1 -- %2
    Set.
    > say [step(print_line,1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8,3)]
    You say "
    1 -- 2 -- 3
    4 -- 5 -- 6
    7 -- 8 --"
  
  This function provided for compatibility with TinyMUSH 3.0
  
  See Also: while(), map(), munge(), iter(), columns(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Toggle: ZONECMDCHK(k)
  
  This toggle, when set, will enable the target to search for $commands
  from a zone as if it were a parent.  This is only useful on commands
  and players.  This toggle is meaningless on rooms (as rooms are already
  searched).

title: KEEPFLAGS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for KEEPFLAGS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: & - match ALL flags for each dbref#.
explanation:
Function: keepflags(<list>,[&|]<flag(s)>[,<delim>[,<output delim>][,<type>]])
  
  The keepflags function keeps all dbref#'s in the given list that contains
  the flags specified.  You must use one of the operators for flag checks:
     & - match ALL flags for each dbref#.
     | - match ANY of the flags for each dbref#.
  
  This function returns the list of dbref#'s that correctly match up the
  flags you specified.
  
  You may specify a <type> of 1 to return values as objid's.
  
  Examples: (#1 is a wizard, nothing else is)
    > say keepflags(#1 #2 #3 #4,&W)
    You say "#1"
    > say keepflags(#1 #2 #3 #4,&Ws)
    You say ""
    > say keepflags(#1 #2 #3 #4,|Ws)
    You say "#1"
  
  Note: You may specify 'P' for players, 'R', for rooms, and 'E' for exits
        as valid flag checks.
  
  See Also: remflags(), remtype(), keeptype()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: KEEPTYPE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for KEEPTYPE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: keeptype(<string>,<type(s)>[,<delim>[,<output delim>][,<type>]])
 
  The keeptype function KEEPS all types of 'type' from the string 'string'.
  The different types are standard MUSH object ...
explanation:
Function: keeptype(<string>,<type(s)>[,<delim>[,<output delim>][,<type>]])
 
  The keeptype function KEEPS all types of 'type' from the string 'string'.
  The different types are standard MUSH object types:
      PLAYER - specifying robots and players
      THING  - specifying objects
      ROOM   - specifying rooms
      EXIT   - specifying exits
      OTHER  - specifying anything not fitting a MUSH 'type'.
  
  You may specify optional separators and output separators.   You may specify
  more than one type at once.
  
  If you specify <type> as 1, the results are always returned as dbref#'s, 
  otherwise the values are returned as the element in <string>.
  
  If you specify <type> as 2, the results are returned as objid's.
    
  Examples: (#0 is a room, #1 #55 and #584 are players, #-1 is invalid (other))
    > say keeptype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,player)
    You say "#1 #55 #584"
    > say keeptype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,exit)
    You say ""
    > say keeptype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,other)
    You say "#-1"
    > say keeptype(#0@#1@#55@#584@#-1,player,@,|)
    You say "#1|#55|#584"
    > say keeptype(#0 #1 #55 #584 #-1,player other)
    You say "#1 #55 #584 #-1"
  
  See Also: delete(), remove(), ldelete(), replace(), remtype()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SWITCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SWITCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: switch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
   
  The switch function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing *
  to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character)...
explanation:
Function: switch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
   
  The switch function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing *
  to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character), and
  returns the corresponding <resN> parameter for the first <patN> pattern
  that matches.  If none match, then the default result <dflt> is returned.
   
  Example:
    > say switch(c,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "C"
    > say switch(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "E"
    > say switch(cab,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "A"
    > say switch(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D)  
    You say ""
    ----- if penn_switches enabled
    > say switch(3,>=2,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
    ----- if float_switches enabled
    > say switch(2.23,>=2.22,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
  
  If configured, you may use #$ as a substitution.   #$ is substituted with 
  the value of <string>. In this way, the commands in <res11>..<dflt> 
  have a short-hand way of getting at the matched value. 
  
  Note: The following config parameters effect how this functions.
        penn_switches  -- if enabled allows >, <, >=. <= for math.
        float_switches -- if enabled allows floating values as well.
  
  Refer: '@list options boolean *switch*' to check switch options.
  
  See Also: @switch, match(), case(), ifelse(), switchall()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: switchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
   
  The switchall function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing *
  to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character), and
  returns all corresponding <resN> parameters for all <patN> patterns
  that matches.  If none match, then the default result <dflt> is returned.
 
  Example:
    > say switchall(c,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "C"
    > say switchall(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "E"
    > say switchall(cab,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E)
    You say "ABC"
    > say switchall(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D)  
    You say ""
    ----- if penn_switches enabled
    > say switch(3,>=2,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
    ----- if float_switches enabled
    > say switch(2.23,>=2.22,Y,N)
    You say "Y"
  
  If configured, you may use #$ as a substitution.   #$ is substituted with 
  the value of <string>. In this way, the commands in <res11>..<dflt> 
  have a short-hand way of getting at the matched value. 
  
  Note: The following config parameters effect how this functions.
        penn_switches  -- if enabled allows >, <, >=. <= for math.
        float_switches -- if enabled allows floating values as well.
  
  Refer: '@list options boolean *switch*' to check switch options.
  
  See Also: @switch, match(), case(), ifelse(), switch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

code:
Function: reswitch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchi(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<r...
explanation:
Function: reswitch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchi(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  Function: reswitchalli(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>,[<patN>,<resN>],...[,<dflt>]])
  
  This function is just like switch(), except they compare <string> against
  a series of regular expressions, not wildcard patterns.  This function
  is case-sensitive.
  
  Example:
    > say reswitch(xxcxxxxxx,.*a.*,A,.*b.*,B,.*c.*,C,.*d.*,D,E)
    You say "C"
  
  See Also: switch(), reswitchi(), reswitchall(), reswitchalli(), regexps
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

code:
Function: ifelse(<expression>,<true string>[,<false string>])
 
  This function returns <true string> if <expression> is true (not 0), 
  <false string> otherwise. Much more efficient than an equivale...
explanation:
Function: ifelse(<expression>,<true string>[,<false string>])
 
  This function returns <true string> if <expression> is true (not 0), 
  <false string> otherwise. Much more efficient than an equivalent
  switch(). To check if a string contains text or not, use strlen() within
  the test case.  
  
  The false string is optional and if nothing is specified, it will return 
  an empty string if a false match is met.  This will effectively mimic 
  the if() function found on other servers.
  
  This function is aliased to if().
   
  Example:
    > say ifelse(v(test),Test exists!,Test doesn't exist.)
    You say "Test doesn't exist."
    > say ifelse(strlen(v(test)),Test exits!,Test doesn't exist.)
    You say "Test exists!"
    > say ifelse(gt(1,0),This is true!)
    You say "This is true!"
    > say ifelse(gt(0,1),This is true!)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: switch(), case(), @switch
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: hastype() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for hastype() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: hastype(<object>, <type>)
  
  Returns 1 if the object is of the named type, otherwise 0.
  Valid types are: ROOM, EXIT, PLAYER, THING.
  If an invalid type is given, #-1 is returned.

  NOT...
explanation:
Function: hastype(<object>, <type>)
  
  Returns 1 if the object is of the named type, otherwise 0.
  Valid types are: ROOM, EXIT, PLAYER, THING.
  If an invalid type is given, #-1 is returned.

  NOTE: The function will return #-1 for invalid objects as well, unless
  the configuration parameter 'hastype_always_zero' is set to 1.
  
  Examples:
    > say hastype(me,PLAYER)
    You say "1"
    > say hastype(me,THING)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: type(), hasflag()
  See Also: wizhelp hastype_always_zero
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: hasattr() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for hasattr() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: hasattr(<object>/<attribute name> [,<key>])
            hasattr(<object>,<attribute name> [,<key>])
   
  Returns 1 if the object has the named attribute, and 0 if it does
  not. If the obje...
explanation:
Function: hasattr(<object>/<attribute name> [,<key>])
            hasattr(<object>,<attribute name> [,<key>])
   
  Returns 1 if the object has the named attribute, and 0 if it does
  not. If the object does not exist or the player does not have the
  ability to examine the object, #-1 will be returned.
 
  Hasattr() doesn't check for attributes inherited from parent
  objects. Use hasattrp() for that.
  
  If <key> is specified it will also optionally check for lock attributes. 
  
  Examples:
    > say hasattr(me/sex)
    You say "1"
    > say hasattr(me/adsadf)
    You say "0"
    > say hasattr(me,sex)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: hasattrp(), hasflag()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: hasattrp() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for hasattrp() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: hasattrp(<object>/<attribute name> [,<key>])
            hasattrp(<object>,<attribute name> [,<key>])
   
  Returns 1 if any of it's parents has the named attribute,
  and 0 if it does not. ...
explanation:
Function: hasattrp(<object>/<attribute name> [,<key>])
            hasattrp(<object>,<attribute name> [,<key>])
   
  Returns 1 if any of it's parents has the named attribute,
  and 0 if it does not. If the object does not exist or the player
  does not have the ability to examine the object, #-1 will be returned.
 
  Use hasattr() to check for attributes without checking parents.
  If the config option hasattrp_compat is set, it will check the target
  object for the attribute as well.
  
  If <key> is specified it will also optionally check for lock attributes. 
  
  Examples:
    > say hasattrp(me/desc)
    You say "1"
    > say hasattrp(me,desc)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: hasattr(), hasflag()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

code:

  Performs a leftwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times.
  This is equivalent to mul(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster.
  This funct...
explanation:
Function: shl(<number or string>,<count>)
  
  Performs a leftwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times.
  This is equivalent to mul(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster.
  This function also shifts left a given string <count> number
  of characters.
  
  Examples:
    > say shl(1,4)
    You say "16"
    > say shl(weird!!!,3)
    You say "rd!!!"
  
  See Also: shr(), rotl(), rotr()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: shr(<number or string>,<count>)
  
  Performs a rightwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times.
  This is equivalent to div(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster.
  Function: case(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>]).  This function also
  shifts right a given string <count> number of characters.
  
  Examples:
    > say shr(16,3)
    You say "2"
    > say shr(weird!!!,4)
    You say "weir"
  
  See Also: shl(), rotl(), rotr()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

description: Help documentation for caseall() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: caseall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])

  (i.e., using *).  In cases where wildcards are not needed, it performs 
  marg...
explanation:
Function: caseall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
  caseall() is like switchall() but does not do wildcard matching 
  (i.e., using *).  In cases where wildcards are not needed, it performs 
  marginally faster.  This function is also case sensitive.
   
  Example:
    > say caseall(c,a,A,b,B,c,C,d,D,c,X,E)
    You say "CX"
    > say caseall(f,a,A,b,B,c,C,d,D,E)
    You say "E"
  
  See Also: @switch, match(), ifelse(), switch(), switchall()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: case(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>])
  case() is like switch() but does not do wildcard matching (i.e., using *).
  In cases where wildcards are not needed, it performs marginally faster.
  This function is also case sensitive.
   
  Example:
    > say case(c,a,A,b,B,c,C,d,D,E)
    You say "C"
    > say case(f,a,A,b,B,c,C,d,D,E)
    You say "E"
  
  See Also: @switch, match(), ifelse(), switch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SPACE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SPACE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: space(<count>)
 
  Returns the number of indicated spaces.  If <count> is missing, negative,
  or cannot be converted to a number, one space is returned.  This function
  is useful when you ...
explanation:
Function: space(<count>)
 
  Returns the number of indicated spaces.  If <count> is missing, negative,
  or cannot be converted to a number, one space is returned.  This function
  is useful when you want to pass a single space (or more than one) as a
  function to an argument, because normally leading and trailing spaces are
  stripped from function arguments.
 
  Examples:
    > say space(4)
    You say "    "
    > say edit(Foo bar bletch, space(), X)
    You say "FooXbarXbletch"
  
  See Also: repeat(), SUBSTITUTIONS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SPELLNUM() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SPELLNUM() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: spellnum(<number> [,<key>])
  
  This function, when fed a number (decimal or floating point) will return
  the long name of the number (or in other words, the number in words).
  
  A 'key'...
explanation:
Function: spellnum(<number> [,<key>])
  
  This function, when fed a number (decimal or floating point) will return
  the long name of the number (or in other words, the number in words).
  
  A 'key' of 1 specifies the ordinal number instead of the pure numeric.
  Ergo, 'tenth' instead of 'ten' or 'first' instead of 'one'. 
  
  Ordinals do not work with decimal notation and will be ignored.
   
  Examples:
    > say spellnum(10)
    You say "ten"
    > say spellnum(10,1)
    You say "tenth"
    > say spellnum(1)
    You say "one"
    > say spellnum(1,1)
    You say "first"
    > say spellnum(1010)
    You say "one thousand ten"
  
  See Also: strmath()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARENTS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARENTS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: parents(<obj> [,<objid>])
  
  Returns all the parents of <obj>.  Returns #-1 if <obj> cannot be found
  or has no parent or if you do not own and/or control <obj>
  
  If the optional <obji...
explanation:
Function: parents(<obj> [,<objid>])
  
  Returns all the parents of <obj>.  Returns #-1 if <obj> cannot be found
  or has no parent or if you do not own and/or control <obj>
  
  If the optional <objid> is specified as '1', then it returns the objid's 
  instead of the dbref#'s.
  
  By default, if you can not examine any of the parents in the chain, then
  it will not show you the parent of that chain. 
 
  If the @admin parameter 'parent_follow' is enabled, which is the default,
  then if you control the <obj> you will see the entire parent chain,
  regardless of your control or examine permissions of those parents in 
  the chain.  We felt this should be the proper default behavior.
  
  Example:
    > say parents(me)
    You say "#-1"
    > @parent #4=#5
    Parent set.
    > @parent #5=#6
    Parent set.
    > say parents(#4)
    You say "#5 #6"
    > say parents(#4,1)
    You say "#5:8185828582 #6:8281859282"
  
  See Also: parent(), children()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ROMAN() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ROMAN() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: roman(<number>)
  
  This function converts the given number to the Roman Numeral equivalent.
  It will convert any number between 1 and 3999999.  As the normal
  overslash on the higher rom...
explanation:
Function: roman(<number>)
  
  This function converts the given number to the Roman Numeral equivalent.
  It will convert any number between 1 and 3999999.  As the normal
  overslash on the higher roman numerals are not easily supported in a text
  environment, the higher roman numerals will be displayed as lower case.
  The following roman numeral mapping exists:
      I - 1          L - 50           v - 5000        c - 100000
      V - 5          C - 100          x - 10000       m - 1000000
      X - 10         M - 1000         l - 50000
  
  Examples:
    > say roman(1999)
    You say "MCMXCIX"
    > say roman(777777)
    You say "dcclxxvMMDCCLXXVII"
  
  See Also: pack()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PACK() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PACK() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: pack(<number>[[,<radix>][,<penn compat flag>]])
   
  Returns the equivalent of the given number using the specified base.
  The default radix is 64. Bases greater than 10 will be more compa...
explanation:
Function: pack(<number>[[,<radix>][,<penn compat flag>]])
   
  Returns the equivalent of the given number using the specified base.
  The default radix is 64. Bases greater than 10 will be more compact
  than the original number. Bases less than 10 will be more expanded.
   
  The inverse function of pack is unpack. pack and unpack are designed
  to support the base-36 radix conversion used in Myrddin's popular
  Bulletin Board. For this reason, and to support bases: 2, 8, and 16,
  this conversion is not the radix-64 conversion used in unix-to-unix
  copy (uuencode).  The range of the radix is between 2 and 64.
  
  You may specify the PennMUSH compatible toggle (1) which will mimic Penn's
  64 bit packing algo.
   
  Examples:
    >think pack(629126998)
    bVxTM
    >think pack(629126998,16)
    257FB756
    >think pack(629126998,2)
    100101011111111011011101010110
    >think pack(-629126998)
    -bVxTM
   
  See Also: unpack(), crc32(), mask(), tobin(), tohex(), tooct(), todec(), 
            roman(), packmath(), crc32obj(), bucket()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PACKMATH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PACKMATH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
+  - apply addition (default)
&  - bitwise and mask (only works on values less than MAXUINT (4294967296)
explanation:
Function: packmath(<number>, <radix>, <offset> [[,<math> ][,<offset-radix>])
  
  This function applies the specified <math> to <number> by applying
  the value of <offset>.  The value returned will be in the same <radix>
  that you specified.  The <radix> allowed is 2 to 64.  If no <math>
  is specified it assumes '+' (addition).
  
  If your <offset> is not in decimal (base 10), you may specify the optional
  <offset-radix> to specify the radix that the value is in.
   
  The valid values for <math> are:
    +  - apply addition (default)
    -  - apply subtraction
    *  - apply multiplication
    /  - apply division
    %  - apply modulus (use two %'s)
    |  - bitwise or mask (only works on values less than MAXUINT (4294967296)
    &  - bitwise and mask (only works on values less than MAXUINT (4294967296)
  
  Note: & and | bitwise masks will return '0' if the values are over MAXUINT 
  
  Examples:
    > think pack(629126998,64)
    bVxTM
    > think packmath(bVxTM,64,100)
    bVxUw
    > think unpack(bVxUw,64)
    629127098
    > think add(629126998,100)
    629127098
    > think unpack(packmath(pack(629126998,64),64,5555),64)
    629132553
    > think add(629126998,5555)
    629132553
  
  See Also: pack(), unpack(), strmath(), bucket()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: UNESCLIST() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for UNESCLIST() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: unesclist(<list of characters to un-escape>|<string>)
  
  This function takes an optional list of characters you wish to un-escape 
  and then un-escapes them (via removing the \ character ...
explanation:
Function: unesclist(<list of characters to un-escape>|<string>)
  
  This function takes an optional list of characters you wish to un-escape 
  and then un-escapes them (via removing the \ character before it) from 
  every character that you specified.  This is intended to be used with 
  weird escape situations like calling external sources.
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=Test: \'A string\' and \"anoter string\"\, I say.
    Set.
    > say unesclist('",|[v(va)])
    You say "Test: 'A string' and "anoter string", I say."
    > say unesclist('|[v(va)])
    You say "Test: 'A string' and "anoter string", I say."
  
  See Also: escape(), escapex(), esclist()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: unpack(<packed number>[[,<radix>][,<penn compat flag>]])
   
  Returns the equivalent normal base-10 number of the given
  packed-number using the specified base. The default radix is 64.
  The inverse function of unpack is pack.  The radix can be between
  2 and 64.
  
  You may specify tghe PennMUSh compatable toggle (1) which will mimic Penn's
  64 bit packing algo.
   
  Examples:
    >think unpack(bVxTM)
    629126998
    >think unpack(1111,2)
    15
   
  See Also: pack(), crc32(), mask(), tobin(), tohex(), tooct(), todec(),
            packmath(), crc32obj()

title: CRC32() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CRC32() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: crc32(<string1>[, ..., <stringN>])
   
  Returns the Cyclic Redundancy Check of the strings or sequences of
  strings as a positive number. The answer for the same sequence of
  strings is a...
explanation:
Function: crc32(<string1>[, ..., <stringN>])
   
  Returns the Cyclic Redundancy Check of the strings or sequences of
  strings as a positive number. The answer for the same sequence of
  strings is always the same.  You may specify more than one string
  to do a CRC check against.
   
  The usefulness of this number is broad, but could provide a unique
  fingerprint, checksum pattern, or high-quality hash function.
   
  Example:
    > think crc32(MUX)
    629126998
  
  See Also: pack(), unpack(), mask(), tobin(), tohex(), tooct(), todec(),
            digest(), packmath(), crc32obj()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARENSTR() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARENSTR() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: parenstr(<string>)
            parenstr(!<string>)
  
  This function returns an ansified match of parenthesis, brackets, and
  braces while hilighting red any mis-matched of the three.  If ...
explanation:
Function: parenstr(<string>)
            parenstr(!<string>)
  
  This function returns an ansified match of parenthesis, brackets, and
  braces while hilighting red any mis-matched of the three.  If you start
  the string you are comparing with a '!' then only the first mis-match
  will be displayed.  The comparison will always be left to right.  If the
  string is too large, it will always be returned un-altered.  If there are
  a large number of parenthesis, brackets and praces, it is possible the
  result will be cut off as ansi takes up extra spaces.  If this is the case,
  use the '!' option to only hilight the errors (if any), otherwise it will
  return the hilighted string.
  
  Bugs:  
  Do to how pre-processing works for functions, even though the arguments to
  this function are not evaluated, if you do not END in the right number
  of )'s and ]'s it's highly possible that it will evaluate portions of
  the string passed to it ANYWAY thinking that it's outside the bounds
  of the parsestr() function itself.  If you run into such a case, store
  the value you are comparing into an attribute and then use parenmatch()
  to compare the result so it won't assume (wrongly) how to parse it.
  
  Examples:
    > say parenstr([add(1,2))])
    You say "[add(1,2))]"       (the second ')' would be hilighted red)
    > say parenstr(![add(1,2))])
    You say "[add(1,2))]"       (JUST the second ')' would be hilighted red)
  
  See Also: parenmatch(), brackets(), pos(), totpos()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARENMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARENMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: parenmatch([<object>/]<attribute> [,<type>, [<key>], [<flags>]])
  
  This function returns an ansified match of parenthesis, brackets, and braces
  while hilighting red any mis-matched of t...
explanation:
Function: parenmatch([<object>/]<attribute> [,<type>, [<key>], [<flags>]])
  
  This function returns an ansified match of parenthesis, brackets, and braces
  while hilighting red any mis-matched of the three.  The comparison will 
  always be left to right.  If the string is too large, it will always be
  returned un-altered.  If there are a large number of parenthesis, brackets, 
  and braces, it is possible the result will be cut off as ansi takes up 
  extra spaces.  If this is the case, use type '1' to just return 
  errors (if any).  An optional key of '1' will issue a pretty-print of the
  output in addition to the color output.  You may specify more than one flag.
  
  The following types exist:
    0 - Ansify the string and highlight red the first missmatch found (default)
    1 - If there is a missmatch, ONLY return that, else ansify the string.
  
  The following keys exist:
    0 - (default) do not pretty print the output.
    1 - pretty print the output.  Be aware on attribs that approach the 
        maximum output buffer size you may get values cut off.
  
  The following flags exist:
    s - put spaces after every , and ; character and before and after =
    p - put spaces before ) and after (
    b - put spaces before ] and after [
    B - put spaces before } and after {
  
  Examples:
    > @va me=[add(1,1)]
    > @vb me=[add(1,2))]
    > say parenmatch(vb)
    You say "[add(1,2))]"       (The second ')' would be hilighted red)
    > say parenmatch(vb,1)
    You say "[add(1,2))]"       (Just the second ')' would be colorized)
    > say parenmatch(vb,,,bps)
    You say "[ add( 1, 2 ) )]"  (it stops adding spaces on an error)
  
  See Also: parenstr(), brackets(), pos(), totpos()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CHILDREN() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CHILDREN() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: children(<obj> [,<key>] [,<objid>])
  
  Returns all children (objects parented to <obj>) that can be found.
  As this is somewhat extensive on the CPU, it may be limited to wizards
  only i...
explanation:
Function: children(<obj> [,<key>] [,<objid>])
  
  Returns all children (objects parented to <obj>) that can be found.
  As this is somewhat extensive on the CPU, it may be limited to wizards
  only in the future.
  
  If the optional <objid> is specified as '1', then it will return the
  objid's instead of dbref#'s.
  
  The following optional keys are available:
    0 - list all children of the target (default)
    n - List 'n'th 400 children of the target. 
        NOTE: 'n' will be any number from 1 to however many 'pages'
              So '1' would be first 400, '2' would be second 400, etc.
    l - List total pages and total children of target.
    ~ - [~#1-#2] list children starting at #1 until count of #2.
     
  Example:
  > @parent #10=#5
  Parent set.
  > @parent #15=#5
  Parent set.
  > say children(#5)
  You say "#10 #15"
  > say children(#5,,1)
  You say "#10:8185828282 #15:8282859018"
  
  See Also: parents(), parent()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TEL() - RhostMUSH Help

code:
Function: tel(<obj> [<obj2>...],<loc> [<loc2>...] [,<silent>])
  
  This function works like @tel/list works.  It will teleport one or
  more objects to one or more destinations.  It follows the same ...
explanation:
Function: tel(<obj> [<obj2>...],<loc> [<loc2>...] [,<silent>])
  
  This function works like @tel/list works.  It will teleport one or
  more objects to one or more destinations.  It follows the same 
  permissions and restrictions that @tel will follow.  The SIDEFX flag
  is required for this function.  
  
  The value of the optional argument 'silent' can be either 0 or 1. If
  set to 1 then the attributes 'atport', 'otport', 'oxtport' and 'tport'
  are not evaluated.
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  The last example teleports you to #0, bob to #2, and joe to #4.
  
  Example:
  > say tel(me,#0)
  You say ""
  The Beginning(#0)
  A simple room
  > @tel/list me=#0
  The Beginning(#0)
  A simple room
  > say tel(me bob joe,#0 #2 #4)
  You say ""
  
  See Also: @tel, move(), SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: LSET() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LSET() command/function in RhostMUSH
explanation:
Function: lset(<object>[/<lock>] [,[!]<flag>])
            lset(<object>[/<lock>])
  
  The lset() function is used to set specialized permissions on locks.  If you
  do not specify a lock, it will default to 'DefaultLock' which is aliased to 
  'BasicLock' for backward compatibility with other codebases.  If you do not
  specify a lock, it will display the current flags on the specified target
  lock.
  
  You may specify the '!' option to remove a specialist lock.
  
  Please see help on '@lset' for what specialized locks that you may set.
  You can only set the flags which you have permission to.
  
  This function returns an empty value and notifies the player as if they 
  ran the @lset command.
  
  Examples:
    > say lset(me,no_inherit)
    @lset: [DefaultLock] set NO_INHERIT on Ashen-Shugar(#12345)
    You say ""
    > say lset(me)
    @lset: [DefaultLock] on Player(#123): no_inherit
    You say ""
    > say lset(me/basic)
    @lset: [DefaultLock] on Player(#123): no_inherit
    You say ""
    > say lset(me/default)
    @lset: [DefaultLock] on Player(#123): no_inherit
    You say ""
    > say lset(me/fubar)
    #-1 LOCK NOT FOUND
    You say ""
  
  See Also: @lset, @set, set()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SET() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SET() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: set(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            set(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>> [,<tree>])
            set(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>> [,<tree>])
        ...
explanation:
Function: set(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            set(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>> [,<tree>])
            set(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>> [,<tree>])
            set(<object>/<attr>,[!]<attrflag>)
  
  The set() function is a side-effect for the @set command.  Everything that
  worked with @set will work with set().  It follows the same permissions and
  restrictions of the command.  The SIDEFX flag is required to use set().
  
  You may specify the optional <tree> of '1' or '3' to specifically set a 
  TREE with all branches filled (that do not exist) on the target.  A TREE 
  set will also verify permission on every branch of that tree prior to 
  setting.  Failure to set any of the branches, for any reason, will disallow 
  setting the attribute as well.
  
  You may specify an optional <tree> of '2' or '3' to specify that all
  attributes set will ignore the special case of '_' (third example above) 
  when setting attributes.  Otherwise, doing '_foo/bar' will try to fetch
  attribute 'bar' from object '_foo' and set it to that attribute. 
    
  The <tree> toggle is ignored on any method of set() that does not 
  set or clear attributes.
   
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @set me=safe
  Set.
  > say set(me,safe)
  You say ""
  > say set(me,_content_)
  You say "No match."
  > say set(me,_content_,2)
  You say ""
  
  See Also: toggle(), totemset() lset(), rset(), writable(), &, @set, 
            SIDEEFFECTS, ATTRIBUTE TREES
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: RSET() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for RSET() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: rset(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            rset(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>> [,<tree>])
            rset(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>> [,<tree>])
     ...
explanation:
Function: rset(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            rset(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>> [,<tree>])
            rset(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>> [,<tree>])
            rset(<object>/<attr>,[!]<attrflag>)
  
  The rset() function is a side-effect for the @set command.  It works nearly
  like the set() sideeffect, except it returns the string that it set. 
  Everything that worked with @set will work with rset().  It follows the 
  same permissions and restrictions of the command.  The SIDEFX flag is 
  required to use rset().
  
  You may specify the optional <tree> of '1' or '3' to specifically set a TREE
  with all branches filled (that do not exist) on the target.  A TREE set will
  also verify permission on every branch of that tree prior to setting.  
  Failure to set any of the branches, for any reason, will disallow 
  setting the attribute as well.
  
  You may specify an optional <tree> of '2' or '3' to specify that all
  attributes set will ignore the special case of '_' (third example above) 
  when setting attributes.  Otherwise, doing '_foo/bar' will try to fetch
  attribute 'bar' from object '_foo' and set it to that attribute. 
  
  The <tree> toggle is ignored on any method of rset() that does not 
  set or clear attributes.
   
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @set me=safe
  Set.
  > say set(me,safe)
  You say ""
  > say rset(me,safe)
  You say "safe"
  
  See Also: toggle(), totemset(), lset(), set(), writable(), &, @set, 
            SIDEEFFECTS, ATTRIBUTE TREES
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: RUNINTZ() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for RUNINTZ() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: runintz(<timezone>, <string>)
  
  This function will evaluate and run the <string> in the specified
  <timezone>.  If the <timezone> is invalid, the function will error out.
  
  If you pas...
explanation:
Function: runintz(<timezone>, <string>)
  
  This function will evaluate and run the <string> in the specified
  <timezone>.  If the <timezone> is invalid, the function will error out.
  
  If you pass a null <string> the function will immediately return out.
  
  This is useful to sandbox a string and evaluate it in a forced timezone.
  All time related functions will honor the timezone.
  
  Examples:
    > say ptimefmt($a $b $d $I:$M:$S $p $Z,1703322860)
      You say "Sat Dec 23 03:14:20 AM CST"
    > say runintz(US/Hawaii, ptimefmt($a $b $d $I:$M:$S $p $Z,1703322860))
      You say "Fri Dec 22 11:14:20 PM HST"
    > say runintz(GMT, ptimefmt($a $b $d $I:$M:$S $p $Z,1703322860))
      You say "Sat Dec 23 09:14:20 AM GMT"
    > say runintz(CST6CDT, ptimefmt($a $b $d $I:$M:$S $p $Z,1703322860))
      You say "Sat Dec 23 03:14:20 AM CST"
    > say runintz(localtime, ptimefmt($a $b $d $I:$M:$S $p $Z,1703322860))
      You say "Sat Dec 23 03:14:20 AM CST"
  
  See Also: ptimefmt(), secstz(), time(), TIMEZONE
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: RULER() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for RULER() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: ruler(<object>/<attribute>, <ruler value>)
  
  This function will provide a ruler to quickly eyeball the character position
  of the output of the given attribute.  The <ruler value> must b...
explanation:
Function: ruler(<object>/<attribute>, <ruler value>)
  
  This function will provide a ruler to quickly eyeball the character position
  of the output of the given attribute.  The <ruler value> must be a multiple
  of 10, and must be between 0 and 100.  
  
  The ruler is color coded to help make it easier to quickly eyeball and 
  count out the position.  Handy for some functions that require positional
  arguments like creplace(), mid(), and @label.
  
  The output of this command works like a side-effect so the output can not
  be captured other than with @pipe.
  
  Examples:
    > &TEST me=Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3
    Set.
    > think ruler(me/test,60)
           | ---------|10-------|20-------|30-------|40-------|50-------|60 |
           | Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3 Testing 1 2 3                      |
    0      | 123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890   |
           | ---------|10-------|20-------|30-------|40-------|50-------|60 |
  
  See Also: mid(), creplace(), @label
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PEMIT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PEMIT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: pemit(<object1> [<object2> ... <objectN>], <string> [,<key>])
  
  The pemit() function is a side-effect for the @pemit/list command.  All
  restrictions and permissions of that command foll...
explanation:
Function: pemit(<object1> [<object2> ... <objectN>], <string> [,<key>])
  
  The pemit() function is a side-effect for the @pemit/list command.  All
  restrictions and permissions of that command follow this function.  The
  SIDEFX flag is required to use pemit().  Pemit() by default evaluates
  for every target in the list.  It does NOT evaluate ## by default.
  
  The following key values are allowable:
    1 - will have ## substituted for every target object in the list.  Keep 
        in mind the '##' is pre-processed like iter's ## would be and could 
        be a security risk if used improperly.  
    2 - only evaluate once.  This by default disables ## from evaluation.
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @pemit/list me me=test
  test
  test
  > say pemit(me me,test)
  test
  test
  You say ""
  > @eval pemit(#123,test ##)		(assuming your dbref# is #123)
  test #123
  
  See Also: @pemit, npemit(), SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: NPEMIT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for NPEMIT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: npemit(<object> [<object2> ...],<string> [,<key>])
  
  The npemit() function works like pemit() except it won't strip spaces.
  
  <key> if specified to '1' evaluates '##' as each <object> ...
explanation:
Function: npemit(<object> [<object2> ...],<string> [,<key>])
  
  The npemit() function works like pemit() except it won't strip spaces.
  
  <key> if specified to '1' evaluates '##' as each <object> in the list.
  
  This executes the exact same code as pemit(), but with the assumption
  of the compile time option secure_sideeffects enabled.  This is the
  default behavior.
  
  Ergo: This function is exactly the same as pemit() with the compile
        option 'secure_sideeffects' enabled.  This function is left
        in to ensure 'secure_sideeffect' behavior exists for npemit
        regardless of compile time options specified.
  
  This function is essentially left for compatibility reasons and not
  really needed anymore, except when compiling specifically without
  the default behavior.  The example below will always be pretty much
  the same regardless of what option you have.  Without the option
  secure_sideeffect, it essentially causes a double-eval which while
  not the preferred method is backward compatible to very old versions
  of RhostMUSH, MUX, and TinyMUSH.
     
  Example:
  > @pemit/list me me=test
  test
  test
  > say npemit(me me,test)
  test
  test
  You say ""
  
  See Also: @pemit, pemit(), SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CREATE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CREATE() command/function in RhostMUSH
explanation:
Function: create(<name>, [<arguments> [,<type> [,<target-owner> [,key]]])
  
  If 'key' is specified as '1', and the <name> starts with a dbref# and is
  enacted by an immortal, it enforces strict mode and verifies the dbref#
  as valid to be used for creation.
  
  @create:  create(<name>, <value>, t) (default)
            create(<dbref#> <name>, <value>, t,, 1)  (enforce free dbref#)
    This will create an object with name <name> of value <value>.  The 't'
    <type> is optional for this as it is the default.  For more help on
    creating objects, please refer to 'help @create'.  If <value> is null
    it assumes the default.  All objects made are sent to enactor's location.
  
    If no arguments are given, the default money value is taken for this 
    option only.
  
  @dig:     create(<name>, <[exit-in], [exit-out]>, r)
            create(<dbref#> <name>, <[exit-in], [exit-out]>, r,, 1)
            dig(<name>, <[exit-in], [exit-out]>)
    This will dig a room with name <name> and OPTIONAL in-exit 'exit-in' and
    OPTIONAL out-exit 'exit-out'.  You may specify both, either, or no exits.
    For more help on digging rooms, please refer to 'help @dig'.
  
  @open:    create(<name>, <link>, e)
            create(<dbref#> <name>, <link>, e,, 1)
            open(<name>, <link>)
    This will open an exit with name <name> to OPTIONAL target <link>.  If
    <link> is unspecified, then the exit will be un-linked and will need to
    be @linked later (if so desired).
  
  @pcreate: create(<name>, <password>, p)
            create(<dref#> <name>, <password>, p,, 1)
    This will create the target player.  You need to have access to @pcreate
    to be able to use this feature of create().
  
  @robot:   create(<name>, <password>, p, <target-owner>)
            create(<dbref#> <name>, <password>, p, <target-owner>, 1)
    This will create the target robot player.  You need to have access to
    both the @robot feature as well as control the target-owner to create
    a robot.  To create a robot that you own, make target-owner yourself.
  
  The SIDEFX flag needs to be set to use this function. 
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > say create(An Object,10)  (this will create 'An Object' with value of '10')
  > say create(An Object)     (this will create 'An Object' with default cost)
  > say create(#123 An Object,10,,,1) (create 'An Object' with dbref #123)
  
  See Also: @create, @dig, @open, @pcreate, dig(), open(), SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: @pcreate - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for @pcreate command/function in RhostMUSH
explanation:
Command: @pcreate[/switch] [#dbref] <player>=<password>
           @pcreate/register [#dbref] <player>=<email>
  
  Creates a new player with the indicated password.  This command is
  equivalent to typing 'create <player> <password>' from the connection
  screen, and is normally only used when registration is enabled.
  
  Super-royalty have the added ability to specify the dbref# they wish
  to use for that player.  The dbref# *must* be in the free list else
  it will default to the highest dbref# on the free list automatically,
  
  Note: @reclist/free to display the free list.
        @stat to show the 'next free dbref#'
  
  Optional switches are:
      /register - Allows you to email a registration email to the
                  target email.  Only wizards and higher may use this.
      /ansi     - Combines @pcreate with @extansi to ansify the name
                  of the player.  This follows @extansi permissions.
      /strict -- will enforce [#dbref] to be a valid free dbref before create.
  
  Example:  @pcreate #5 NewPlayer=FarkleWhoop&Wo0
            @pcreate NewPlayer=FarkleWhoop&Wo0
            @pcreate/reg NewPlayer=myfriend@myemail.net
            @pcreate/ansi [ansi(hb,Blueboy)]=FarkleWhoop&Wo0
   
  Note: if the config parameter safer_passwords is enabled, it requires 
        much more strict passwords than one may expect.
  
  You may use the lastcreate() function to see the last player @pcreate'd.
  
  See Also: REGISTRATION, safer_passwords
  
  Normal Help: lastcreate()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: LISTMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LISTMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: listmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delimiter> [,<args>]])
 
  The listmatch() function tries to match <pattern> against <string>. If it
  succeeds, it returns a list of the text that matched e...
explanation:
Function: listmatch(<string>, <pattern>[, <delimiter> [,<args>]])
 
  The listmatch() function tries to match <pattern> against <string>. If it
  succeeds, it returns a list of the text that matched each wildcard (up to
  ten) in <pattern>. Normally, the list is space-separated, but if
  <delimiter> is specified, the list will be separated by that instead.
  
  You may specify the optional <args> that you want to display in a space
  delimited list.
   
  If it fails, or <pattern> contains no wildcards, it returns an empty
  string.
 
  Example:
    > say listmatch(This is a test, *test)
    You say "This is a "
    > say listmatch(hit the troll with the sword, hit * with *, /)
    You say "the troll/the sword"
    > say listmatch(hit the troll with the sword, hit * with *, /, 0 1)
    You say "the troll/the sword"
    > say listmatch(hit the troll with the sword, hit * with *, /, 1)
    You say "the sword"
    > say listmatch(hit the troll with the sword, hit * with *, /, 0)
    You say "the troll"
    > say listmatch(kow, wok)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: setqmatch(), match(), totmatch(), wildmatch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: LIST() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LIST() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: list(<list>, <eval>[, <delim> ][, <header>][, <target>])
 
  This function works just like iter() but returns each result on a separate
  line thereby bypassing the buffer limit that RhostMU...
explanation:
Function: list(<list>, <eval>[, <delim> ][, <header>][, <target>])
 
  This function works just like iter() but returns each result on a separate
  line thereby bypassing the buffer limit that RhostMUSH contains.  Each line
  will be a new line and will not be space delimited and will be displayed
  PRIOR to the output of the command calling it.
  
  <list> is a <delimiter>-separated list of strings, which can be object
  numbers, attributes, or arbitrary words.  <eval> is a string that is to be
  evaluated once for each item in <list>, replacing the special symbol ## with
  the corresponding item from <list>.  A space-separated list of the results
  of these evaluations is returned to the caller.  The effect is very similar
  to @dolist, except that the results are made into a list and returned, not
  executed.  The special symbol #@ can be used to return the positional match
  of the current item of the list.  list() will work without SIDEFX.  You may 
  specify an optional <header> which will be displayed prior to the lists.
  <target> optionally sends output to the target player.  You must control
  the target or it will default to the enactor.
  
  You may use %i0-%i9 for itext(0) to itext(9).  
  You may use %il for the outermost layer, equiv to itext(ilev())
   
  {See 'help list2' for examples}
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios
