title: DIGEST() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for DIGEST() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: digest(<algorithm>, <string>)
   
  Returns a checksum (Hash, digest, etc.) of <string> using the given
  <algorithm>.  If the mush is compiled with SSL support <algorithm> 
  can be one of:...
explanation:
Function: digest(<algorithm>, <string>)
   
  Returns a checksum (Hash, digest, etc.) of <string> using the given
  <algorithm>.  If the mush is compiled with SSL support <algorithm> 
  can be one of:
   
           md2 md4 md5 sha sha1 dss1 mdc2 ripemd160
   
  Without SSL, only the sha algorithm is enabled. 
  
  See '@list options' on what algorithms are supported.
  
  Examples: 
    > say digest(md5, test123)
    You say "cc03e747a6afbbcbf8be7668acfebee5"
    > say digest(sha, test123)
    You say "3a589de6214fd40ae461313fd81dfd1edb7eae70"
   
  See also: crc32(), pack(), roman(), encrypt(), decrypt(), encode64(),
            decode64(), crc32obj(), bucket()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: DIG() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for DIG() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: dig(<room>[[,<in exit>][,<out exit>][,<location>][,<type>]])
  
  This side-effect function mimics the full range of functionality that @dig 
  uses.  It also follows all restrictions and pe...
explanation:
Function: dig(<room>[[,<in exit>][,<out exit>][,<location>][,<type>]])
  
  This side-effect function mimics the full range of functionality that @dig 
  uses.  It also follows all restrictions and permissions of the @dig command.
  You can dig room name <room> with optional exit from your current location 
  to that room <in exit> and optional exit from the room being created to your
  current room <out exit>.  Neither of the exits are required.  
  
  The optional <location> specifies what location the dig() function is to
  open exits <in exit> from and <out exit> back to.  You must control the
  location, it must be specified as a dbref#, and it must be an object or room.
  
  The optional <type> specifies if the default behavior (with a '0') returns
  just the dbref# of the room created, or if a '1' specifies if the room# with
  the exit TO and the exit FROM be listed on a single line.
  
  This function requires the SIDEFX flag.
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect function is enabled.
   
  Examples:
    > say dig(My Room)			(without sidefx return values enabled)
    You say ""
    > say dig(Another Room,In <I>;i;in) (with sidefx return values enabled)
    You say "#123"
    > say dig(Yet Another Room,In <I>;i;in,Out <O>;o;out)
    You say "#124"
    > say dig(Yet Another Room,In <I>;i;in,Out <O>;o;out,,1)
    You say "#127 #128 #129"
  
  See Also: create(), open(), @dig, SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: OPEN() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for OPEN() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: open(<exit>[,<link>][,<location>])
  
  This side-effect function mimics the full range of functionality that @open
  uses.  It also follows all restrictions and permissions of the @open 
  ...
explanation:
Function: open(<exit>[,<link>][,<location>])
  
  This side-effect function mimics the full range of functionality that @open
  uses.  It also follows all restrictions and permissions of the @open 
  command.  You may open an exit with name <exit> with-out linking it to a 
  destination <link> if you so desire, but the exit would have to be @linked
  (or link()'d) later depending on what you're needs are.  The first example
  just opens an exit without linking it.  The second example opens an exit
  and links it to #0.  
  
  The optional <location> specifies where to open the exit out of.  It must
  be controlled by you, specified as a dbref# and must be an object or room.
  
  The SIDEFX flag is required to use open().
  
  Note:  To make variable exits, you @toggle the exit VARIABLE then set
         an appropriate @exitto on it.
   
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect function is enabled.
  
  Examples:
    > say open(My Exit <ME>;my exit;my;exit;me)
    You say ""
    > say open(Another Exit <AE>;another exit;another;exit;ae,#0)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: create(), dig(), link(), @open, SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: DESTROY() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for DESTROY() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: destroy(<object>)
  
  The destroy() function will destroy the targeted object.  You can not
  destroy anything set SAFE or INDESTRUCTABLE with the destroy() function.
  You have to use @des...
explanation:
Function: destroy(<object>)
  
  The destroy() function will destroy the targeted object.  You can not
  destroy anything set SAFE or INDESTRUCTABLE with the destroy() function.
  You have to use @destroy for these.  This is for security precautions.
  This will immediately halt anything that the object may be evaluating.
  
  Check @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  Anything using this side-effect must have the SIDEFX flag set.
  
  Example:
    > say destroy(#123)
    You say ""
   
  See Also: @destroy, wipe(), create()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: WIPE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for WIPE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: wipe(<obj>[/wildattr] [[,<regexp>] [,<ownerkey>] [,<preserve>]])
            wipe(<owner>/<obj>[/wildattr], [,<regexp>], 1, [,<preserve>])
  
  The wipe() function will remove all matching a...
explanation:
Function: wipe(<obj>[/wildattr] [[,<regexp>] [,<ownerkey>] [,<preserve>]])
            wipe(<owner>/<obj>[/wildattr], [,<regexp>], 1, [,<preserve>])
  
  The wipe() function will remove all matching attributes specified by
  a wildcard, or, if no attribute is specified, remove all attributes of
  the specified object.  This function works like @wipe and follows all
  permissions and restrictions of the matching command.
  
  If <regexp> is specified as '1', then <wildattr> is evaluated as a
  regular expression instead of the default expression.
  
  If <ownerkey> is specified as '1', then, as the second syntax example above,
  it takes the additional <owner> argument as the owner to compare against.
  
  If <preserve> is specified as '1', it takes the reverse of the wipe and
  keeps the specified wildcard pattern and wipes everything else.
   
  Check @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  Anything using this side-effect must have the SIDEFX flag set.
  
  Examples:
    > say wipe(Corum/#123/*foo,,1)   (this wipes attribs owned by Corum only)
    You say "Wipe: 1 attributes wiped."
    > say wipe(#123/*foo*)
    You say "Wipe: 8 attributes wiped."
    > say wipe(#123/^.*ab$,1)
    You say "Wipe: 2 attributes wiped."
    > say wipe(#123)
    You say "Wipe: 218 attributes wiped."
  
  See Also: @wipe, @set, &, set()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ZEMIT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ZEMIT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: zemit(<list of zones>, <text> [,<key>])
  
  The zemit() function returns 'text' to every room of every zone in
  the specified list.  If the target zone is not a zonemaster, but still
  is ...
explanation:
Function: zemit(<list of zones>, <text> [,<key>])
  
  The zemit() function returns 'text' to every room of every zone in
  the specified list.  If the target zone is not a zonemaster, but still
  is contained in a zone, then it will just return the text to that room.
  This function by default evaluates '##' for each zone in the list and
  evaluates separately for every zone member.
  
  This works similarly to @pemit/zone/list
  
  Check @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.  
  Anything using this side-effect must have the SIDEFX flag set.
  
  Following <key> values exist:
    1 - disable ## substitution.
    2 - evaluate only once for every zone in list (disables ## automatically)
  
  Examples:
    > @zone here=#0
    > say zemit(#0,blarg)
    blarg   (Note: blarg will have been sent to all rooms of the zonemaster!)
    You say ""
    > say zemit(here,blarg)
    blarg   (Note: blarg is just sent to this current room)
    You say ""
    > @zone/purge here
    > say zemit(here,blarg)
    Invalid zone.
    You say ""
  
  See Also: @pemit, @emit, emit()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: oemit(<target>, <text> [,<key>])
  
  The oemit() function returns 'text' at location of 'target' without letting
  'target' know what was emitted.  This works identical to the @oemit command
  and follows all permissions and restrictions.  The SIDEFX flag is required
  to be able to use the oemit() function.
  
  An optional key of <key> may be specified to toggle the affect of having
  <target> be multiple arguments.  A <key> of '1' enables multi-targetting.
   
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect function is enabled.
  
  Examples:
    > say oemit(TinyPlayer,boo!)
    boo!
    You say ""
    > say oemit(me,boo!)
    You say ""
    > say oemit(me you them,boo!,1)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: lemit(), pemit(), emit(), @oemit, SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

  Type @list options to see if this side-effect function is enabled.
  
  Examples:
    > say lemit(boo!)
    boo!
    You say ""
  
  See Also: emit(), pemit(), oemit(), @emit, SIDEEFFECTS

explanation:
Function: clone(<object>[[,<new name>][,<key>])
  
  The clone() function will clone <object> with the optional new name of
  <new name>.  It follows all permissions and restrictions that the @clone
  command requires.  The SIDEFX flag is required to be able to use this
  function.
  
  The following keys are available for clone():
      1 - issue a PARENT clone                (normal rules apply)
      2 - issue a PRESERVE clone              (wizard only)
      3 - issue a PARENT and PRESERVE clone   (wizard only)
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect function is enabled.
  
  Examples:
    > say clone(An Object)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: create(), dig(), open(), @clone, SIDEEFFECTS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARENT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARENT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: parent(<obj>[,<parent>])
 
  Returns the parent of <obj>.  Returns #-1 if <obj> cannot be found or
  if you do not own <obj> and it is not set VISUAL.
 
  If side-effects are enabled, specif...
explanation:
Function: parent(<obj>[,<parent>])
 
  Returns the parent of <obj>.  Returns #-1 if <obj> cannot be found or
  if you do not own <obj> and it is not set VISUAL.
 
  If side-effects are enabled, specifying a parent will cause it to be
  parented to that object.  If side-effects are not enabled, you will
  get an error message.  The SIDEFX flag is required to use the side-effect.
  Type @list options to see if the side-effect portion of parent() is enabled.
  The sideeffect will return the dbref# of the parent it set it to or #-1
  if the parent was not set.
  
  Example:
    > say parent(me)
    You say "#-1"
    > say My va is [v(va)].
    You say "My va is "
    > @parent me=test
    Parent set.
    > say parent(me) and my va is [v(va)].
    You say "#123 and my va is Testing 123"
    > say parent(me,#0)
    You say ""
    > say parent(me)
    You say "#0"
  
  See Also: @parent, PARENT OBJECTS, parents(), children()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: sign(<number>)
 
  Returns -1, 0, or 1 depending on whether its argument is negative, zero, or
  positive (respectively).
 
  Example:
  > say sign(-4)
  You say "-1"
  > say sign(4)
  You say "1"
  > say sign(0)
  You say "0"
  > say sign(-1)
  You say "-1"
  
  See Also: abs()

title: CONN() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CONN() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: conn(<player> [,<boolean> [,<port>]])
 
  Returns the number of seconds that <player> has been connected.  If <player>
  is not connected then -1 is returned.  If <player> is connected more ...
explanation:
Function: conn(<player> [,<boolean> [,<port>]])
 
  Returns the number of seconds that <player> has been connected.  If <player>
  is not connected then -1 is returned.  If <player> is connected more than
  once, the longest connect time is returned.
  
  You may specify an optional boolean value of '1' to return the result in
  the form '<port>:<conntime>'.  You may also specify the port of the player
  for an exact match of their conn() time.
   
  Example:
    > WHO
    Player Name          On For Idle  Doing
    Wizard                00:04   1m
    Evinar                00:12   6m  
    Wizard                00:32   6s  
    3 Players logged in.
    > say conn(wiz)
    You say "2125"
    > say conn(wiz,1)
    You say "12:251 14:2125"
    > say conn(e)
    You say "770"
  
  See Also: WHO, idle(), lwho(), CONNINFO
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: connrecord()
            connmax(<player>)
            conntotal(<player>)
            connnum(<player>)
            connleft(<player>)
            connlast(<player>)
  
  These set of functions pull the CONNINFO data from a player.  Each function
  references a different value of the data.
  
  Examples:
  > say connrecord()      @@ record of total connections to the mush
    32
  > say connmax(tester)   @@ longest connection time in seconds by the player
    289592
  > say conntotal(tester) @@ total seconds the player has been on the the mush
    22858928
  > say connnum(tester)   @@ total connections player made to the mush
    49
  > say connleft(tester)  @@ EPOCH (in seconds) player last disconnected
    1711325808
  > say connlast(tester)  @@ total seconds the player's last connection was
    5929
  
  See Also: idle(), conn(), lwho()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

  Returns the number of seconds that <player> has been idle.  If <player>
  is not connected then -1 is returned.  If <player> is connected more than
...
explanation:
Function: idle(<player> [,<boolean> [,<port>]))
 
  Returns the number of seconds that <player> has been idle.  If <player>
  is not connected then -1 is returned.  If <player> is connected more than
  once, the smallest idle time is returned.
  
  You may specify an optional boolean value for the type.  If '1' is chosen 
  it will output in the form '<port>:<idle>'.  You may specify the exact port 
  of the player for an exact idle() match.
  
  Example:
    > WHO
    Player Name          On For Idle  Doing
    Wizard                00:04   1m
    Evinar                00:12   6m  
    Wizard                00:32   6s  
    3 Players logged in.
    > say idle(wiz)
    You say "6"
    > say idle(wiz,1)
    You say "12:68 14:6"
    > say idle(frobozz)
    You say "-1"
  
  See Also: WHO, conn(), lwho(), CONNINFO
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CONVSECS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CONVSECS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: convsecs(<seconds> [,<timezone>])
 
  This function converts seconds to a time string, based on how many
  seconds the number is after Jan 1, 1970.
  
  You may specify a seperate <timezone>...
explanation:
Function: convsecs(<seconds> [,<timezone>])
 
  This function converts seconds to a time string, based on how many
  seconds the number is after Jan 1, 1970.
  
  You may specify a seperate <timezone> for the convsecs to run against.
   
  Note: the time_paddzero @admin config parameter allows padding zeros.
  
  Example:
    > say secs()
    You say "709395750"
    > say convsecs(709395750)
    You say "Wed Jun 24 10:22:54 1992"
    > say convsecs(709395750,US/Hawaii)
    You say "Wed Jun 24 04:22:30 1992"
  
  This function may also be called as secs2time().
  
  See Also: convtime(), secs(), secstz(), time(), timefmt()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CONVTIME() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CONVTIME() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: convtime(<time string>)
 
  This functions converts a time string to the number of seconds since
  Jan 1, 1970. A time string is of the format: Ddd MMM DD HH:MM:SS YYYY
  where Ddd is the da...
explanation:
Function: convtime(<time string>)
 
  This functions converts a time string to the number of seconds since
  Jan 1, 1970. A time string is of the format: Ddd MMM DD HH:MM:SS YYYY
  where Ddd is the day of the week, MMM is the month, DD is the day
  of the month, HH is the hour in 24-hour time, MM is the minutes,
  SS is the seconds, and YYYY is the year.
  If you supply an incorrectly formatted string, it will return -1.
 
  Example:
    > say time()
    You say "Wed Jun 24 10:22:54 1992"
    > say convtime(Wed Jun 24 10:22:54 1992)
    You say "709395774"
  
  This function may also be called as time2secs().
  
  This function, if allowing enhanced time formats, can handle a
  varying method of other formats.  Please see '@list options convtime'
  to see the available extra formats (if available).
  
  Enhanced date checking is handled with the 'enhanced_convtime' param.
  
  See Also: convsecs(), secs(), secstz(), time(), timefmt()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SORT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SORT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: sort(<list>[, <sort type>[, <delim> [, <sep>]]])
   
  * Takes a list of words, numbers, or dbref, and sorts them into ascending
    order.  Lexicographic order is used for words, and numeri...
explanation:
Function: sort(<list>[, <sort type>[, <delim> [, <sep>]]])
   
  * Takes a list of words, numbers, or dbref, and sorts them into ascending
    order.  Lexicographic order is used for words, and numeric order is used
    for numbers and dbrefs.
  * <sort type> may be used to specify the type of sort to perform (use d for
    dbref, n for integer numeric, f for floating numeric, a for alphanumeric
    and i for case-insensitive alphanumeric). If omitted or left blank, the
    sort() function will automatically determine the type of sort to perform.
  * If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
    in the list.  You may specify an alternate delimiter without specifying
    a sort type by passing a null <sort type> parameter.
  * If <sep> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
    in the output.
  
  If sort type starts with a ~ character, it does a reverse sort of the type.
     
  Examples:
    > say sort(This is a test)
    You say "This a is test"
    > say sort(98 99 100 101)
    You say "98 99 100 102"
    > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,,-)
    You say "bar-bletch-foo"
    > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,,-,+)
    You say "bar+bletch+foo"
    > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,~,-,+)
    You say "foo+bletch+bar"
  
  See Also: sortby(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff(),
            sortlist()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SORTLIST() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SORTLIST() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
+a  -- (default) sort alphanumerically by maximum value
+i  -- sort alphanumerically by maximum value (Case-insensitive)
+n  -- sort integers numerically by maximum value
+f  -- sort floating numerically by maximum value
+d  -- sort dbref#'s numerically by maximum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid)
+/-m  -- merge all the lists into a single list (+ or - does same thing)
+/-m| -- same as above, but anything after the '|' will be taken as the
explanation:
Function: sortlist(<order>, <sep>[;<osep>], <list1>, <list2>, [...,<listN>])
  
  This function takes 2 or more lists and chooses from each sample the max
  or min value based on the sorting value type.  The <order> must have as the
  first character a + for maxsort or a - for minsort.  If you do not specify
  a sort type after the +/- or if the value is invalid, it assumes alphanum.
  
  You may specify a seperator of <sep> for the elements in the list.  This can
  only be one character.  If part of the <sep> value is a semicolon followed 
  by a string, it will take the first char as the <sep> value and anything
  after the semi-colon (;) as the <osep> output seperator for the list.  
  The <osep> may be more than one character.  An example is '%b;FOO' where
  '%b' (a space) would be the <sep> value, and 'FOO' would be the <osep>
  value.
  
  The lists may be unequal lists.
  
  The following <order> types are allowed:  
    +a  -- (default) sort alphanumerically by maximum value 
    -a  -- (default) sort alphanumerically by minimum value
    +i  -- sort alphanumerically by maximum value (Case-insensitive)
    -i  -- sort alphanumerically by minimum value (Case-insensitive)
    +n  -- sort integers numerically by maximum value
    -n  -- sort integers numerically by minimum value
    +f  -- sort floating numerically by maximum value
    -f  -- sort floating numerically by minimum value
    +d  -- sort dbref#'s numerically by maximum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid)
    -d  -- sort dbref#'s numerically by minimum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid)
  +/-m  -- merge all the lists into a single list (+ or - does same thing)
  +/-m| -- same as above, but anything after the '|' will be taken as the 
           output delimiter between elements in each <list>. 
  
  With the dbref# sort, any invalid dbref# is assigned the value #-1.  If all
  arguments in that list order are all invalid, #-1 will be seen for the
  value.
  
{ see 'help sortlist2' for examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
(CONTINUED)
  Function: sortlist(<order>, <sep>[;<osep>], <list1>, <list2>, [...,<listN>])
  
  Examples:
    > say sortlist(+n,,1 2 3,10 0 20, 0 0 0)
    You say "10 2 20"
    > say sortlist(-n,,1 2 3,10 0 20, -100 100 200)
    You say "-100 0 3"
    > say sortlist(+n,:,1:2:3,5:6:7,4:4:4,0:9:20)
    You say "5:9:20"
    > say sortlist(+f,,1.2 2.5 3.3,1.3 2.4 -1.2)
    You say "1.3 2.5 3.3"
    > say sortlist(+d,,#1 #2 #3,#10 #0 #20 #3735 #100 #200 #333,#-1 #3 #3735)
    (Note: #3735 in this example is a Garbage/Recover/Non-Existant dbref#)
    You say "#10 #3 #20 #-1 #100 #200 #333"
    > say sortlist(+m,,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z)
    You say "a1v b2w c3x d4y e5z"
    > say sortlist(+m|++,,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z)
    You say "a++1++v b++2++w c++3++x d++4++y e++5++z"
    > say sortlist(+m|++,%b;@,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z)
    You say "a++1++v@b++2++w@c++3++x@d++4++y@e++5++z"
  
  See Also: sort(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff(),
            listinter(), listunion(), listdiff()

title: SORTBY() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SORTBY() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: sortby([<obj>/]<attrib>,<list>[,<delim> [,<sep>]])
  
  This sorts an arbitrary list according to the u-function <obj>/<attrib>.
  This u-function should compare two arbitrary elements, %0 a...
explanation:
Function: sortby([<obj>/]<attrib>,<list>[,<delim> [,<sep>]])
  
  This sorts an arbitrary list according to the u-function <obj>/<attrib>.
  This u-function should compare two arbitrary elements, %0 and %1, and
  return zero (equal), a negative integer (element 1 is less than element 2)
  or a positive integer (element 1 is greater than element 2).
  
  A simple example, which imitates a normal alphabetic sort:
    > &ALPHASORT test=[comp(%0,%1)]
    > say [sortby(test/ALPHASORT,foo bar baz)]
    You say "bar baz foo"
  
  A slightly more complicated sort. #1 is "God", #2 is "Amby", "#3" is "Bob":
    > &NAMESORT me=[comp(name(%0),name(%1))]
    > say [sortby(NAMESORT,#1 #2 #3)]
    You say "#2 #3 #1"
  
  Warning: the function invocation limit applies to this function. If
  this limit is exceeded, the function will fail _silently_. List and
  function sizes should be kept reasonable.
  
  See Also: sort(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

code:
Function: listdiff(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep>] [,<type>]]])
  
  This function returns the difference of two sets, keeping the order of the

explanation:
Function: listdiff(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep>] [,<type>]]])
  
  This function returns the difference of two sets, keeping the order of the
  first set.  Any element in <list1> that is not in <list2> will be 
  displayed.  The following types exist:
  
      0 - remove duplicates from lists (default)
      1 - show list with duplicates
  
  Example:
    > say listdiff(foo baz gleep bar foo foo, bar moof gleep)
    You say, "foo baz"
    > say listdiff(foo baz gleep bar foo foo, bar moof gleep,,-)
    You say, "foo-baz"
    > say listdiff(foo baz gleep bar foo foo, bar moof gleep,,-,1)
    You say, "foo-baz-foo-foo"

explanation:
Function: setdiff(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]])
   
  This function returns the difference of two sets -- i.e., the elements in
  <list1> that aren't in <list2>. The list that is returned is sorted.
   
  If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
  in the list.
  
  If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output
  separator for the list.
  
  If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default
  alphanumerical sort.  (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric.
   
  If sort type starts with a ~ character, it does a reverse sort of the type.
     
  Example:
    > say setdiff(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep)
    You say, "baz foo"
    > say setdiff(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-)
    You say, "baz-foo"
  
  See Also: setinter(), setunion(), sort(), listdiff()

  both <list1> and <list2>, minus any duplicate ...
explanation:
Function: setunion(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]])
   
  This function returns the union of two sets -- i.e., all the elements of
  both <list1> and <list2>, minus any duplicate elements. Think of it as
  CAT() without duplicated words.  The list returned is sorted.
   
  If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items
  in the list.
   
  If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output
  separator for the list.
  
  If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default
  alphanumerical sort.  (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric.
   
  If sort type starts with a ~ character, it does a reverse sort of the type.
     
  Example:
    > say setunion(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep)
    You say, "bar baz foo gleep moof"
    > say setunion(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-)
    You say, "bar-baz-foo-gleep-moof"
  
  See Also: setdiff(), setinter(), sort(), listunion()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: MERGE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for MERGE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: merge(<string1>, <string2>, <character> [,<key>])
  
  This function merges <string1> and <string2>, depending on <character>.
  
  If a character in <string1> is the same as <character>, it...
explanation:
Function: merge(<string1>, <string2>, <character> [,<key>])
  
  This function merges <string1> and <string2>, depending on <character>.
  
  If a character in <string1> is the same as <character>, it is replaced
  by the character in the corresponding position in <string2>.  The two
  strings must be of the same length.
  
  Spaces need to be treated specially. A null character is considered to
  equal a space, for <character>.
  
  If you specify <key> it will optionally be utf8/ansi aware.
  
  Note: if ansi_default is enabled, <key> is reversed.
  
  Note: If you specify <key> of 2 it will always be ansi aware.
    
  Examples:
    > say merge(AB--EF,abcdef,-)
    You say, "ABcdEF"
    > say merge(AB[space(2)]EF,abcdef,)
    You say, "ABcdEF"
  
  See Also: splice(), tr()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: repeat(<string>,<number> [,<ansi>])
  
  This function simply repeats <string>, <number> times.  No spaces are
  inserted between each repetition.
  
  You may specify the <ansi> toggle to '1' to make repeat ansi aware
  which optimizes ansi but will have a cost in performance.  This 
  defaults to '0'.
  
  Example:
    > say repeat(Test, 5)
    You say, "TestTestTestTestTest"
  
  See Also: space()

explanation:
Function: splice(<list1>, <list2>, <word>[, <delim> [, <sep> ]])
  
  This function splices <list1> and <list2> together. <list1> and <list2>
  are space-separated lists of words
  
  If a word in <list1> is the same as <word>, it is replaced by the word
  in the corresponding position in <list2>.  Both lists must have the
  same number of words.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.  
  
  <sep> may be used to specify an output separator other than a space.
   
  Example:
    > say splice(foo bar baz,eek moof gleep,bar)
    You say, "foo moof baz"
    > say splice(foo bar baz,eek moof gleep,bar,,-)
    You say, "foo-moof-baz"
  
  See Also: merge()

explanation:
Function: pmatch(<target>)
  
  This function returns the dbref# of the matching player.  It returns '#-1'
  if no player was found.
  
  You may specify a valid player dbref#, *player, or player.
  
  Example:
    > say %n %#
    You say "Bob #12345"
    > say pmatch(bob)
    You say "#12345"
    > say pmatch(#12345)
    You say "#12345"
    > say pmatch(*bob)
    You say "#12345"
  
  See Also: num(), pfind()

  This function works similiar to pmatch, except it will return any valid 
  dbref# when a dbref# is entered.  This also does not accept *player.
  
  This is provided for compatibility purposes to other codebases.
  
  Example:
    > say pfind(Bob)

Function: lloc(<target>)
  
  This function returns all the locations of the player until a condition
  is met.  
  
  Condition #1:  The first room is found and it exits normally.

explanation:
Function: lloc(<target>)
  
  This function returns all the locations of the player until a condition
  is met.  
  
  Condition #1:  The first room is found and it exits normally.
  Condition #2:  It surpasses the max drill-down of locations (20)
  Condition #3:  It detects recursive contents.
  
  Example:
    > @dig Room
    Room created with room number 1768.
    > @tel #1768
    Room(#1768)
    > @create An Object
    An Object created as object #1767
    > @drop An Object
    Dropped.
    > enter An Object
    An Object(#1767)
    > say lloc(me)
    You say "#1767 #1768"
  
  See Also: lroom(), loc(), rloc(), room()
  Function idea from Akallabeth, a PENNMush.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: between(<value1>,<value2>,<number>[,<boolean>])

  the values <value1> and <value2>.  If you specify the 
  optional boolean '1', it will see if the <number> is 
  between OR the values <value1> and <value2>.
  
  Example:
    > say between(10,15,14)
    You say "1"
    > say between(10,15,15)
    You say "0"
    > say between(10,15,15,1)
    You say "1"

explanation:
Function: fbetween(<value1>,<value2>,<number>[,<boolean>])
  
  This function will return TRUE (1) if <number> is between
  the values <value1> and <value2>.  If you specify the 
  optional boolean '1', it will see if the <number> is 
  between OR the values <value1> and <value2>.  This works
  like between() but handles floating point numbers.  This
  will round the values to the nearest significant 6th digit.
  
  Example:
    > say fbetween(10.01,15.01,14.5)
    You say "1"
    > say fbetween(10.5,15.20,15.20)
    You say "0"
    > say fbetween(10.5,15.20,15.20,1)
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: between(), fbound(), bound(), gt(), lt(), gte(), lte()

Function: soundex(<word>)

  A soundex pattern represents the sound of the word, and similar

explanation:
Function: soundex(<word>)
   
  The soundex function returns the soundex pattern for a word.
  A soundex pattern represents the sound of the word, and similar
  sounding words should have the same soundex pattern. Soundex patterns
  consist of an uppercase letter and 3 digits.
   
  Example:
    > think soundex(foobar)
    F160
   
  For details of how the algorithm works, see help soundex2
  
  See Also: soundlike()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SOUNDEX2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SOUNDEX2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Here's how the soundex algorithm works:
  1. The first letter of the soundex code is the first letter of
     the word (exception: words starting with PH get a soundex
     starting with F)
  2. Each ...
explanation:
Here's how the soundex algorithm works:
  1. The first letter of the soundex code is the first letter of
     the word (exception: words starting with PH get a soundex
     starting with F)
  2. Each remaining letter is converted to a number:
      vowels, h, w, y ---------> 0
      b, p, f, v --------------> 1
      c, g, j, k, q, s, x, z --> 2
      d, t --------------------> 3
      l -----------------------> 4
      m, n --------------------> 5
      r -----------------------> 6
     At this stage, "foobar" is "F00106" 
  3. Strings of the same number are condensed. "F0106"
  4. All 0's are removed, because vowels are much less important
     than consonants in distinguishing words. "F16"
  5. The string is padded with 0's or truncated to 4 characters. "F160"
  That's it. It's not foolproof (enough = "E520", enuf = "E510") but
  it works pretty well. :)
  
  Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: vadd(<vector>,<vector>[[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the sum of two vectors.  A vector is a list of numbers
  separated by spaces or a delimiter.  The vector lists must contain
  the same number of items or it will return an error.  You may
  specify an optional output separator.
   
  Examples:
    > think vadd(1 2 3,4 5 6)
    5 7 9
    > think vadd(0|0|0,1|2|3,|)
    1|2|3
    > think vadd(0|0|0,1|2|3,|,@)
    1@2@3
  
  See Also: vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Function: vdot(<vector>,<vector>[,<delimiter>])
  
  Returns the dot product of two vectors. A dot product is the sum
  of the products of the corresponding elements of the two
  vectors, e.g. vdot(a b c,d e f) = ad + be + cf.
  The vectors must be of the same length.
  
  Example:

Function: vmul(<vector|number>,<vector|number>[[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the result of either multiplying a vector by a number,
  or the elementwise product of two vectors.  This function may take an 
  optional output separator.
  
  Examples: 
    > think vmul(1 2 3,2)      (this is a vector by number)
    2 4 6
    > think vmul(1 2 3,2 3 4)  (this is a vector by vector)
    2 6 12
    > think vmul(1@2@3,2@3@4,@,|)  (this is a vector by vector)
    2|6|12
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vsub(), vmag(), vcross()

explanation:
Function: vmag(<vector>[,<delimiter>]
   
  Returns the magnitude of a vector, using a euclidean distance metric.
  That is, for vector a b c d, returns sqrt(a^2+b^2+c^2+d^2).
  The vectors must be the same length.
   
  Example:
    > think vmag(3 4) 
    5
  
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vcross()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: VCROSS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for VCROSS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: vcross(<vector>,<vector>[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the cross product of two vectors. The cross product of two
  vectors is a vector.  This function may take an optional separ...
explanation:
Function: vcross(<vector>,<vector>[,<delimiter>],<separator>])
   
  Returns the cross product of two vectors. The cross product of two
  vectors is a vector.  This function may take an optional separator.
  
                          | a b c |
  (a,b,c) X (d,e,f) = det | d e f | = i(bf-ce) + j(cd-af) + k(ae-bd)
                          | i j k |
  
  where i, j, and k are taken as unit vectors in Cartesian space.
   
  Examples:
  > @pemit me=vcross(1 2 3,2 3 4)
  -1 2 -1
  > @pemit me=vcross(1 2 3,2 3 4,,@)
  -1@2@-1
  
  Taken from MUX 2.0 with permission.
   
  See Also: vadd(), vdim(), vunit(), vdot(), vmul(), vsub(), vmag()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: pi([<arg>])
 
  Returns the value of the trigonometric constant pi to nine decimal places.
  
  If you specify an <arg> it takes that as the precision to the number of
  decimal places you want.  The value must be greater than zero, and less
  than the current maximum value specified as floating point precision.
  
  Please see:  @list options system 
   
  Example:
    > say pi()
    You say "3.141562654"
  
  See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), sin(), tan(), ctu(), 
            cosh(), sinh(), tanh()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PID() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PID() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: pid([<display> [,<separator> [,<type> [,<target>] [,<key>]]])
  
  This function returns the queue process table based on various arguments.
  
  <display> is one of a bitwise mask of the fo...
explanation:
Function: pid([<display> [,<separator> [,<type> [,<target>] [,<key>]]])
  
  This function returns the queue process table based on various arguments.
  
  <display> is one of a bitwise mask of the following:
    0    -  (default) show just the pids of all the processes
    1    -  Show just the pids of all the processes
    2    -  Show the owners of all the processes
    4    -  Show the enactor of all the processes
    8    -  Show the wait times of all the processes (semaphores have '0')
    16   -  Show the STOP/RUNNING status of all the processes
    32   -  Show the commands queued for all the processes.
  
  Adding the <display> values will return a combination of the values separated
  by the pipe (|) character.
  
  <separator> is your output separator that you wish between processes.  
  Default is a space.
  
  <type> can be one of many types.
    q    - show all queued (waited and semaphores) queued.  (default)
    w    - show all wait jobs
    s    - show all semaphore jobs
    p    - show all player queue jobs (jobs currently being ran)
    o    - show all object queue jobs (jobs currently being ran)
    c    - show count of all processes
  
  <target> is an optional target to narrow down queue values.  The <target> 
  may be a player or a process ID (PID).  Default is everyone.
  
  <key> if set to '1' will cause <target>, if a player type, to list all
  processes owned by that player.
  
  {help pid2 for examples}
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

    (PID: 224  )   [34]Weather Object (WO)(#1497VsIS[s]):@trigger me/TIME_LOOP

    ----- Semaphore Queue -----
    (PID: 71   )   [#901]Tester(#901Pc>Dp^UF<[so]):@pemit me=zoot
    (PID: 84   )   [#12345]Bob(#734P-ci>WFO<[UsO]):think foo

  Returns the sine of <number>, expressed in radians.
  
  You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians,
  (g)radians, or (d)egrees.  (r)adians are the default.
   
  Examples:

    You say "0.707107"
    > say sin(fdiv(pi(),6))
    You say "0.5"
  
  See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), tan(), ctu(), 
            sinh(), cosh(), tanh()

title: SINGLETIME() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SINGLETIME() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: singletime(<seconds>)
 
  This function converts seconds to a single time element which is
  the lowest approximation to the given number of <seconds>.
  
  The following letters are relevan...
explanation:
Function: singletime(<seconds>)
 
  This function converts seconds to a single time element which is
  the lowest approximation to the given number of <seconds>.
  
  The following letters are relevant:
    s - second    d - day     y - year               e - epoch
    m - minute    w - week    C - century
    h - hour      M - month   a - annum(Millennium)
  
  Note:  an epoch is 1 million years or more.
    
  Example:
    > say singletime(45)
    You say "45s"
    > say singletime(12345)
    You say "3h"
    > say singletime(123456)
    You say "1d"
 
  Related Topics: secs(), secstz(), time(), timefmt()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: ctu(<number>, <units-from>, <units-to>)
  
  The ctu() function will convert <number> that was originally in
  the units of <units-from> into the units of <units-to>.
  
  The units available are (r)adians, (g)radians, and (d)egrees.
  
  180 degrees = PI (3.141593) radians = 200 gradians.
  
  Examples:
    > say ctu(180,d,g)
    You say "200"
    > say ctu(180,d,r)
    You say "3.141593"
  
  See Also: sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), atan2(), pi(), 
            cosh(), sinh(), tanh()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ACCENT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ACCENT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: accent(<string>,<template>)
  
  The accent() function will return <string>, with characters in it
  possibly changed to accented ones according to <template>. Both
  arguments must be the s...
explanation:
Function: accent(<string>,<template>)
  
  The accent() function will return <string>, with characters in it
  possibly changed to accented ones according to <template>. Both
  arguments must be the same number of characters.
  
  Whether or not the resulting string is actually displayed correctly
  is client-dependent. Some OSes uses different character sets than
  the one assumed (ISO 8859-1), and some clients strip these 8-bit
  characters.
  
  You may also use the markup character %f to specify accents.
  To do that you would specify the <template> character after %f
  and then a 'n' to normalize it.
   
  You must be @toggled ACCENTS to be able to use accents. 
  
  ZENTY_ANSI must be compiled in to be able to use accents.
  
{ "help accent2" for more }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ACCENT2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ACCENT2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
CONTINUE
  Function: accent(<string>,<templatet>)
  
  For each character in <string>, the corresponding character of
  <template> is checked according to the table below, and a replacement
  done. If...
explanation:
CONTINUE
  Function: accent(<string>,<templatet>)
  
  For each character in <string>, the corresponding character of
  <template> is checked according to the table below, and a replacement
  done. If either the current <string> or <template> characters aren't
  in the table, the <string> character is passed through unchanged.
  
  Accent                         Template   String
  Name       Description         Character  Character
  -----------------------------------------------------------------
  grave      Backward slant      `          A,E,I,O,U,a,e,i,o,u
             above letter
  acute      Forward slant       '          A,E,I,O,U,Y,a,e,i,o,u,y
             above letter
  tilde      Wavy line above     ~          A,N,O,a,n,o
             letter
  circumflex carat above         ^          A,E,I,O,U,a,e,i,o,u
             letter
  umlaut     Two dots above      :          A,E,I,O,U,a,e,i,o,u
  diaeresis  letter
  ring       Small circle above  o          A,a
             letter
  cedilla    Small tail below    ,          C,c
             letter
  
{ "help accent3" for more }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: STRIPACCENTS() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for STRIPACCENTS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: stripaccents(<string>)
            stripunicode(<string>)
  
  Returns the string with accented (see also: ACCENTS) characters converted to
  non-accented.  This usage assumes the ISO 8859-1...
explanation:
Function: stripaccents(<string>)
            stripunicode(<string>)
  
  Returns the string with accented (see also: ACCENTS) characters converted to
  non-accented.  This usage assumes the ISO 8859-1 character set.
  
  Additionally, Unicode codepoints (see also: UNICODE SUPPORT) are converted to
  their closest non-accented character where available.
  
  Example:
    > say stripaccents(Aul(e-with-diaeresis))
    You say "Aule"
  
  If the accent or Unicode character has no ASCII version, it will not be shown.
  
  Example:
    > say stripaccents(Aul(latin-small-letter-thorn))
    You say "Aul"
  
  This function is also called stripunicode().
   
  See Also: chr(), asc(), strip(), stripansi(), stripunicode(), tr(), accent(),
            ACCENTS, UNICODE SUPPORT.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

description: Help documentation for ATAN2() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: atan(<number> [,<units>])
            atan2(<number1>, <number2> [,<units>]
  
  ATAN Returns the arctangent of <number>, expressed in radians.
  
  ATAN2 Returns the arctangent of <number1>...
explanation:
Function: atan(<number> [,<units>])
            atan2(<number1>, <number2> [,<units>]
  
  ATAN Returns the arctangent of <number>, expressed in radians.
  
  ATAN2 Returns the arctangent of <number1> divided by <number2> in radians.
  This is equivalent to atan(fdiv(<number1>,<number2>)[,<units>]) but allows
  a '0' divider without a divide by zero error.
   
  You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians,
  (g)radians, or (d)egrees.  (r)adians are the default.
  
  Examples:
    > say atan(0)
    You say "0"
    > say atan(1)
    You say "0.785398"
    > say atan2(90,90)
    You say "0.785398"
    > say atan(1.557408)
    You say "1"
    > say atan2(90,25)
    You say "1.299849"
  
  See Also: acos(), asin(), cos(), pi(), sin(), tan(), ctu(), cosh(), sinh(),
            tanh(), atan2()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: FLOORDIV() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for FLOORDIV() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: floordiv(<number1>,<number2>)
   
  Returns the integer quotient from dividing <number1> by <number2>.
   
  However, integer division for the case where either <integer1> or
  <integer2> is...
explanation:
Function: floordiv(<number1>,<number2>)
   
  Returns the integer quotient from dividing <number1> by <number2>.
   
  However, integer division for the case where either <integer1> or
  <integer2> is negative is defined in a specific way -- by choosing
  the largest integer that is less than or equal to the algebraic
  quotient. If <integer1> and <integer2> are the same sign, then
  idiv() and floordiv() are equivalent.
   
  For example, division of -9 by 5 would give -2 by this definition
  instead of -1. idiv() would return -1. floordiv() would return -2.
  The floordiv() function goes with the mod() function.
   
  floordiv(x,y)*y + mod(x,y) ==> x
   
  Examples:
    > say floordiv(17,3)
    You say "5"
    > say floordiv(18,3)
    You say "6"
    > say floordiv(-17,3)
    You say "-6"
   
  See Also: fdiv(), div(), mul(), sub(), mod()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

code:
Function: tag(<string>)
 
  This function returns the #dbref stored behind the tag named <string>.
  These tags get created with Rhost's tag system ( see 'wizhelp @tag' and
  'wizhelp tags' ) by admin...
explanation:
Function: tag(<string>)
 
  This function returns the #dbref stored behind the tag named <string>.
  These tags get created with Rhost's tag system ( see 'wizhelp @tag' and
  'wizhelp tags' ) by admins, and can be useful to avoid having hardcoded
  #dbrefs in mushcode.
 
  These tags can also be used on-the-fly in the client, for example using
  something like 'ex tag(weather_globals)' to examine the object of which
  the #dbref is stored in the 'weather_globals' tag.
 
  If a non-existent tagname is supplied in the tag() function, it always
  returns #-1.

  NOTE: An alternative to using tag() is to look up a tag with #<tagname>
   as a replacement for #dbref. For example, "tag(weather_globals)" and
  "#weather_globals" will return the same #dbref.
 
  Also See: help wizhelp tags, wizhelp @tag, wizhelp listtags(),
            wizhelp tagmatch()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TR() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TR() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: tr(<string>, <find>, <replace> [,<type>])
  
  This function translates every character in <string> that exists in
  <find> to the character at an identical position in <replace>. 
  
  If y...
explanation:
Function: tr(<string>, <find>, <replace> [,<type>])
  
  This function translates every character in <string> that exists in
  <find> to the character at an identical position in <replace>. 
  
  If you specify the <type> of '1', then tr will be made ansi-aware and 
  also process strings slower withthe ansi overhead.
  
  The default value is '0' which allows tr() to be in raw mode.
   
  Ranges of characters separated by -'s are accepted. <find> and <replace> 
  must be the same length after expansion of ranges. If a character exists 
  more than once in <find>, only the last instance will be counted. The example
  below is the common ROT-13 algorithm for lower case strings, demonstrated
  with every letter explicitly listed, and with the equivalent but briefer 
  character ranges. Literal -'s can be in <find> and <replace> if they are the
  first or last characters in the arguments.
  
  Note: the config param 'ansi_default' handles if the ansi handling is 
        configured default or not.  In which case the 'type' is reversed.
  
  Note: If you specify <type> of 2 it will always be ansi aware.
   
  Examples:
    > say tr(hello,abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz,nopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklm)
      You say, "uryyb"
    > say tr(uryyb, a-z, n-za-m)
      You say, "hello"
    > say tr(This is a TEST,a-mn-zA-MN-Z,n-za-mN-ZA-M)  (rot13)
      You ssay, "Guvf vf n GRFG"
  
  See also: merge(), foreach(), garble(), creplace(), medit(), edit(), 
            editansi()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TEMPLATE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TEMPLATE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: template(<string>, <arg0> [,<arg1>, ..., <arg9>])
  
  This function will take an input string <string> as the template string
  and do substitution based on the arguments you pass to it.  I...
explanation:
Function: template(<string>, <arg0> [,<arg1>, ..., <arg9>])
  
  This function will take an input string <string> as the template string
  and do substitution based on the arguments you pass to it.  It will
  walk through each of the arguments one character at a time and replace
  the specified characters in the template.  The following characters
  specify each of the template replacements in question:
  
    1 or more 0's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg0
    1 or more 1's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg1
    1 or more 2's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg2
    1 or more 3's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg3
    1 or more 4's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg4
    1 or more 5's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg5
    1 or more 6's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg6
    1 or more 7's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg7
    1 or more 8's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg8
    1 or more 9's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg9
  
  You may have any order of substitutions in the template.  You may
  use numbers that have no arguments.  In such a case the template will
  be replaced with a space character.  If the argument is shorter than
  the number of substitutions in the template, spaces are used as filler.
  
  Tabs will be replaced with a single space. 
  
  This function is ansi and accent aware.
  
  Examples:
    > say template(test <0123> test <0123> test,aaaaaaa,bbbbbbb,cccccc,dddddd)
    You say "test <abcd> test <abcd> test"
    > say template(test 001 wheee 100,----,<>)
    You say "test --< wheee >--"
    > think template(>>> 000000 <<<%r>>> 000000 <<<,abcde%rtuvwy)
    >>> abcde  <<<
    >>> tuvwy  <<<
  
  See Also: printf(), medit(), edit(), regedit(), template()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: FOREACH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for FOREACH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: foreach([<object>/]<attribute>,<string>[,<begin>, <end> [,<ansi>]])
   
  Each character in <string> has the user-defined function of the first
  argument performed on it; the character is p...
explanation:
Function: foreach([<object>/]<attribute>,<string>[,<begin>, <end> [,<ansi>]])
   
  Each character in <string> has the user-defined function of the first
  argument performed on it; the character is passed to the function as
  %0. The position of the argument is passed as %1.  The results are 
  concatenated. If <begin> and <end> are specified, only the characters 
  between <begin> and <end> are parsed, other characters are concatenated 
  as they are. This allows a rudimentary form of tokens and speeds up 
  the evaluation greatly if tokenizing is your purpose.
  
  If you specify <ansi> as '1', then specify <begin> and <end> as the special 
  string '@@' to specify to ignore the <begin> and <end> values.  Just putting
  nulls (empty values) there will assume null begin and end values and may
  not return the result you are wishing for.  Due to the higher than normal
  overhead, ansi-awareness in this function is not the default.
   
  Examples:
    > &add_one me=[add(%0,1)]
    > &ansi me=-%0-
    Set.
    > say [foreach(add_one, 54321)]
    You say, "65432"
    > &add_one me=[add(%0,1)]
    Set.
    > say [foreach(add_one, This adds #0# to numbers in this string,#,#)]
    You say, "This adds 1 to numbers in this string."
    > say [foreach(ansi,ansi(hr,r,hb,b,hc,c,hg,g),@@,@@,1)]
    You say "-r--b--c--g-"  (r is red, b is blue, c is cyan, g is green)
    
  See Also: @dolist, iter(), map(), citer(), nsiter(), list(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARSE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARSE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: parse(<list>,<eval>[,<delimiter> [,<output separator>]])
  
  This function takes each element of <list>, evaluates <eval> after
  substituting it for ##, and constructs a space-separated li...
explanation:
Function: parse(<list>,<eval>[,<delimiter> [,<output separator>]])
  
  This function takes each element of <list>, evaluates <eval> after
  substituting it for ##, and constructs a space-separated list of the
  results.  The special substitution of #@ can be used for the position
  of the current item in the list.  You may specify an output separator.
  
  This function can be reproduced with the iter function and as
  such is considered depreciated but left for compatibility.
  
  This function does not handle itext/inum/%i.  Use iter() for this.
   
  Examples:
    > say nsiter(lnum(3),--+#@)
    You say "--+1--+2--+3--+4"
    > say nsiter(lnum(4),--+)
    You say "--+--+--+--+"
    > say nsiter(This is a test,strlen(##))
    You say "4214"
    > say nsiter(This is a test,{strlen(##)})
    You say "4214"
    > say nsiter(lnum(10),mul(mul(##,##),10))
    You say "0104090160250360490640810"
    > say nsiter(lcon(me),[name(##)]..[money(##)])
    You say "test..1t1..1radio..1The Wizard's Pointy Hat..1"
    > say nsiter(Was it a cat I saw,words(##),s)
    You say "141"
  
  See Also: iter(), citer(), @dolist, parse(), list(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARSESTR() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARSESTR() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: parsestr(<string>, <eval> [,<delim> [.<output> [,<type>]
                       [,[&]<target>] [,<transchar> [,<endchar> [,<transeval>
                       [,<prefix> [,<oocprefix>]]]]]]])...
explanation:
Function: parsestr(<string>, <eval> [,<delim> [.<output> [,<type>]
                       [,[&]<target>] [,<transchar> [,<endchar> [,<transeval>
                       [,<prefix> [,<oocprefix>]]]]]]])
  
  This function takes an input string and parses it, based on the 
  delimiters, in a 'staggered' method, and passes each substring to
  the 'eval' as %0.  This is handy for parsing speech for example.
  
  Arguments are:
    <string>    -- input string that you wish to parse & translate
    <eval>      -- how you wish to parse each segment of the string. 
    <delim>     -- the optional input delimiter of the string
    <output>    -- the optional output delimiter of the string.
                   Note: if you have a space-separated argument, then
                         the first part is prefix, the rest is suffix.
    <type>      -- Take arguments between delimiters as even (default) or odd.
    <target>    -- The target you wish to have if initializer specified.
                   Note: a '&' prefix takes the string 'as-is'.  You must
                         control the target for the target to work.
    <transchar> -- The translation character after the 'delimiter' you wish
                   to identify the string for special processing.
    <endchar>   -- The last character in the field you wish to do special
                   processing on. (good for punctuation)
    <transeval> -- How you wish to parse the special processing string.
    <prefix>    -- The optional eval'd prefix to use for the 'say' string.
    <oocprefix> -- optional prefix to use when the @emit (|) option used.
  
  Note on <eval>: All arguments passed will be as in the <eval> and <transeval>
            %0  -- The string being passed for evaluation.      
  (prefix)  %1  -- The player name specified in target          (or &string).
  (prefix)  %2  -- The current parameter number being processed (-1 for prefix)
  (prefix)  %3  -- The absolute parameter being processed       (0 for prefix)
  (prefix)  %4  -- The transchar OR endchar being processed     (if any)
  
  Note:  Only the values with '(prefix)' are valid for the prefix evaluation.
  
{ see 'help parsestr2' for options for <string> }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: PARSESTR2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PARSESTR2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
(CONTINUED)
  Function: parsestr(<string>, <eval> [,<delim> [.<output> [,<type>]
                       [,[&]<target>] [,<transchar> [,<endchar> [,<transeval>]
                       [,<prefix>]]]]])
...
explanation:
(CONTINUED)
  Function: parsestr(<string>, <eval> [,<delim> [.<output> [,<type>]
                       [,[&]<target>] [,<transchar> [,<endchar> [,<transeval>]
                       [,<prefix>]]]]])
  
  The <string> argument handles the following syntax prefixes:
    " - This is a 'say' string.  If no prefix is specified this is the default
        case that is used.  When in 'say' format, it auto-closes all 
        double-quotes.
    : - This is a 'pose' string.  It follows standard pose/: syntax formatting.
    ; - This is the 'possessive-pose' string.  Follows ';' formatting.
    | - This is an '@emit' string.  Follow standard @emit formatting.
  
  If no prefix is identified as the 4 above, it assumes a say string.
  
  These prefixes are only used if the <prefix> option is specified in parsestr.
  If you do not specify a <prefix> then all prefix args are considered part
  of a normal string and ignored for special consideration.
  
{ see 'help parsestr3' for examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

code:

  Examples:

title: PASSTHROUGH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for PASSTHROUGH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: passthrough(<function> [,[+]<max> [,<args> [,<default>])
  
  This function will take a function call and pass the arguments that is 
  currently cached (being passed) to that function.
  
 ...
explanation:
Function: passthrough(<function> [,[+]<max> [,<args> [,<default>])
  
  This function will take a function call and pass the arguments that is 
  currently cached (being passed) to that function.
  
  This is a bit of a complex function in idea.  To help break it down these
  are the possible arguments and what they mean.
  
    <function>  -- the calling function that will accept the arguments.
    <max>       -- the maximum number of arguments the function will take.
                   If you prerfix with a + it enforces that number of args.
    <args>      -- this allows you to substitute the arguments.  For example:
                   1:3 3:1  -- substitute arg 1 with 3 and argument 3 with 1
                   Note: Arguments start at '0'.  So if 3 args are passed 0,
                         1, and 2 are the arguments
    <default>   -- use the default value as a filler value for any args
                   that are not being passed or are missing.
  
  Examples:
    > &FUN_FOO me=[passthrough(add)]
    > @lfunction add=me/fun_foo
    > say foo(10,10,10)
    You say "30"

    > &FUN_FOO me=[passthrough(strcat,,1:0 0:1)]
    > say foo(foo,bar)
    You say "barfoo"

    > &FUN_FOO me=[passthrough(strcat,,1:0)]
    > say foo(foo,bar)
    You say "foofoo"

    > &FUN_FOO me-[passthrough(strcat,+10,1:0,xxY)]
    > say foo(foo,bar)
    You say "foofooxxYxxYxxYxxYxxYxxYxxYxxY"
  
  See Also: strfunc()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: map() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for map() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: map([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>[[,<delim>][,<sep>][,<arg1>,...,<argN>])
  
  This function is nearly identical to an iter() operating on u() function.
  Each member of <list> is passed to the resu...
explanation:
Function: map([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>[[,<delim>][,<sep>][,<arg1>,...,<argN>])
  
  This function is nearly identical to an iter() operating on u() function.
  Each member of <list> is passed to the result of fetching <attr> as %0, and
  the results are used to form a new list, separated by the delimiter
  character.
  
  <delim>iter may be used to specify a delimiter other than space.
  
  <sep>erator may be used to specify an output separator other than a space.
  
  You may specify arguments <arg1> through <argN> that will be passed as %1
  for the first argument (or arg1) all the way through MAX_ARGS 
  (which defaults to 30 total to a function, so 30 - 4 args, or 26 total).
  Any arguments over 9 can be fetched with v(10), v(11), etc.  You may also
  use the shift() function.
  
  Examples: 
  > &ADD_ONE object=add(%0,1)
  > say map(object/add_one,1 2 3 4 5)
  You say "2 3 4 5 6"
  
  See Also: filter(), fold(), iter(), parse(), u(), munge(), citer(), 
            nsiter(), sortlist(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: filter() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for filter() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: filter([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>[,<delim>[,<sep>][,<arg1>,...,<argN>]])
  
  This function evaluates the contents of <attr> for each element of <list>,
  passing it in as %0.  A <delimiter>-sepa...
explanation:
Function: filter([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>[,<delim>[,<sep>][,<arg1>,...,<argN>]])
  
  This function evaluates the contents of <attr> for each element of <list>,
  passing it in as %0.  A <delimiter>-separated list is returned of those
  elements for which the evaluation returns the value 1.  You may specify an
  optional output separator.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than space.
  
  You may specify 26 arguments to pass as %1 (or v(1)) though v(25) or may
  utilize the shift() function.
  
  Examples:
    > &IS_ODD object=mod(%0,2)
    > say filter(object/is_odd,1 2 3 4 5)
    You say "1 3 5"
    > say filter(object/is_odd,1@2@3@4@5,@)
    You say "1@3@5"
    > say filter(object/is_odd,1@2@3@4@5,@,|)
    You say "1|3|5"
  
  See Also: u(), map(), fold(), citer(), nsiter(), munge(), list(), 
            sortlist(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: fold() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for fold() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: fold([<obj>/]<attr>, <list>[, <base-case>[, <delim>])
  
  This function iteratively processes a list through a function, feeding
  the result of one step into the next step as %0, passing i...
explanation:
Function: fold([<obj>/]<attr>, <list>[, <base-case>[, <delim>])
  
  This function iteratively processes a list through a function, feeding
  the result of one step into the next step as %0, passing in the next element
  from the list as %1.
  
  If a base case is provided, it is used as the initial %0.  If not, the first
  list element is passed as %0 and the second is passed as %1, and subsequent
  iterations proceed normally.
  
  <delimiter> may be used to specify a delimiter other than space, but you
  must specify a base case in order to specify the delimiter.
 
  Examples:
    > &REP_NUM object=[%0][repeat(%1,%1)]
    > say fold(object/rep_num,1 2 3 4 5,->)
    You say "->122333444455555"
    > &ADD_NUMS object=add(%0,%1)
    > say fold(object/add_nums,1 2 3 4 5)
    You say "15"
  
  See Also: u(), iter(), map(), filter(), citer(), nsiter(), list(), inf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: RJUST() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for RJUST() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: rjust(<string>, <length>[, <fill> [,<cut>]])
            rj(<string>, <length>[, <fill> [,<cut>]])
 
  This function pads a string with leading <fill> characters, or with spaces
  if no fill...
explanation:
Function: rjust(<string>, <length>[, <fill> [,<cut>]])
            rj(<string>, <length>[, <fill> [,<cut>]])
 
  This function pads a string with leading <fill> characters, or with spaces
  if no fill character is given) ("right-justifies") so it is <length> long.
  If <string> is longer than <length>, the <string> is returned; it is not
  truncated. <fill> may be a string of over one character.
  
  If you wish to use ansified filler, use printf() instead.
  
  You may specify an optional 'cut' argument to rjust() to mimic rjc() 
  
  This function is UTF8 aware.
  
  Examples:
    > say -[rjust(foo,6)]-
    You say "-   foo-"
    > say %r0[rjust(foo,6)]7%r01234567
    You say "
    0   foo7
    01234567"
    > say =[rjust(bar,5,.)]=
    You say "=..bar="
  
  Alternate:
    > say =[printf($:.:5s,bar)]=       (The default justification is right)
    You say "=..bar="
  
  See Also: rjc(), ljust(), ljc(), strlen(), printf(), wrap(), template()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

  This function pads a string with leading blanks to right justify the 
  <string> within a field of <length> characters.  I...
explanation:
Function: rjc(<string>, <length> [,<fill>])     'Right Justify and Cut'
   
  This function pads a string with leading blanks to right justify the 
  <string> within a field of <length> characters.  If <string> is longer 
  than <length> it will be cut to fit within a field of <length> characters.
  You may specify an optional fill character.
  
  If you wish to use ansified filler, use printf() instead.
  
  This function is UTF8 aware.
   
  Examples:
    > say -[rjc(foo,6)]-
    You say "-   foo-"
    > say -[rjc(this is foo,6)]-
    You say "-this i-"
   
  See Also: rjust(), ljc(), ljust(), printf(), wrap(), template()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: STRDISTANCE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for STRDISTANCE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: strdistance(<string1>, <string2> [,<type> [,<damareu match>]])
  
  This function will calculate the levenshtein distance between two strings.
  This basically is the value calculated by the...
explanation:
Function: strdistance(<string1>, <string2> [,<type> [,<damareu match>]])
  
  This function will calculate the levenshtein distance between two strings.
  This basically is the value calculated by the number of letters that differ
  between the two strings entered.  If either string fed to this function
  is null, it returns a -1.  You may specify the <type> of '1' to expressly
  require case insensitivity in the matching.  The default behavior is case
  sensitivity.  The optional forth argument enables damareu style matching
  which considers the transposing of characters a single difference instead of
  two.
  
  Examples:
    > say [strdistance(this,thiz)]
    You say "1"
    > say [strdistance(this,This)]
    You say "1"
    > say [strdistance(this,This,1)]
    You say "0"
    > say [strdistance(the,teh)]
    You say "2"
    > say [strdistance(the,teh,,1)]
    You say "1"
  
  See Also: comp()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: BITTYPE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for BITTYPE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: bittype(<object> [,<type>])
 
  Returns a number from the following table based on the owner of <object>.
  You may specify a <type> of '1' to enforce wiz-inheritance checks on
  the target ...
explanation:
Function: bittype(<object> [,<type>])
 
  Returns a number from the following table based on the owner of <object>.
  You may specify a <type> of '1' to enforce wiz-inheritance checks on
  the target <object> otherwise the default of '0' is applied which just
  checks ownership.
  
  The following permission levels are shown:
    God (#1)                 7
    Super-Royalty/Immortal   6
    Royalty/Wizard           5
    Councilor                4
    Architect                3
    Guildmaster              2
    Citizen (Normal Player)  1
    Wanderer/Guest           0
    ERROR                  #-1
 
  If a player has more than one bit flag set, their highest one takes
  precedence.
  
  See Also: FLAGS, GOD, IMMORTAL, ROYALTY, COUNCILOR, ARCHITECT, GUILDMASTER,
            GUEST, WANDERER

title: R() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for R() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: r(<number>|<label>)
   
  The r() function is used to access "local registers", and returns
  the contents of the specified register. There are ten such registers,
  numbered 0 through 9.  T...
explanation:
Function: r(<number>|<label>)
   
  The r() function is used to access "local registers", and returns
  the contents of the specified register. There are ten such registers,
  numbered 0 through 9.  The local registers are normally cleared at the
  start of each command, but are preserved across the commands that compose
  an actionlist, as well as commands that directly trigger actionlists, such
  as @switch, @trigger, and @dolist.  A macro for r() is also %q that some
  people prefer.  Example:  r(0) would be the same as %q0
  
  If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well.
  Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage.
  
  You may substitute <number> for <label> if you have one assigned for the
  register.  For %q to understand labels, you must use %q<label>.  The <>'s
  are required.
   
  Example:
    > say [setq(0,testing)][r(0)]
    You say "testing"
    > say [setq(0,testing,bob)][setq(bob,testing2)][r(bob)]
    You say "testing2"
    > say [setq(0,testing,bob)][setq(bob,testing2)]%q<bob>
    You say "testing2"
   
  See Also: setq(), setr(), setrm(), setqm(), nameqm(), nameq(), inc(), dec()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: XINC() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for XINC() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @list options system
explanation:
Function: xinc(<number> [,<key>])
  
  INC() and XINC() may be reversed.  to check if they are, Please reference:  
                           @list options system  
  
  The xinc() function is used to increment the number passed into it.
  Any number passed into it is automatically incremented by one.
  
  If <key> is 1, it does advanced increments.  It then will take the number
  at the end of the string and increment, or if the string is a hexidecimal
  code starting with '0x' or '0X' it will increment the hex number. 
  
  Example:
    > say xinc(5)
    You say "6"
    > say xinc(-5)
    You say "-4"
    > say xinc(test123,1)
    You say "test124"
    > say xinc(0xfa,1)
    You say "0xfb"
  
  See Also: xdec(), inc(), dec(), add(), sub()
  
  Note:  Check @list options for the line 'Mux Formatted Inc() and Dec()'. If
         this is enabled, the functionality of inc() and dec() are swapped
         with xinc() and xdec() for MUX/Tiny style support.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: INC() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for INC() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @list options system
explanation:
Function: inc(<number>)
  
  INC() and XINC() may be reversed.  to check if they are, Please reference:  
                           @list options system  
  
  The inc() function is used to increment numerical values in local registers.
  The valid registers are 0-9, and a-z.  You may also use setq labels.
  If the value in the register is a string, it will return the string without
  any changes.
  
  Example:
    > say [setq(0,10)] 1: [r(0)] [inc(0)] 2: [r(0)]
    You say " 1: 10  2: 11"
    > say [setq(0,The)] 1: [r(0)] [inc(0)] 2: [r(0)]
    You say " 1: The #-1 GLOBAL REGISTER NOT AN INTEGER 2: The
  
  See Also: dec(), xdec(), xinc(), setq(), setr(), setrm(), r(), setqm()
  
  Note:  Check @list options for the line 'Mux Formatted Inc() and Dec()'. If
         this is enabled, the functionality of inc() and dec() are swapped
         with xinc() and xdec() for MUX/Tiny style support.
