title: NAMEQ() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for NAMEQ() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: nameq([<register or label> [,<new label> [,<key>]]])
  
  The nameq() function has multiple features.  It can return registers
  that match given conditions, or label or re-label registers.
...
explanation:
Function: nameq([<register or label> [,<new label> [,<key>]]])
  
  The nameq() function has multiple features.  It can return registers
  that match given conditions, or label or re-label registers.
  
  You may use any name of 31 characters or less for the label.  You may 
  use any character, including spaces.  The labels have to be unique, 
  and will return an error for a label already inn use.  If you do not 
  specify a new label, it will display the existing label (if one exists) 
  for that register.
  
  The following keys exist:
    1 - <new label> MUST be null/empty, and this will return the 
        register (0-9 or a-z) assigned to the specified label.
    2 - Like '1' above, but will show numerical value of a-z
        This requires setq_nums enabled.
  
  Option 1 and 2 for the key will return the register if given a label,
  or the label (or nothing if no label exists) if given a register.
  
  Special keys exist where <register or label> is a wildcard match.
    l/L - show all registers that currently have labels.
          -- Wildcards match label.
    v/V - show all registers that currently contain contents.
          -- wildcards match register contents.
    n/N - show all registers  that currenty contain contents.
          -- wildcards match register reference numbers.
    u/U - show all registers that have labels or contents
          -- wildcards match register contents or label.
    b/B - show all registers that have labels and contents
          -- wildcards match register contents or label.
    f/F - show all registers that have labels and contents
          -- wildcards match register reference numbers or label.
    a/A - show all registers that have labels and contents
          -- wildcards match register reference numbers, contents, or label.
  
  Note: Using a capital letter will display a-z instead of 10-36 for register.
  
  { see 'help nameq2 for examples }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: NAMEQ2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for NAMEQ2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: nameq([<register or label> [,<new label> [,<key>]]])
  
  Examples:
    > say nameq()
      36
    > say [setq(0,Test 1 2 3)][r(0)]
      You say "Test 1 2 3"
    > say [setq(0,Test 1 2 3)][...
explanation:
Function: nameq([<register or label> [,<new label> [,<key>]]])
  
  Examples:
    > say nameq()
      36
    > say [setq(0,Test 1 2 3)][r(0)]
      You say "Test 1 2 3"
    > say [setq(0,Test 1 2 3)][nameq(0,Foo Foo)][r(Foo Foo)]
      You say "Test 1 2 3"
    > say [setq(0,Test 1 2 3)][nameq(0,Foo Foo)][nameq(0)]
      You say "Foo Foo"
    > say [setq(0,Test 1 2 3)][nameq(0,Foo Foo)][nameq(Foo Foo,,1)]
      You say "0"
    > say [setq(a,store,foo)][nameq(foo,,1)]
      You say "a"
    > say [setq(a,store,foo)][nameq(foo,,2)]  (this assumes setq_nums enabled)
      You say "10"
    > say [setq(0,foo)][setq(a,,bar)][nameq(*,,U)]
      You say "0 a"
    > say [setq(0,foo)][setq(a,,bar)][nameq(*,,V)]
      You say "0"
    > say [setq(0,foo)][setq(a,,bar)][nameq(*,,L)]
      You say "a"
    > say [setq(0,foo)][setq(a,,bar)][nameq(*,,l)]
      You say "10"
  
  Note: registers go from 0-9 then a-z where a-z would be assigned 11-36. 
  
  See Also: nameqm(), setq(), setr(), setrm(), r(), setqm(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: NAMEQM() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for NAMEQM() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: nameqm(<register1>, <label1>, ..., <registerN>, <labelN>)
  
  This function works like nameq() in how it sets labels to registers, but
  it allows setting more than one register at once.
  ...
explanation:
Function: nameqm(<register1>, <label1>, ..., <registerN>, <labelN>)
  
  This function works like nameq() in how it sets labels to registers, but
  it allows setting more than one register at once.
  
  This function follows all rules and guidelines that nameq() would follow
  when setting labels on registers.
  
  As with nameq(), any label previously defined can not be used on a register.
  
  This function requires an even number of arguments.
  
  Examples:
    > say [setqm(0,val1,1,val2)][nameqm(0,foolabel,1,barlabel)]%q<foolabel>
    You say "val1"
  
  See Also: nameq(), setqm(), setq(), setr(), setrm(), r(), localize(), 
            privatize()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SETQM() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETQM() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: setqm(<register1>, <string1>, ..., <registerN>, <stringN>)
            setqm(R1>L1, <string1>, ...,RN>LN, <stringN>)
  
  This function works like setq() in how it sets registers, but it all...
explanation:
Function: setqm(<register1>, <string1>, ..., <registerN>, <stringN>)
            setqm(R1>L1, <string1>, ...,RN>LN, <stringN>)
  
  This function works like setq() in how it sets registers, but it allows
  setting more than one register at once.
  
  This function follows all rules and guidelines that setq() would follow
  when setting registers and/or labels. 
  
  This function honors the SETQLABEL @totem and all standard restrictions.
  
  This function will set registers in order, meaning you can reference a
  previously set register in the chain.
  
  If <register> is in the form R1>L1 then R1 is the register and
  L1 will be the label.  This is useful to assign the register and
  label in a single argument.
  
  Examples:
    > say [setqm(0,foo,1,bar,2,%q0%q1baz)]%q2
      foobarbaz
    > say [setqm(label1,moo,label2,cow)]%q<label1> goes the %q<label2>.
      moo goes the cow.
  Examples --------- (registers + labels)
    > say [setqm(a>label1,moo,5>label2,cow)]%q<a> goes the %q<5>
      moo goes the cow.
    > say [setqm(a>label1,moo,5>label2,cow)]%q<label1> goes the %q<label2>
      moo goes the cow.
  
  See Also: setq(), setr(), setrm(), r(), nameqm(), nameq(), localize(), 
            privatize()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SETQ() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETQ() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @list options to see if it was.
explanation:
Function: setq(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq(<label>,<string>[,<label>)
            setq(!,<string>,<label>)
            setq(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setq(<label|register>,<string>)
            setq(+,<string>,<label>)
            setq(!,<string>,<label>)
 
  The setq() function is used to copy strings into local registers.
  It returns a null string; it is a purely "side effect" function.
  
  There are ten local registers, numbered 0 through 9. They are cleared
  at the start of each command. They are most useful for storing complex
  function evaluations which are used repeatedly within a single command.
  The local registers may be read via the r() function, and a common use
  of setq()/r() is to temporarily store the result of a complex evaluation
  whose result is needed more than once.
 
  setq() can be used to improve the readability of MUSH code, as well as to
  cut down the amount of time needed to do complex evaluations.
  
  If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well.
  Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage.
  
  Compiletime may also switch this functionality with SETQ_OLD().  Check
  @list options to see if it was.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first  unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.
  
  Note: if setq_nums is enabled, you may specify numerical registers 
        greater than 9 up to the total number of registers defined.
  
  If the target has SETQLABEL enabled or the config parameter is set,
  then any register that has a label must have the label to set new values.
   
  Example:
    > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()].
    > say [setq(0,u(TEST))]'[r(0)]' has length [strlen(r(0))].
      You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45."
    > say [setq(0,u(TEST),test)][setq(test,Test: [u(test)])][r(0)]
      You say "Test: Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993"
  
  See Also: setqm(), setr(), setr_old(), setq_old(), r(), nameq(), inc(), dec(), 
            nameqm(),setrm(),  setqmatch(), SETQ_TEMPLATE, REGISTERS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SETQ_OLD() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETQ_OLD() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: setq_old(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq_old(<label>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq_old(!,<string>,<label>)
            setq_old(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Co...
explanation:
Function: setq_old(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq_old(<label>,<string>[,<label>])
            setq_old(!,<string>,<label>)
            setq_old(+,<string>,<label>)
  
      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setq_old(<label|register>,<string>)
            setq_old(+,<string>,<label>)
            setq_old(!,<string>,<label>)
  
  This functions exactly like setq(), except it is using the old MUSH 
  method of evaluation.  This tends to be less abrasive on braces and
  brackets.
  
  Please check @list options to see if SETQ_OLD and SETQ are switched
  at compiletime.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.
  
  Note: if setq_nums is enabled, you may specify numerical registers 
        greater than 9 up to the total number of registers defined.
  
  If the target has SETQLABEL enabled or the config parameter is set,
  then any register that has a label must have the label to set new values.
  
  Example:
    > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()].
    > say [setq_old(0,u(TEST))]'[r(0)]' has length [strlen(r(0))].
      You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45."
    > say [setq_old(0,u(TEST),test)][setq(test,Test: [u(test)])][r(0)]
      You say "Test: Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993"
  
  See Also: setqm(), setr(), setr_old(), setq_old(), r(), nameq(), inc(), dec(), 
            nameqm(), setrm(), setqmatch(), SETQ_TEMPLATE, REGISTERS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SETQMATCH() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETQMATCH() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: setqmatch(<string>, <pattern>[,delim])
 
  The setqmatch() function tries to match <pattern> against <string>. If it
  succeeds, it returns 1 and puts the text that matched each wildcard (up...
explanation:
Function: setqmatch(<string>, <pattern>[,delim])
 
  The setqmatch() function tries to match <pattern> against <string>. If it
  succeeds, it returns 1 and puts the text that matched each wildcard (up to
  ten) into successive setq registers. The first wildcard's match goes into
  register 0, the second into register 1, etc.
 
  (If it reaches '10' and there's more, dump the remaining into
   '10' if '10' is a '*' wildcard and not a '?' wildcard)
 
  If it fails, it returns 0.  If optional delimiter of 'n' is specified,
  then it returns nothing for failures or successes.  Default is 'y' for
  returning values.
  
  If the target has SETQLABEL enabled or the config parameter is set,
  then any register that has a label must have the label to set new values.
 
  Example:
    > say setqmatch(This is a test, *test) -- [r(0)]
    You say "1 -- This is a "
    > say setqmatch(open the door hal, open * ???) -- [r(0)] -- [r(2)]
    You say "1 -- the door -- a"
    > say setqmatch(kow, wok)
    You say "0"
    > say setqmatch(kow, wok, n)
    You say ""
  
  See Also: setqm(), listmatch(), match(), totmatch(), wildmatch(), setq(), 
            REGISTERS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SETQ_TEMPLATES - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETQ_TEMPLATES command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
You can specify 'templates' for setq registers to automatically have 
  pre-defined labels for each individual object.  This is done by setting
  a string in the attribute 'SETQ_TEMPLATE' on the objec...
explanation:
You can specify 'templates' for setq registers to automatically have 
  pre-defined labels for each individual object.  This is done by setting
  a string in the attribute 'SETQ_TEMPLATE' on the object.  The attribute
  should be in the format:  <register>:<string>
  
  So an example would be:   0:foobar 1:xyzzy q:myqreg
  
  This would set a template on an object where it would preassign the
  label 'foobar' to register 0, 'xyzzy' to register 1, and 'myqreg' to
  register q.
  
  Note:  These are only useful for the immediate calling $commands.
  They are not transversed through u() functions, @triggers, or other
  action based events.
  
  You may redefine these labels as you would normally with nameq(), 
  setq(), or setr().
  
  If the target has SETQLABEL enabled or the config parameter is set,
  then any register that has a label must have the label to set new values.
  
  Registers that are invalid and out of range will be ignored.
    
  See Also: nameqm(), nameq(), setq(), setr(), setrm(), setqm(), r(), 
            REGISTERS
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: SETR() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETR() command/function in RhostMUSH
code: @list options to see if it was.
explanation:
Function: setr(<register>,<string>[,<label>])
            setr(<label>,<string>[,<label>])
            setr(!,<string>,<label>)

      -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) 
            setr(<label|register>,<string>)

  The setr() function is used to copy strings into local registers.
  Unlike setq(), it returns its <string> argument.
  In all other respects it is identical to setq().
  
  If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well.
  Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage.
  
  Compiletime may also switch this functionality with SETR_OLD().  Check
  @list options to see if it was.
  
  You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call
  with r().  Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less.
  You may then specify the label instead of the <number>.  Using '!' for the
  number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next
  available register automatically.  '+' will use the first unnamed AND
  unused register.  '!' just uses the first unnamed register.
  
  If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the
  register set and not a label assigned.
  
  Note: if setq_nums is enabled, you may specify numerical registers 
        greater than 9 up to the total number of registers defined.
  
  If the target has SETQLABEL enabled or the config parameter is set,
  then any register that has a label must have the label to set new values.
   
  Example: 
    > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()].
    > say '[setr(0,u(TEST))]' has length [strlen(r(0))].
      You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45."

title: SETRM() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for SETRM() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: setrm(<register1>, <string1>,...,<registerN>, <stringN> [,<delim>])
            setrm(R1>L1, <string1>, ...,RN>LN, <stringN> [,<delim>])
  
  This function works like setr() in how it sets a...
explanation:
Function: setrm(<register1>, <string1>,...,<registerN>, <stringN> [,<delim>])
            setrm(R1>L1, <string1>, ...,RN>LN, <stringN> [,<delim>])
  
  This function works like setr() in how it sets and returns registers, but it 
  allows setting more than one register at once.
  
  You may specify an optional delimiter as the last argument of a 
  reister/string pair.  For a delimiter to work an odd number of arguments
  must be passed to the function.  The delimeter may be null/empty.
  
  The default delimiter if not specified is a space.
  
  This function follows all rules and guidelines that setr() would follow
  when setting registers and/or labels. 
  
  This function honors the SETQLABEL @totem and all standard restrictions.
  
  This function will set registers in order, meaning you can reference a
  previously set register in the chain.
  
  If <register> is in the form R1>L1 then R1 is the register and
  L1 will be the label.  This is useful to assign the register and
  label in a single argument.
  
  Note: examples expect penn_setq to be enabled.
  
  Examples: 
    > say [setrm(0,foo,1,bar,2,%q0%q1baz,null())] Reg:%q2
      You say "foobarfoobarbaz Reg:foobarbaz"
    > say [setrm(0,foo,1,bar,2,%q0%q1baz)] Reg:%q2
      You say "foo bar foobarbaz Reg:foobarbaz"
      Reg:foobarbaz
    > say [setqm(label1,moo,label2,cow,)] Val:%q<label1> goes the %q<label2>.
      You say "moocow Val:moo goes the cow.
  Examples --------- (registers + labels)
    > say [setrm(a>label1,moo,5>label2,cow)]//%q<a> goes the %q<5>
      moo cow//moo goes the cow.
    > say [setrm(a>label1,moo,5>label2,cow,++)]//%q<label1> goes the %q<label2>
      moo++cow//moo goes the cow.
  
  See Also: setq(), setr(), setrm(), r(), nameqm(), nameq(), localize(), 
            privatize()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TRIGGER() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TRIGGER() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
@list options to see if this function has been enabled and is allowed.
@trigger.  This takes all normal permissions and executions.
explanation:
Function: trigger(<#obj/attr> [,<arg1>, <arg2>, ..., <argN>])
  
  This function requires the SIDEFX flag.  
  
  @list options to see if this function has been enabled and is allowed.
  
  This function is the functional sideeffect of the @trigger command.  This
  function does not execute in-line.  This function, as a side-effect, will
  cause the command(s) triggered to queue as if it was done via normal
  @trigger.  This takes all normal permissions and executions.
  
  If you do not have access to <#obj/attr> it will fail to trigger.
  If you do not have access to the trigger command it will fail to trigger.
  If you do not have funds to queue commands it will fail to trigger.
  
  This follows the same guidelines as @trigger.
  
  Example:
    > @va me=think boo to %0
    Set.
    > think trigger(me/va,bob)
    boo to bob
  
  See Also: @trigger, u()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: TRIM() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for TRIM() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: trim(<string> [,<trim style> [,<trim character(s)>]])
 
  This function will trim trailing and/or lead characters on the string
  that you specify.  <trim character> specifies the character ...
explanation:
Function: trim(<string> [,<trim style> [,<trim character(s)>]])
 
  This function will trim trailing and/or lead characters on the string
  that you specify.  <trim character> specifies the character to trim (default
  is space), and <trim style> tells the kind of trimming to perform (default
  is trim both sides of the string).  You may specify more than one character
  for trimming.
 
  The following values for <trim style> are recognized:
      'b' :   Trim both ends of the string (default)
      'l' :   Trim the left end of the string.
      'r' :   Trim the right end of the string.
  Note: anything else specified for <trim style> will trim both sides.
 
  Example:
    > say trim(;;;Wacka;;;,,;)
    You say "Wacka"
    > say trim(%b%b%b Polly Parrot %b%b%b%b,r)
    You say "    Polly Parrot"
    > say trim(---Trim Rules!---,l,-)
    You say "Trim Rules!---"
  
  See Also: center(), ljust(), rjust(), ljc(), rjc(), s(), printf()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CENTER() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CENTER() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: center(<string>,<width>[,<fill>])
 
  This function will center a string in a string <width> characters wide,
  using <fil> characters for padding on either end of the string for
  centering...
explanation:
Function: center(<string>,<width>[,<fill>])
 
  This function will center a string in a string <width> characters wide,
  using <fil> characters for padding on either end of the string for
  centering.  If no fill character is specified then a space is used.
  If <string> is longer than <width> characters, the string is returned
  unmodified.  The <fill> may contain more than one character.
  
  If you wish to use ansified filler, use printf() instead.
  
  This function is UTF8 aware.
   
  Example:
    > say center(a,5,-)
    You say "--a--"
    > say center(*BAMF*,15)
    You say "    *BAMF*     "
  
  Alternate:
    > say printf($:-:^5s,a)            (the '^' specifies center justify)
    You say "--a--"
  
  See Also: ljust(), rjust(), ljc(), rjc(), printf(), template()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: INSERT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for INSERT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: insert(<list>, <pos> [..<posN>], <word>[[,<sep>] [,<osep>]], <key>)
   
  This function inserts a word into <list> so that the word becomes the
  <pos>'th element of the list, and all subseq...
explanation:
Function: insert(<list>, <pos> [..<posN>], <word>[[,<sep>] [,<osep>]], <key>)
   
  This function inserts a word into <list> so that the word becomes the
  <pos>'th element of the list, and all subsequent list elements are moved
  down.  This means that it appears between the <pos-1>'th and <pos>'th
  elements of the original list.  This function may be used to append or
  prepend a word to a list.  You may specify more than one position.
   
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  The <pos> fields may be negative to take the argument from the right
  instead of the left.
  
  You may specify a separate <sep> seperator or it assumes space if not
  provided.  
  
  The <osep> output delimiter may be more than one character, and if 
  enabled, '@@' can be used as another method for a null.  You may specify 
  an empty <osep> as well.
  
  The following <key>s exist for insert:
    0 - (default) do normal insert
    1 - Append the text to the position(s)
    2 - Prepend the text to the position(s)
    3 - Box in the position(s) with the text (prepend and append)
    4 - Transpose box in the position(s) with the text (prepend and append)
  
{ see 'help insert2' for examples }

explanation:
(CONTINUED)
  Function: insert(<list>,<pos> [..<posN>],<word>[[,<sep>][,<osep>][,<key>]])
  
  Note: if you leave the <osep> output seperator null when using <key>, it 
        assumes you want an empty (null) output seperator.  To have it use 
        the same seperator explicitly specify the <osep> if you plan to 
        use <key>.  You only need to explicitly set <osep> if you use <key>
        or if you plan to use a different output seperator.
  
  Examples:
    > say insert(This is a test, 4, new)
    You say "This is a new test"
    > say insert(Yet@Another@List, 3, Funky, @)
    You say "Yet@Another@Funky@List"
    > say insert(1|2|3,2,>>,|,|,1)
    You say "1|2>>|3"
    > say insert(1|2|3,2,>>,|,|,2)
    You say "1|>>2|3"
    > say insert(1|2|3,2,>>,|,|,3)
    You say "1|>>2>>|3"
    > say insert(1|2|3,2,>>,|,|,4)          (this transposes the > character)
    You say "1|>>2<<|3"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), ldelete(), replace(), iindex(), aindex(),
            rindex()

Function: ipv4math(<site ip>)

explanation:
Function: ipv4math(<site ip>)
  
  This function will convert the input into the expected output.  It
  auto-recognizes the input to the type you specify.
  
  Invalid formats fed to ipv4math() will error out with a message.
  
  Formats allowed for <site ip>
    1.  123456789     -- decimal format for an IPv4 address.
    2.  8.8.8.8       -- IPv4 address format.
  
  Examples:
    > say ipv4math(8.8.8.8)            (convert to decimal format)
    You say "134744072"            
    > say ipv4math(134744072)          (convert to IPv4 format)
    You say "8.8.8.8"
  
  See Also: lastsite
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: LREPLACE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for LREPLACE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: lreplace(<list>, <pos>, <string>[, <delim> [,<key>]])
  
  This function replaces the words in the list <list> starting at the
  position <pos> and continuing to overwrite word for word till...
explanation:
Function: lreplace(<list>, <pos>, <string>[, <delim> [,<key>]])
  
  This function replaces the words in the list <list> starting at the
  position <pos> and continuing to overwrite word for word till the
  end of <string>.  If <string> is longer than what would be replaced,
  the rest of the <string> is automatically appended to the end of
  <list>.  You may specify optional delimiters instead of the default
  space.  You may specify more than one position.
  
  If you specify a <key> of 1, then null entries will be recognized in lists.
  
  Examples:
    > say lreplace(this is a test,3,a spotted giraffe)
    You say "this is a spotted giraffe"
    > say lreplace(this@is@a@test,2,was@another,@)
    You say "this@was@another@test"
    > say lreplace(a|b|c|d,2,|X,|)         -- null entries not recognized
    You say "a||X|c|d"
    > say lreplace(a|b|c|d,2,|X,|,1)       -- null entries recognized
    You say "a||X|d"
  
  See Also: replace(), rindex(), ldelete(), ldelete(), delete()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: REPLACE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for REPLACE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: replace(<list>, <pos> [<pos2>..<posN>], <word>[[,<sep>] [,<osep>]])
   
  This function inserts a word into <list> so that the word becomes the
  <pos>'th element of the list, and the word p...
explanation:
Function: replace(<list>, <pos> [<pos2>..<posN>], <word>[[,<sep>] [,<osep>]])
   
  This function inserts a word into <list> so that the word becomes the
  <pos>'th element of the list, and the word previously in that position
  is removed.  This means that it appears between the <pos-1>'th and
  <pos+1>'th elements of the original list, replacing the word at that
  position.  This function may not be used to append a word to a list.
  You may specify more than one position.
   
  The <pos> fields may be negative to take the argument from the right
  instead of the left.
  
  You may specify a separate <sep> seperator or it assumes space if not
  provided.  
  
  The <osep> output delimiter may be more than one character, and if 
  enabled, '@@' can be used as another method for a null.  You may specify 
  an empty <osep> as well.
   
  Examples:
    > say replace(This is a test, 4, quiz)
    You say "This is a quiz"
    > say replace(Yet@Another@Mundane@List, 3, Funky, @)
    You say "Yet@Another@Funky@List"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), insert(), ldelete(), delete(), rindex(),
            medit(), edit()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: ldelete(<list>, <pos> [<pos2>..<posN>] [[,<sep>] [,<osep>]])
 
  This function removes a word from <list> by position.
  
  <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space.
  
  The <pos> fields may be negative to take the argument from the right
  instead of the left.
  
  You may specify a separate <sep> seperator or it assumes space if not
  provided.  
  
  The <osep> output delimiter may be more than one character, and if 
  enabled, '@@' can be used as another method for a null.  You may specify 
  an empty <osep> as well.
   
  Examples:
    > say ldelete(This is not a test, 3)
    You say "This is a test"
    > say ldelete(Yet@Another@Mundane@List, 3, @)
    You say "Yet@Another@List"
  
  See Also: extract(), extractword(), insert(), replace(), rindex()

explanation:
Function: isalpha(<string>)
  
  This function matches on the FIRST CHARACTER of the string and checks
  if it's an alpha character (a-z or A-Z).  if it is, then it returns '1'.
  If not, it returns a '0'.
  
  Examples:
    > say isalpha(a1238548385**|%*) 
    You say "1"
    > say isalpha(0)
    You say "0"
 
  See Also: isdbref(), isalnum(), ispunct(), isxdigit(), isdigit(), isspace(),
            istag(), isword(), isunicode(), isutf8(), isobjid()

Function: isalnum(<string>)
  
  This function matches on the FIRST CHARACTER of the string and checks
  if it's an alphanumerical character (0-9, a-z, or A-Z).  If it is, then
  it returns '1'.  Else it returns a '0'.
  
  Examples:
    > say isalnum(?)
    You say "0"
    > say isalnum(9********)
    You say "1"

explanation:
function: isint(<string>)
  
  This function matches the returned string to see if it is a valid
  integer.  A valid integer is considered a string that optionally
  starts with a + or a - and contains nothing but numbers.
  
  Examples:
    > say isint(+123)
    You say "1"
    > say isint(-123)
    You say "1"
    > say isint(123)
    You say "1"
    > say isint(123.456)
    You say "0"
  
  See Also: isdbref(), isalpha(), isalnum(), isxdigit(), ispunct(), isspace(),
            isnum(), istag(), isword(), isunicode(), isutf8(), isdigit(), 
            isobjid()

explanation:
Function: istag(<string>)
  
  This function will return 1 if the string passed to it is a valid tag.
  To be a valid tag it must be defined in the @tag subsystem and must begin
  with a '#'.  If the object fails these conditions, then a 0 is returned.
  
  Example:
     > say istag(#-1)
     You say "0"
     > say isdtag(#sirlancelot)
     You say "1"
     > say isdbref(#sirnotappearinginthismovie)
     You say "0"
  
  See Also: @ltag, isspace(), isalpha(), isalnum(), isdigit(), isxdigit(), 
            ispunct(), isdbref(), isword(), isunicode(), isutf8(), isobjid()
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

explanation:
Function: isdbref(<string>)
 
  This function will return 1 if the string passed to it is a valid dbref.
  To be a valid dbref the string must begin with '#' and be followed by an
  integer.  Also, the dbref must exist in the current database as a valid
  object.  If the object fails either of these criteria, then a 0 is
  returned.
 
  Example:
     > say isdbref(#-1)
     You say "0"
     > say isdbref(#1)
     You say "1"
     > say isdbref(This is not a dbref)
     You say "0"
  
  See Also: isspace(), isalpha(), isalnum(), isdigit(), isxdigit(), ispunct(),
            istag(), isword(), isunicode(), isutf8(), isobjid()

explanation:
Function: isobjid(<string>)
  
  This function will return 1 if the string passed to it is a valid objid.
  To be a valid objid the string must begin with '#' and be followed by an
  integer, contain a ':' and have a valid timestamp.  Ergo, it must be a
  valid objid.  Also, the objid must exist in the current database as a valid
  object.  If the object fails either of these criteria, then a 0 is
  returned.
 
  Example:
     > say objid(#1)
     You say "#1:841303473"
     > say isobjid(#-1)
     You say "0"
     > say isobjid(#1)
     You say "0"
     > say isobjid(#1:841303473)
     You say "1"
     > say isobjid(#1:841303472)
     You say "0"
  
  See Also: isspace(), isalpha(), isalnum(), isdigit(), isxdigit(), ispunct(),
            istag(), isword(), isunicode(), isutf8(), isdbref()

Function: isunicode(<string>)
  
  This function will return '1' if the argument is a valid unicode word.  A 
  valid unicode word is defined as a string that is alpha, contains a
   hyphen (-) char, contains an underscore (_) char, or contains unicode.
  
  Example:
    > say isunicode(testing)
    You say "1"
    > say isunicode(testing0)
    You say "0"
    > say isunicode(testing-me_%<u2222>)
    You say "1"

title: ANSI() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ANSI() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: ansi(<codes>,<string>[,<codes>,<string>,...,<codes>,<string>])
            ansi(FG/BG,<string>[,<codes>,string>,...,FG/BG,<string>])
   
  *NOTE* : You MUST have both the ANSI and ANSICOLOR ...
explanation:
Function: ansi(<codes>,<string>[,<codes>,<string>,...,<codes>,<string>])
            ansi(FG/BG,<string>[,<codes>,string>,...,FG/BG,<string>])
   
  *NOTE* : You MUST have both the ANSI and ANSICOLOR flags set to see color!
           ANSI-NORMAL (n) has priority in any ansi string!
  
  This allows you to highlight a string using ANSI terminal effects. The
  string is terminated with a "return to normal" code, and the codes are
  utilized in the order they are specified. You may specify multiple
  arguments as shown to ansi().  The 16 color codes are:
   
    f - flash                           i - inverse
    h - hilite                          n - normal
    u - underscore
   
    x - black foreground                X - black background
    r - red foreground                  R - red background
    g - green foreground                G - green background
    y - yellow foreground               Y - yellow background
    b - blue foreground                 B - blue background
    m - magenta foreground              M - magenta background
    c - cyan foreground                 C - cyan background
    w - white foreground                W - white background
  
  For example, "ansi(fc, Test)" would hilight "Test" in flashing cyan.
  
  See: 'XTERMCOLOR LIST' for the 256 color list.
  
{ 'help ansi encoding' for encoding used in %c/%x substitutions }
{ 'help ansi2' for more -- The 256 Color Support }
{ 'help ansi quirks' for work arounds on weird ansi problems }
{ 'help ansi usage' on how to use ansi }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ANSI2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ANSI2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code: +color      -- example: ansi(+pink,string) for the 256 foreground 'pink'.
explanation:
Function: ansi(<codes>,<string>)   -- CONTINUED
            ansi(<FG>/<BG>,<string>) -- CONTINUED
  
  For 256 color support, we offer multiple methods to handle it.  This needs
  the XTERMCOLOR flag to be set in addition to the normal ANSI and ANSICOLOR.
  
  First, you may specify the color with the + prefix.  This does not require 
  the '/' in the second option unless you intend to use background  colors.
  
  For 256 Color support we offer for the <FG> and <BG> options:
    0x<hex>     -- example: ansi(0xC4/,string) for 256 color foreground support
                            ansi(/0xC4,string) for 256 color background support
                            ansi(0xC4/0xC1,string) for FG and BG support
                   This does NOT require / for FG colors, but does for BG.
    0-255       -- example: ansi(196/,string) instead of '0xC4' for decimal.
                   This does NOT require / for FG colors, but does for BG.
    +color      -- example: ansi(+pink,string) for the 256 foreground 'pink'.
                   This does NOT require / for FG colors, but does for BG.
    #FFFFFF     -- example: ansi(#FF0000,string) to specify the RGB values.
                   This does NOT require / for FG colors, but does for BG.
    <#FFFFFF>   -- example: ansi(<#FF0000>,string) to specify the RGB values.
                   This does NOT require / for FG colors, but does for BG.
    <R G B>     -- example: ansi(<255 0 0>,string) to specify the RGB values.
                   This does NOT require / for FG colors, but does for BG.
    /           -- foreground/background indicator -- required where mentioned.
   
  You may mix and match the methods of the 256 color support.  As ansi() 
  supports multiple arguments, you may also use multiple types in different
  arguments.
  
  You may also use the %c/%x substitution (depending what is configured) to
  display 256 colors by using the '0x##' for foreground and '0X##' for 
  background.  Example: %c0xc4%c0X20whee%cn.  This allows you to even mix
  and match different ansi types like: %c0xc4%c0X20%cuwhee%cn to underline.
  0x## is foreground, and 0X## is background when using percent substitutions.
     
{ 'help ansi3' for more -- about XTERMCOLOR and ANSI examples }
{ 'help ansi quirks' for work arounds on weird ansi problems}
{ 'help ansi usage' on how to use ansi}
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: ANSI3 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for ANSI3 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: ansi(<codes>,<string>)   -- CONTINUED
            ansi(<FG>/<BG>,<string>) -- CONTINUED
  
  You may also use the XTERM color support if your client supports it.
  You must set the XTERMCOLO...
explanation:
Function: ansi(<codes>,<string>)   -- CONTINUED
            ansi(<FG>/<BG>,<string>) -- CONTINUED
  
  You may also use the XTERM color support if your client supports it.
  You must set the XTERMCOLOR flag to see the extended color set.
  
  See XTERMCOLOR LIST for the extended color list and codes used for it.
  
  hex like ansi(0xca/0xab,string).  ansi(+colorname/+colorname) is allowed 
  for foreground and background.  Hex is case-insensitive.
  
  There is also a substitution for colors.  This is '%c' and works just
  as '%n' would for your name.  %crred%cn is red, %c0x01red%cn is also red.
  If you use %c substitutions, the 'x' after the '0' IS CASE SENSITIVE.  
  0x01 would be foreground, 0X01 would be background.
  
  Examples: 
    > say I like %cbblue %cnrocks and %crred %cnballs
    You say "I like <blue> rocks and <red> balls"
    > say I like [ansi(b,blue)] rocks and [ansi(r,red)] balls
    You say "I like <blue> rocks and <red> balls"
    > say I like [ansi(38/,skyblue)] rocks and [ansi(203/,indianred)] balls
    You say "I like <skyblue> rocks and <indianred> balls"
    > say I like [ansi(0x26/,skyblue)] [ansi(0xcB/,indianred)] ballons
    You say "I like <skyblue> <indianred> balls"
    > say I like [ansi(+skyblue,skyblue)] [ansi(+indianred,indianred)] balls
    You say "I like <skyblue> <indianred> balls" (note / not needed for +FG)
    > say I like [ansi(+skyblue/,skyblue)] [ansi(+indianred/,indianred)] balls
    You say "I like <skyblue> <indianred> balls"
  
  The words 'blue' and 'red' being their respected colors.  Any ansi
  sequence can be substituted using percent substitutions, and will
  continue till either the end of the line or until a normalization ansi 
  code is entered (the %cn).
   
{ 'help ansi4' for more -- Flags required and information }
{ 'help ansi quirks' for work arounds on weird ansi problems}
{ 'help ansi usage' on how to use ansi}

explanation:
Function: ansi(<codes>,<string>)   -- CONTINUED
            ansi(<FG>/<BG>,<string>) -- CONTINUED
  
  NOTE:  The ANSI flag is used to see base ansi sequences (flash,highlight,etc)
         The ANSICOLOR flag is used _with_ ANSI to see color.
         The XTERMCOLOR flag is used _with_ ANSICOLOR to see extended colors.
         You must have both of the first flags set to see ansi color.
         You must have all three flags to see extended colors.
         
  Keep in mind that the functionality of %c and %x may be reversed.  
  Check '@list options' on the server you are on to see if this has
  been reversed or not.
  
  See Also: ansi(), stripansi(), ANSI, ANSICOLOR, XTERMCOLOR, NO_FLASH, 
            SUBSTITUTIONS, XTERMCOLOR LIST, COLORS()

title: CLUSTER_ATTRCNT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_ATTRCNT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_attrcnt(<object>[/<pattern>] [,<key>])
  
  This function returns the total attributes in the given cluster.
  
  The following keys exist:
      0 - (default) - list attributes and ...
explanation:
Function: cluster_attrcnt(<object>[/<pattern>] [,<key>])
  
  This function returns the total attributes in the given cluster.
  
  The following keys exist:
      0 - (default) - list attributes and delete corrupted attributes.
      1 - list attributes and attempt to repair corrupted attributes.
      2 - list attributes but do not touch corrupted attributes.
      3 - remove any IS_LOCK on any attribute that is user-defined.
  
  If there is attribute corruption, the value returned will be '-1'.
  
  You may specify <pattern> as a wildcard pattern or if you start the
  <pattern> with a ^ character it will assume a regex pattern to match.
  
  Examples:
    > say cluster_attrcnt(cluster#1)
    You say "20192"
    > say words(cluster_lattr(cluster#1))	(this will hit the LBUF limit)
    You say "622"
    > say cluster_attrcnt(cluster#1/v*)         (globbing pattern)
    You say "192"
    > say cluster_attrcnt(cluster#1/^v.*$)      (regex pattern)
    You say "192"
    > say words(cluster_lattr(cluster#1/v*))
    You say "192"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(), 
            cluster_hasattr(), cluster_lattr(), cluster_regrep(),

title: CLUSTER_EDEFAULT() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_EDEFAULT() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_edefault(<obj>/<attr>,<default case>)
 
  This function returns the evaluated value of <obj>/<attr> for the cluster,
  as if retrieved via the cluster_get_eval() function, if the att...
explanation:
Function: cluster_edefault(<obj>/<attr>,<default case>)
 
  This function returns the evaluated value of <obj>/<attr> for the cluster,
  as if retrieved via the cluster_get_eval() function, if the attribute 
  exists and is readable by you. Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, 
  and returns that. The default case is only evaluated if the attribute
  does not exist or cannot be read.
 
  Example:
    > &TEST cluster#1=You have lost [rand(10)] marbles.
    > say cluster_edefault(cluster#1/Test,You have no marbles.)
    You say "You have lost 6 marbles."
    > &TEST me
    > say cluster_edefault(cluster#1/Test,You have no marbles.)
    You say "You have no marbles."
  
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),

Function: cluster_get(<object>/<attribute>)
 
  The get function fetches the specified attribute from the cluster object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
  a...
explanation:
Function: cluster_get(<object>/<attribute>)
 
  The get function fetches the specified attribute from the cluster object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
  attributes of objects near you, and public and visual attributes other
  than the description of players wherever they may be.  If the attribute is
  not present on cluster <object>, it will continue through every object
  in the cluster.
 
  Example:
    > read me
    > say get(cluster#1/desc)
  
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),

title: CLUSTER_GET_EVAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_GET_EVAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_get_eval(<object>/<attribute>)
 
  The get_eval function returns the specified attribute from the named cluster
  (just like the get function), except that function references and
  ...
explanation:
Function: cluster_get_eval(<object>/<attribute>)
 
  The get_eval function returns the specified attribute from the named cluster
  (just like the get function), except that function references and
  %-substitutions have already been performed.  In function references, 
  'me' refers to the object being looked at, and %-substitutions that refer
  to the enactor (such as %n, %#, etc) refer to the object making the get_eval
  call.  If the attribute is not present on <object>, it searches all clusters
  for the attribute.
 
  Example:
    > @va cluster#1 = This is a get_eval test on %n.  The vb is [get(me/vb)]
    > @vb cluster#1 = VB from test
    > say cluster_get(cluster#1/va)
    You say "This is a get_eval test on %n. The vb is [get(me/vb)]"
    > say cluster_get_eval(cluster#1/va)
    You say "This is a get_eval test on Foobar. The vb is VB from test"
  
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(),

title: CLUSTER_GREP() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_GREP() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_grep(<object>, <attribute(s)>, <pattern>[,<type> [,<key>]])
   
  This returns a list of any matching attribute in a cluster that matches the
  <attribute(s)> that contain <pattern>....
explanation:
Function: cluster_grep(<object>, <attribute(s)>, <pattern>[,<type> [,<key>]])
   
  This returns a list of any matching attribute in a cluster that matches the
  <attribute(s)> that contain <pattern>.  The <attribute> may be wildcarded
  with a '*' or a '?' for multiple character matches and single character
  matches respectively.  In addition, the pattern may also be wildcarded.
  The following types exist:
    0 - show attributes matching pattern (default)
    1 - show the dbref# then all matching attributes after it
    2 - show the attributes in the form dbref#/pattern
  
  You may specify 'key' to '1' to remove assumed wildcard matches and require
  literal wildcard placements.
   
  Examples:
    > @va cluster#1=This is a test
    > @vb cluster#2=This is another test.
    > @vc cluster#3=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say cluster_grep(cluster#1,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB VC"
    > say cluster_grep(cluster#1,v*,is,,1)
    You say "VA VB"
    > say cluster_grep(cluster#2,v*,*is*)
    You say "VA VB VC"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(),

explanation:
Function: cluster_hasattr(<object>/<attribute name>)
            cluster_hasattr(<object>,<attribute name>)
  
  This function checks if the cluster has the matched attribute.  It will 
  search every object in the cluster for the matching attribute returning a
  1 (true) if it exists or a 0 (false) if it does not.
  
  Examples:
    > say cluster_hasattr(cluster#1,desc)
    You say "1"
    > say cluster_hasattr(cluster#1,rubberbabybuggybumper)
    You say "0"

title: CLUSTER_LATTR() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_LATTR() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
+ - List existing lock attributes on player.
$ - list all attributes that are $commands.
& - list all attributes that contain all attribute flags <flg>.
explanation:
Function: cluster_lattr(<obj>[/<wild>][,<tgt>[,<tp>][,<flg>][,<rexp>][,<tr>])
 
  Returns a list of the attributes set on cluster <obj>ect.  If <wild>pattern
  is given, only attributes matching it are returned.  If you have the regexp
  toggle <rexp> as true (1), the matching <wild> is evaluated as a regular
  expression instead of the default matching algorithm.  You may specify the 
  optional target <tgt> if you wish to return attributes that only the target
  could see.  If you do not have control over target, it defaults to yours.
  This searches all objects that are contained in the cluster.
  You may specify tree <tr> viewing if you set it to '1'.
  
  You may specify a type <tp> to check against.  The following types exist:
    + - List existing lock attributes on player.
    $ - list all attributes that are $commands.
    ^ - list all attributes that are ^listens.
    & - list all attributes that contain all attribute flags <flg>.
    | - list all attributes that contain any attribute flags <flg>.
    l - list total attributes and pages of attributes.
    # - page (1, 2, etc) for attribute listing.  118 for 32byte attrs.
    > - find the alphanumerical largest attribute name.
    < - find the alphanumerical smallest attribute name.
    ~ - [~#1-#2] list attribs starting at #1 until count of #2.
  
  { see 'help cluster_lattr2' to continue }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CLUSTER_REGREP() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_REGREP() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_regrep(<object>, <attrs>, <regexp> [,<key>])
  
  This function returns a list of attributes on cluster <object> containing
  <pattern> (or matching <regexp>).  <attrs> is a wildcard...
explanation:
Function: cluster_regrep(<object>, <attrs>, <regexp> [,<key>])
  
  This function returns a list of attributes on cluster <object> containing
  <pattern> (or matching <regexp>).  <attrs> is a wildcard pattern for
  attribute names to search; if you want to search all attributes, use "*".
  
  Parsing _does_ occur before this function is invoked. Therefore,
  "special" characters will need to be escaped out.   This searches all
  objects contained in the specified cluster.
  
  If <key> is specified as '1', attribute wildcards are done with
  regular expression matching.  The default is globbing (* and ?).
  
  This function is case-sensitive. 
  
  Examples:
    > @va cluster#1=This is a test
    > @vb cluster#2=This is another test.
    > @vc cluster#3=Test Test Test whisooo!
    > say cluster_regrep(cluster#1,v*,is)
    You say "VA VB"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(), 
            cluster_hasattr(), cluster_lattr(), cluster_regrep(),

title: CLUSTER_SET() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_SET() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_set(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            cluster_set(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>>)
            cluster_set(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>>)
    ...
explanation:
Function: cluster_set(<object>,<[!]<flag> [[!]<flag> [!]<flag> ...]>)
            cluster_set(<object>,<<attribute>:<value>>)
            cluster_set(<object>,<<attribute>:_<fromobj>/<fromattr>>)
            cluster_set(<object>/<attr>,[!]<attrflag>)
  
  The cluster_set() function is a side-effect for the @cluster/set command.  
  Everything that worked with @cluster/set will work with cluster_set().  It 
  follows the same permissions and restrictions of the command.  The SIDEFX 
  flag is required to use cluster_set().  For flags, this will set the flags 
  on ALL objects in the cluster.
  
  Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  
  Example:
  > @cluster/set cluster#1=safe
  Cluster: Flags (safe) set on cluster members #3672 #3667 #3683
  > say cluster_set(me,safe)
  You say ""

description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_STATS() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_stats(<object>,<type> [,<attribute name>])
  
  This function returns various statistics for the cluster specified.  The 
  following <type> is available for the cluster:
      0 - r...
explanation:
Function: cluster_stats(<object>,<type> [,<attribute name>])
  
  This function returns various statistics for the cluster specified.  The 
  following <type> is available for the cluster:
      0 - return 1 if specified object is a cluster, 0 if not (default).
      1 - return the list of objects contained in the specified cluster.
      2 - return the action list for the specified cluster.
      3 - return the threshold value for the specified cluster.
      4 - return dbref# where the attribute name exists in the specified 
          cluster.  Third option must be used for this option.
  
  Examples:
    > &FOOBAR #234=Boo
    Set.
    > say [cluster_stats(cluster#1,0)] | [cluster_stats(cluster#1,1)]
    You say "1 | #123 #234 #345"
    > say cluster_stats(cluster#1,2)
    You say "@pemit owner(me)=Cluster exceeded!"
    > say cluster_stats(cluster#1,3)
    You say "700"
    > say cluster_stats(cluster#1,4,foobar)
    You say "#234"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),

explanation:
Function: cluster_u([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
   
  The cluster_u function evaluates an attribute, either from the object 
  performing the function or from another object you own, passing in arguments
  and returning the result.  It searches the entire cluster for the matching 
  attribute.
  
  See '@list options' to see if this functionality switched with u2()'.
  This will be switched if 'u() TinyMUSH compatibility' is enabled.
   
  Examples:
    > @va cluster#1=Word is [extract(cluster_get(me/vb),add(%0,1),1)], arg2:%1.
    > @vb cluster#2=This is a test of the u function.
    > say cluster_u(cluster#3/va,4,Testing 123)
    You say "Word is of, arg2:Testing 123."
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),

title: CLUSTER_U2() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_U2() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_u2([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
  
  This is nearly exactly like the original cluster_u() function except it 
  parses in an object-dependant way like the old mushes.  It works by 
  e...
explanation:
Function: cluster_u2([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
  
  This is nearly exactly like the original cluster_u() function except it 
  parses in an object-dependant way like the old mushes.  It works by 
  evaluating the function(s) by the power of the owner of the item it's 
  on, and not by the power of the enactor.  
  
  This command is also very handy to keep security.
  
  See '@list options' to see if this functionality switched with cluster_u2()'.
  This will be switched if 'u() TinyMUSH compatibility' is enabled.
   
  For examples or more information, look at cluster_u()
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(),

code:

  Works like cluster_udefault() but uses the u2() function instead of u()
  
  This function returns the value of the user-de...
explanation:
Function:  cluster_u2default([<obj>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
   
  Works like cluster_udefault() but uses the u2() function instead of u()
  
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <obj>/<attr>), as if retrieved via
  the cluster_u2() function, with <args>, if the attribute exists and is
  readable by you.
   
  Otherwise, it evaluates the default case, and returns that. The
  default case is only evaluated if the attribute does not exist
  or cannot be read.
 
  Examples:
    > &TEST cluster#1=[center(%0,5,*)]
    > say cluster_u2default(cluster#1/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),

Function:  cluster_u2ldefault([<obj>/]<attr>,<default case>[,<arg>]...)
   
  This function returns the value of the user-defined function
  as defined by <attr> (or <obj>/<attr>), as if retrieved via

  %q0-%q9 registers.
   
  Examples:

    > say cluster_u2ldefault(cluster#1/Test,-- BOOM --,ACK)
    You say "*ACK*"

title: CLUSTER_U2LOCAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_U2LOCAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function:  cluster_u2local([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The cluster_u2local() function is almost identical to u2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the fu...
explanation:
Function:  cluster_u2local([<obj>/]<attr>[,<arg>]...)
 
  The cluster_u2local() function is almost identical to u2() in function:  it
  evaluates an attribute, either from the object performing the function,
  or another object that you control or has the same owner as you, passing
  in arguments and returning the result. When evaluating the fetched
  attribute, %# refers to the original enactor and not the 'calling' object;
  'me' refers to the object that supplied the attribute.
 
  However, unlike the u2() function, the global registers r(0) through r(9)
  (%q0 - %q9) are preserved in their initial state. This means that functions
  "below" the level of the u2() can reset global registers for temporary
  calculations, without needing to worry about "clobbering" the original
  values.
 
  This makes cluster_u2local() particularly useful for global or shared code 
  which calls arbitrary u2() functions, where global register values need to be
  preserved from accidental user clobbering.
  
  This function searches all objects in the cluster for the matching attribute.
   
{ See "help cluster_u2local2" for examples. }
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: CLUSTER_U2LOCAL2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_U2LOCAL2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Example of cluster_u2local():
    > &FRUIT cluster#1=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION cluster#2=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION cluster#3=[setq(0,a...
explanation:
Example of cluster_u2local():
    > &FRUIT cluster#1=apples bananas oranges pears
    > &SUB-FUNCTION cluster#2=[setq(0,v(FRUIT))][extract(%q0,match(%q0,%0),1)]
    > &TOP-FUNCTION cluster#3=[setq(0,are delicious!)]
                              [cluster_u2local(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say cluster_u2(cluster#1/TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas are delicious!"
   
  If SUB-FUNCTION had been called with cluster_u2() and not cluster_u2local():
    > &TOP-FUNCTION me=[setq(0,are yummy!)][cluster_u2(SUB-FUNCTION,%0)] %q0
    > say cluster_u2(TOP-FUNCTION,b*)
    You say "bananas apples bananas oranges pears"
   
  In this second example, in SUB-FUNCTION, %q0 was set to "apples bananas
  oranges pears", so that when the cluster_u2() "returned" and TOP-FUNCTION 
  evaluated %q0, this is what was printed. In the first example, 
  cluster_u2local() reset the value of %q0 to its original "are delicious!"
 
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),

title: CLUSTER_UEVAL() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_UEVAL() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_ueval([<obj>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The cluster_ueval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object 
  performing the function or from another object you own,...
explanation:
Function: cluster_ueval([<obj>/]<attr>/permission[,<arg>],...)
  
  The cluster_ueval function evaluates an attribute, either from the object 
  performing the function or from another object you own, passing in 
  arguments and returning the result.  In this way it works just like 
  'cluster_u()', except you pass in a permission to specify what permission 
  level you wish to use for evaluation.  
   
  The available permission levels are CIT[IZEN], GUILD[MASTER], ARCH[ITECT],
  COUN[CILOR], ROY[ALTY], IMM[ORTAL].  You must have the permissions of the
  given level in order to use it else it defaults to your permission level.
  The permission must be included for the function to work.
  
  Examples:
    > @set cluster#1=royalty (let's assume you're a wizard)
    > @va cluster#1=[num(*Miriar)] (the ghod player - #1)
    > say cluster_ueval(va/royalty)
    You say "#1"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(), 
            cluster_hasattr(), cluster_lattr(), cluster_regrep(), 
            cluster_regrepi(), cluster_set(), cluster_stats(), cluster_u(),

            cluster_uldefault(), cluster_ulocal(), cluster_vattrcnt(),

explanation:
Function: cluster_vattrcnt(<object>)
  This function counts just the user-defined attributes that exist on
  a cluster.  User defined attributes are attributes that are set
  with the &attr object=string or @set object=attr:string commands and
  have no @<attribute> ability. (like @va, @desc, etc)
  
  To set attributes on clusters, you would use >attr object=string or
  @cluster/set cluster=attr:string.
  
  Examples:
    > say vattrcnt(cluster#1)
    You say "714"
    > say cluster_vattrcnt(cluster#1)
    You say "7123"
    > say cluster_attrcnt(cluster#1)
    You say "9175
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(), 
            cluster_hasattr(), cluster_lattr(), cluster_regrep(), 
            cluster_regrepi(), cluster_set(), cluster_stats(), cluster_u(), 
            cluster_u2(), cluster_u2default(), cluster_u2ldefault(), 
            cluster_u2local(), cluster_udefault(), cluster_ueval(), 
            cluster_uldefault(), cluster_ulocal(), cluster_vattrcnt(), 
            cluster_wipe(), cluster_xget(), iscluster(), cluster_flags(), 
            cluster_hasflag(), cluster_add()

title: CLUSTER_WIPE() - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for CLUSTER_WIPE() command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Function: cluster_wipe(<obj>[/wildattr] [[,<regexp>] [,<ownkey>] [,<pres>]])
            cluster_wipe(<owner>/<obj>[/wildattr], [,<regexp>], 1, [,<pres>])
  
  The cluster_wipe() function will remove ...
explanation:
Function: cluster_wipe(<obj>[/wildattr] [[,<regexp>] [,<ownkey>] [,<pres>]])
            cluster_wipe(<owner>/<obj>[/wildattr], [,<regexp>], 1, [,<pres>])
  
  The cluster_wipe() function will remove all matching attributes 
  specified by a wildcard, or, if no attribute is specified, 
  remove all attributes of the specified cluster.  This function 
  works like @cluster/wipe and follows all permissions and 
  restrictions of the matching command.
  
  If <regexp> is specified as '1', then <wildattr> is evaluated as a
  regular expression instead of the default expression.
  
  If <ownkey> is specified as '1', then, as the second syntax example above,
  it takes the additional <owner> argument as the owner to compare against.
  
  If <pres> is specified as '1', it takes the reverse of the wipe and
  keeps (preserves) the specified wildcard pattern and wipes everything else.
  
  Check @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled.
  Anything using this side-effect must have the SIDEFX flag set.
  
  Examples:
    > say cluster_wipe(Corum/#123/*foo,,1)  
    You say "Wiped: [20 objects: 0 not found, 0 safe] 1 attributes wiped."
    > say cluster_wipe(#123)
    You say "Wiped: [20 objects: 0 not found, 0 safe] 127 attributes wiped."
    > say cluster_wipe(#123/*foo*)
    You say "Wiped: [20 objects: 0 not found, 0 safe] 0 attributes wiped."
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(), 
            cluster_hasattr(), cluster_lattr(), cluster_regrep(), 
            cluster_regrepi(), cluster_set(), cluster_stats(), cluster_u(), 
            cluster_u2(), cluster_u2default(), cluster_u2ldefault(), 
            cluster_u2local(), cluster_udefault(), cluster_ueval(), 
            cluster_uldefault(), cluster_ulocal(), cluster_vattrcnt(), 
            cluster_wipe(), cluster_xget(), iscluster(), cluster_flags(), 
            cluster_hasflag(), cluster_add()

Function: cluster_xget(<object>,<attribute>)
   
  The xget function fetches the specified attribute from the named object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
 ...
explanation:
Function: cluster_xget(<object>,<attribute>)
   
  The xget function fetches the specified attribute from the named object.
  It can be used to get attributes from objects you own, public and visual
  attributes of objects near you, and public and visual attributes other
  than the description of players wherever they may be.  If the attribute is
  not present on <object>, its parent is searched for the attribute.
  This searches all objects in the specified cluster.
   
  Example:
    > read cluster#1
    > say cluster_xget(cluster#1,desc)
    You say "My Desc"
  
  See Also: @cluster, cluster_attrcnt(), cluster_default(), cluster_edefault(),
            cluster_get(), cluster_get_eval(), cluster_grep(), 
            cluster_hasattr(), cluster_lattr(), cluster_regrep(), 
            cluster_regrepi(), cluster_set(), cluster_stats(), cluster_u(), 
            cluster_u2(), cluster_u2default(), cluster_u2ldefault(), 
            cluster_u2local(), cluster_udefault(), cluster_ueval(),

title: mail - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for mail command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
mail_def_object - This is dynamic aliases
- This is an @admin parameter (or .conf file parameter)
that will specify the object you wish the alias to go.
&ALIAS.<aliasname> dbref#=<function>
&COMMENT.<aliasname> dbref#=<comment for alias>
wmail/alias will show the global static aliases, locks for them, and the
&ALIAS.<aliasname> dbref#=<function>
&COMMENT.<aliasname> dbref#=<comment for alias>
explanation:
There are two ways to set up global aliases.  The first is with the command:
     wmail/alias     - This is static aliases
                     - refer to 'wizhelp wmail alias' on setting them up.
                     - This can't be added to but rewritten with changes.
                     Syntax: wmail/alias <alias>=<list-of-players>
  
     mail_def_object - This is dynamic aliases
                     - This is an @admin parameter (or .conf file parameter)
                       that will specify the object you wish the alias to go.
                     - This requires mush-softcode functions that will return
                       a list of dbref#'s that will be used by mail.
                     Syntax: @admin mail_def_object=<valid dbref# w/o the '#'>
                             &ALIAS.<aliasname> dbref#=<function>
                             &COMMENT.<aliasname> dbref#=<comment for alias>  
  
  wmail/alias will show the global static aliases, locks for them, and the 
  current dbref# that is being used (if any) for the dynamic aliases.
  
  mail/alias will show you (and the normal player) the aliases.  Both dynamic,
  and static.  It will list the player list with static, but _NOT_ with the
  dynamic ones.  That is why there's a comment to describe it.
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: MAIL-OBFUSCATE - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for MAIL-OBFUSCATE command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Topic: MAIL-OBFUSCATE
  
  Wizards may obfuscate where it appears the mail comes from.  This is just
  an obfuscation.  Mail can still be replied or fowarded to the original
  writer and it will displ...
explanation:
Topic: MAIL-OBFUSCATE
  
  Wizards may obfuscate where it appears the mail comes from.  This is just
  an obfuscation.  Mail can still be replied or fowarded to the original
  writer and it will display their real name in this case.
  
  This is intended for system based mails so that players will have a better
  understanding of where a given mail may have come from.  
  
  The underlying sender remains the same.  It is just obfuscated.
  
  For a wizard to obfsucate a sender, they need to set an attribute to the
  target of where they want it to show it came from.  This can be any valid
  dbref#, including non-players.  
  
  Please be aware that it assumes a 16 character name and formatting may
  break if the name of the target exceeds this, but it's just a display issue.
  
  Examples:
    > @create An Obfuscation
    An Obfuscation created as dbref #12345
    > &OBF me=#12345
    Set.
    > mail *player=<obf>My Subject//My Body
    Mail: Message sent to -> Player
  
  See Also: mail send, mail topics
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: MAILNOTIFY - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for MAILNOTIFY command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Attribute: &MAILNOTIFY
  
  This attribute, when set on a player, will send a message to the person
  mailing them depending on the evaluated text in the attribute.
  
  If the message evaluates to an...
explanation:
Attribute: &MAILNOTIFY
  
  This attribute, when set on a player, will send a message to the person
  mailing them depending on the evaluated text in the attribute.
  
  If the message evaluates to an empty string, no message is sent.
  
  The following arguments are passed for evaluation:
              %0  - the dbref# of the player (or #-1 if anonymous)
              %1  - the subject of the message
              %2  - the body of the message
              %3  - the date/time of the message
  
  Examples:
    > &mailnotify me=Hi, [name(%0)]!  You sent me mail!
    Set.
    > think [name(me)]
    Bob
    > mail me=Test!
    Hi, Bob!  You sent me mail!
    Mail: You have new mail from -> Bob
    Mail: Message sent to -> Bob
    Mail: Done
    > think [name(me)]
    Betty
    > mail bob=Test!
    Hi, Betty! You sent me mail!
    Mail: Message sent to -> Bob
    Mail: Done
  
  See Also: @mailsig, &mailfilter
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: MAILFILTER - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for MAILFILTER command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Attribute: &MAILFILTER
  
  This attribute, when set on a player, will allow that player individual
  control of where the mail will go.  This allows the player to redirect
  incoming mail into pre-ex...
explanation:
Attribute: &MAILFILTER
  
  This attribute, when set on a player, will allow that player individual
  control of where the mail will go.  This allows the player to redirect
  incoming mail into pre-existing folders.  The following are passed:
              %0  - the dbref# of the player (or #-1 if anonymous)
              %1  - the subject of the message
              %2  - the body of the message
              %3  - the date/time of the message
  Examples:
    > folder/list
      Mail: You have the following folders ->
      Incoming Testing Junk
    > &MAILFILTER me=[switch(%0,#123,Testing,#234,Junk)]
      Set.
    > think [num(me)] [name(me)]
      #123 Yourself
    > mail me=A Test//A Test
      Mail: You have new mail from -> Yourself [Subj: A Test]
      Mail: Auto-Moved to folder -> Testing
      Mail: Message sent to -> Yourself
    > (receiving mail from Bob, dbref #999)
      Mail: You have new mail from -> Bob [Subj: Hey!]
    > (receiving mail from Tony, dbref #234)
      Mail: You have new mail from -> Tony [Subj: You smell]
      Mail: Auto-Moved to folder -> Junk
  
  See Also: @mailsig, &mailnotify
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

  allows you filter incoming mail by either the target player or the subject.
  If the mail was sent anonymously, the player is returned as #-1, otherwise

title: mail-aliases - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for mail-aliases command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
+alias  -- global STATIC mail alias shown with 'mail/alias'
$alias  -- global DYNAMIC mail alias shown with 'mail/alias'
&alias  -- personal STATIC alias with attribute named after '&'
explanation:
Topic: MAIL-ALIASES
  
  RhostMUSH allows multiple ways to set and utilize aliases for mail.
  Global aliases can be seen with 'mail/alias'.  Personal aliases are
  just normal attributes you would set on yourself.
  
  Summation:
       +alias  -- global STATIC mail alias shown with 'mail/alias'
       $alias  -- global DYNAMIC mail alias shown with 'mail/alias'
       &alias  -- personal STATIC alias with attribute named after '&'
       ~alias  -- personal DYNAMIC alias with attribute named after '~'
  
  Usage Example:
       mail/send +foo $bar &baz ~beep=My mail!
  
  mail/alias will show all the global mail aliases, if it's a static mail
  alias or a dynamic mail alias, or if there's any locks that make it so
  you can not use them.  To use a static mail alias, you would prepend a '+'
  before the alias.  Such as:
  
     mail +wizards=To all Wizards!
  
  For dynamic mail aliases, you would prepend a '$' before the alias.
  
     mail $wizards=To all Wizards!
  
  You will see with mail/alias if it's a static global (+) or a dynamic
  global ($) mail alias to help avoid confusion.
  
  {see 'help mail-aliases2' for personal mail aliases}
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

title: mail-aliases2 - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for mail-aliases2 command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
@@ set the attribute with the players you want to send to
@@ mail using the previously set personal alias
@@ set the attribute with an evaluation
@@ mail using the previously set personal alias
explanation:
Topic: MAIL-ALIASES (continued)
  
  Personal mail aliases are nothing more than attributes that you would 
  set on yourself.  Please refer to 'help &' on setting attributes.
  
  Static aliases are fetched with using a prefix of '&' for an alias.
  This will take the contents of your attribute verbatum as the list.
  
  Examples: 
     @@ set the attribute with the players you want to send to
     > &myfriends me=Bob Sarah #456 Julie
     @@ mail using the previously set personal alias
     > mail/send &myfriends=Mail to my friends.

  Note: Any non-players will automatically be stripped in the sending of 
        the mail (with appropriate warning messages).  
  
  Dynamic aliases use the same attribute structure above.  However, 
  instead of a prefix of '&' you would use '~'.  This tells the mail system
  to evaluate the contents of your attribute for the send list.
  
    Exmaple: 
      @@ set the attribute with an evaluation
      > &list1 me=Sue
      > &list2 me=Bob
      > &morefriends me=[get(me/list1)] [get(me/list2)]
      @@ mail using the previously set personal alias
      > mail ~morefriends=To all of my friends!
  
  For help on setting attributes, please check help for '&' or '@set'.
  
  See Also: mail topics
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

Topic: MAIL-DELETING
  
  The following is used to delete mail:
     mail/mark <range|message|*player>        [help mail mark]
        - This marks the message(s) for deleting.
     mail/mark/save <range|message|*player>   [help mail save]
        - This marks the message(s) for saving from deleting.
     mail/unmark <range|message|*player>      [help mail unmark]
        - This removes the mark from the message

        - This removes the saved mark from the message
     mail/delete                              [help mail delete]

description: Help documentation for mail-reading command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
Topic: MAIL-READING
  
  The following commands are used to read the mail:
     mail new                    [help mail new]
        - This reads the first new message
     mail nall                   ...
explanation:
Topic: MAIL-READING
  
  The following commands are used to read the mail:
     mail new                    [help mail new]
        - This reads the first new message
     mail nall                   [help mail nall]
        - This reads ALL new mail messages (can be spammy).
     mail unread                 [help mail unread]
        - This reads the first unread message
     mail uall                   [help mail uall]
        - This reads ALL unread mail messages (can be spammy).
     mail both                   [help mail both]
        - This reads the first new OR unread message
     mail ball                   [help mail ball]
        - This reads BOTH ALL unread AND new mail messages (can be spammy).
     mail #                      [help mail read]
        - This reads the specified message #.
     mail/status                 [help mail status]
        - This displays all the mail in your mailbox
     mail/quick                  [help mail quick]
        - This gives you a quick status of your mailbox.
     mail +all
        - This will read all your mail.
     mail/read/save 
        - This option will output mail in an MBOX format
  
  See Also: mail quick, mail status, mail read, mail topics, mail main
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios

  The following commands are used to share a mailbox with a friend:
     mail/share <key>              [help mail share]
        - You may refer to 'help @lock keys' on how to set this.
     folder/share <mailbox>        [help folder share]

          pass the mail/share lock above, will be able to see the folders.
     mail/number <player>          [help mail number]

     mail/check <player>=<message> [help mail check]

title: mail-writing - RhostMUSH Help
description: Help documentation for mail-writing command/function in RhostMUSH
code:
@toggle me=brandy_mail mail_stripreturn       [set up interface]
@toggle me=!brandy_mail penn_mail             [set up interface]
explanation:
Topic: MAIL-WRITING
  
  The following commands exist for writing new mail messages:
     Brandy/@mail
        @toggle me=brandy_mail mail_stripreturn       [set up interface]
        mail[/forward|reply] <player(s)>=<subj>       [start message]
           -<new line of text>                        [add new text]
        mail/write +feditall=old,new                  [edit text]
        mail/write +forget                            [toss message]
        mail/write +subject=<text>                    [reset the subject]
        mail/write +acc=<players>                     [append to players]
        mail/write +cc=<players>                      [reset the players]
           --                                         [send off mail] (or)
           -~                                         [send mail anonymously]
        mail/send <player(s)>=<subject>//<body>       [quick-send of mail]
  
     PENN @mail
        @toggle me=!brandy_mail penn_mail             [set up interface]
        mail <player-list>=<subject>/<body>           [send message]
  
     Seawolf(Rhost) Mail -- Base mail system
         mail <player-list>=<subject>//<body>         [send mail - type 1]
         mail/write <start of text>                   [first line of text]
            -<new line of text>                       [add new text]
         mail/write +subject=<subject>                [set subject]
         mail/write [+send|+forward|+reply]=<players> [send message - type 2]
         mail/write/anon [+send|+forward|+reply]=<pl> [send anonymously -tp 3]
  
  See Also: mail main, mail topics, mail cmdlist, mail write cmdlist
learningObjectives: Apply help documentation in practical scenarios
